{"response": {"status": "ok", "userTier": "developer", "total": 433, "startIndex": 401, "pageSize": 200, "currentPage": 3, "pages": 3, "orderBy": "newest", "results": [{"id": "books/2023/apr/18/the-best-recent-and-thriller-writing-review-roundup", "type": "article", "sectionId": "books", "sectionName": "Books", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T06:00:36Z", "webTitle": "The best recent crime and thriller writing \u2013 review roundup", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/apr/18/the-best-recent-and-thriller-writing-review-roundup", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/books/2023/apr/18/the-best-recent-and-thriller-writing-review-roundup", "fields": {"headline": "The best recent crime and thriller writing \u2013 review roundup", "standfirst": "<p>A village treasure hunt digs up trouble, a game of dares goes too far and a Mary Higgins Clark classic is revisited in this month\u2019s highlights</p>", "trailText": "A village treasure hunt digs up trouble, a game of dares goes too far and a Mary Higgins Clark classic is revisited in this month\u2019s highlights", "byline": "Alison Flood", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"cec5e94bc6902dc09e6a7af1b11f362aec0f69bf\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/cec5e94bc6902dc09e6a7af1b11f362aec0f69bf/0_86_5200_3120/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Murder in an English village in Stig Abell\u2019s Death Under a Little Sky\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Murder in an English village in Stig Abell\u2019s Death Under a Little Sky.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: David J Green/Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Anna Bradshaw remembers nothing when she wakes in a London hospital after an accident. Her husband, Stephen, feels like a total stranger to her; the details of her life are a mystery. \u201cIt is as though there is an impenetrable black box in my head, like the flight recorder of a crashed plane, but it is locked and tightly sealed and there is no way for me to access it.\u201d Meanwhile, in Bristol, Livvy Nicholson has a six-month-old son, a loving new husband, Dominic, and a yearning to get back to work that is being inadvertently thwarted by Dominic\u2019s plans for his own career. There are shades of <em>Before I Go to Sleep</em>, SJ Watson\u2019s debut novel about a woman with amnesia, in Hannah Beckerman\u2019s <strong><a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/the-forgetting-9781542030380\">The Forgetting</a></strong><a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/the-forgetting-9781542030380\"> </a>(Lake Union), but that\u2019s no bad thing: Beckerman gives the amnesia trope her own twist to create a compelling, claustrophobic story. In the best possible way, this is a hugely stressful read, as we watch both women slowly come to realise the truth about their situations, urging them on from the sidelines. I finished it in one huge gulp, excusing myself unilaterally from any family responsibilities I was so desperate to finish it.</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/death-under-a-little-sky-9780008517014\">Death Under a Little Sky</a></strong> (HarperCollins) is journalist Stig Abell\u2019s first novel and a joyful dive into the detective genre. Jake Jackson is a washed-upcop, disillusioned with his career and his marriage. So when his uncle dies, leaving him a property in the middle of nowhere, he gives it all up to begin a new life off-grid: long runs, morning swims in his private lake, minimal interaction with the world at large and time to read through his uncle\u2019s vast library of detective novels. He is sucked back in, though, both by beautiful neighbour Livia Bennet and by the discovery, during a treasure hunt around the nearby village of Caelum Parvum, or Little Sky, of a young woman\u2019s bones. What really happened to her and who can Jake really trust out here? Abell\u2019s enjoyment of the genre shines through, as Jake ponders what the likes of Jack Reacher might do in a messy situation, and as he and Livia team up to investigate, becoming \u201cJackson and Bennet, the crime-fighters of Little Sky\u201d, another of crime fiction\u2019s detective duos. I was charmed and engrossed \u2013 by Jake\u2019s self-reinvention, by Abell\u2019s eccentric cast of characters (\u201cIt\u2019s the middle of the day in a picturesque English church. We are, together, a burnt-out ex-cop, a beautiful vet and a fairly eccentric botanist\u2026 I don\u2019t think we should be desecrating a mausoleum\u201d) and by the increasing sense of menace, as Jake digs into what happened to the dead girl.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--supporting\"> <blockquote> <p>Abell\u2019s love of the genre shines through, as Jake ponders what Jack Reacher might do in a messy situation</p> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>In Laura Vaughan\u2019s psychological thriller <strong><a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/search.php?search_query=Hazard+Night\">Hazard Night</a></strong> (Corvus), Eve\u2019s husband, Peter, takes a job as a housemaster at his old, minor public school, Cleeve College, remembering his time there as \u201cthe best years\u201d of his life. To Eve, public schools are \u201calien territory\u201d, and at first she commutes to her own job in London, but when she becomes pregnant she gives it up and settles into life at Cleeve. Motherhood drains her \u2013 \u201csoon all of Eve\u2019s time was spent waiting, waiting, waiting for the day to pass\u201d \u2013 until the new classics teacher, Gabriel Easton, and his wife, Fen, arrive. Fen draws Eve into a game of dares, breaking the school\u2019s various rules: \u201cPlagiarising, cheating, drinking \u2019n\u2019 drug-taking, lying, stealing, trespassing, failing to report a violation\u2026 Any one of those activities is a hundred per cent more fun than another round of watery coffee with the beards\u201d (beards being Cleeve\u2019s delightful term for the \u201ccampus wives\u201d). Things escalate, until, on the school\u2019s annual Hazard Night \u2013 an evening of pranks after exams are finished \u2013 a body is found. Moving between the perspectives of Eve and Alice, the daughter of the school chaplain, Vaughan slowly and ominously unpicks the rotten core of Cleeve, a place where \u201cfemale rage had little currency\u201d and where privilege ends up being no protection. Atmospheric and sinister.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2020/feb/03/mary-higgins-clark-dies-aged-92\">Mary Higgins Clark</a>\u2019s first suspense novel, <em>Where Are the Children?</em>, was, I think, the book that first made me fall for thrillers \u2013 I read this terrifying tale of kidnapped children and marital abuse far too young and absolutely adored it. Now Alafair Burke and the late Higgins Clark have written a sequel, <strong><a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/where-are-the-children-now-9781471197338\">Where Are the Children Now?</a></strong> (Simon &amp; Schuster) in which those kidnapped children Mike and Missy are adults. Melissa is now a lawyer turned true-crime podcaster who has blocked out all memory of the time she was abducted. She has just married a widower with a young daughter, Riley, and is helping her mother, Nancy \u2013 who, in the first novel, was accused of murdering her first two children, released on a technicality and then under suspicion for murdering Mike and Missy until she rescued them \u2013 to move house. Then Riley disappears from her cot and the past has to be raked up all over again. I enjoyed being back in the company of these well-remembered characters \u2013 but really, all this sequel did was make me want to read the original again. Higgins Clark: much missed, seldom bettered.</p> <p>\u2022 To order any of these books for a special price click on the titles or go to <a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/\">guardianbookshop.com</a>. Fen draws Eve into a game of dares, breaking the school\u2019s various rules: \u201cPlagiarising, cheating, drinking \u2019n\u2019 drug-taking, lying, stealing, trespassing, failing to report a violation\u2026 Any one of those activities is a hundred per cent more fun than another round of watery coffee with the beards\u201d (beards being Cleeve\u2019s delightful term for the \u201ccampus wives\u201d). Things escalate, until, on the school\u2019s annual Hazard Night \u2013 an evening of pranks after exams are finished \u2013 a body is found. Moving between the perspectives of Eve and Alice, the daughter of the school chaplain, Vaughan slowly and ominously unpicks the rotten core of Cleeve, a place where \u201cfemale rage had little currency\u201d and where privilege ends up being no protection. Atmospheric and sinister.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2020/feb/03/mary-higgins-clark-dies-aged-92\">Mary Higgins Clark</a>\u2019s first suspense novel, <em>Where Are the Children?</em>, was, I think, the book that first made me fall for thrillers \u2013 I read this terrifying tale of kidnapped children and marital abuse far too young and absolutely adored it. Now Alafair Burke and the late Higgins Clark have written a sequel, <strong><a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/where-are-the-children-now-9781471197338\">Where Are the Children Now?</a></strong> (Simon &amp; Schuster) in which those kidnapped children Mike and Missy are adults. Melissa is now a lawyer turned true-crime podcaster who has blocked out all memory of the time she was abducted. She has just married a widower with a young daughter, Riley, and is helping her mother, Nancy \u2013 who, in the first novel, was accused of murdering her first two children, released on a technicality and then under suspicion for murdering Mike and Missy until she rescued them \u2013 to move house. Then Riley disappears from her cot and the past has to be raked up all over again. I enjoyed being back in the company of these well-remembered characters \u2013 but really, all this sequel did was make me want to read the original again. Higgins Clark: much missed, seldom bettered.</p> <p>\u2022 To order any of these books for a special price click on the titles or go to <a href=\"https://guardianbookshop.com/\">guardianbookshop.com</a>. Delivery charges may apply</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Anna Bradshaw remembers nothing when she wakes in a London hospital after an accident. Her husband, Stephen, feels like a total stranger to her; the details of her life are a mystery. \u201cIt is as though there is an impenetrable black box in my head, like the flight recorder of a crashed plane, but it is locked and tightly sealed and there is no way for me to access it.\u201d Meanwhile, in Bristol, Livvy Nicholson has a six-month-old son, a loving new husband, Dominic, and a yearning to get back to work that is being inadvertently thwarted by Dominic\u2019s plans for his own career. There are shades of Before I Go to Sleep, SJ Watson\u2019s debut novel about a woman with amnesia, in Hannah Beckerman\u2019s The Forgetting (Lake Union), but that\u2019s no bad thing: Beckerman gives the amnesia trope her own twist to create a compelling, claustrophobic story. In the best possible way, this is a hugely stressful read, as we watch both women slowly come to realise the truth about their situations, urging them on from the sidelines. I finished it in one huge gulp, excusing myself unilaterally from any family responsibilities I was so desperate to finish it. Death Under a Little Sky (HarperCollins) is journalist Stig Abell\u2019s first novel and a joyful dive into the detective genre. Jake Jackson is a washed-upcop, disillusioned with his career and his marriage. So when his uncle dies, leaving him a property in the middle of nowhere, he gives it all up to begin a new life off-grid: long runs, morning swims in his private lake, minimal interaction with the world at large and time to read through his uncle\u2019s vast library of detective novels. He is sucked back in, though, both by beautiful neighbour Livia Bennet and by the discovery, during a treasure hunt around the nearby village of Caelum Parvum, or Little Sky, of a young woman\u2019s bones. What really happened to her and who can Jake really trust out here? Abell\u2019s enjoyment of the genre shines through, as Jake ponders what the likes of Jack Reacher might do in a messy situation, and as he and Livia team up to investigate, becoming \u201cJackson and Bennet, the crime-fighters of Little Sky\u201d, another of crime fiction\u2019s detective duos. I was charmed and engrossed \u2013 by Jake\u2019s self-reinvention, by Abell\u2019s eccentric cast of characters (\u201cIt\u2019s the middle of the day in a picturesque English church. We are, together, a burnt-out ex-cop, a beautiful vet and a fairly eccentric botanist\u2026 I don\u2019t think we should be desecrating a mausoleum\u201d) and by the increasing sense of menace, as Jake digs into what happened to the dead girl.\nIn Laura Vaughan\u2019s psychological thriller Hazard Night (Corvus), Eve\u2019s husband, Peter, takes a job as a housemaster at his old, minor public school, Cleeve College, remembering his time there as \u201cthe best years\u201d of his life. To Eve, public schools are \u201calien territory\u201d, and at first she commutes to her own job in London, but when she becomes pregnant she gives it up and settles into life at Cleeve. Motherhood drains her \u2013 \u201csoon all of Eve\u2019s time was spent waiting, waiting, waiting for the day to pass\u201d \u2013 until the new classics teacher, Gabriel Easton, and his wife, Fen, arrive. Fen draws Eve into a game of dares, breaking the school\u2019s various rules: \u201cPlagiarising, cheating, drinking \u2019n\u2019 drug-taking, lying, stealing, trespassing, failing to report a violation\u2026 Any one of those activities is a hundred per cent more fun than another round of watery coffee with the beards\u201d (beards being Cleeve\u2019s delightful term for the \u201ccampus wives\u201d). Things escalate, until, on the school\u2019s annual Hazard Night \u2013 an evening of pranks after exams are finished \u2013 a body is found. Moving between the perspectives of Eve and Alice, the daughter of the school chaplain, Vaughan slowly and ominously unpicks the rotten core of Cleeve, a place where \u201cfemale rage had little currency\u201d and where privilege ends up being no protection. Images</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure>", "body": "<p>Good morning.</p> \n<p>Sudan has found itself in the midst of another crisis, as fighting erupted in the capital, Khartoum, over the weekend between rival military groups after months of growing disquiet over the future of the country and its democracy.</p> \n<p>It has only been four years since the country\u2019s dictator, President Omar al-Bashir, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/apr/11/omar-al-bashir-sudan-ousted-regime-president\">was ousted after three decades of vicious rule</a> and euphoria filled the streets as people demanded democratic rule. Things have not quite gone to plan \u2013 two of the country\u2019s most powerful generals, General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/mohamed-hamdan-dagalo-the-feared-ex-warlord-taking-on-sudan-army-hemedti\">Lieutenant General Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo</a> (more commonly known as Hemedti or \u201clittle Mohammed\u201d), came together in 2021 to take power in a military coup. It was an alliance that has proved short lived as al-Burhan, the head of the army, and Hemedti, the leader of the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces (RSF), have now turned on each other, with the people of Sudan stuck in the middle.</p> \n<p>In today\u2019s newsletter, I take a look at the events that have led up to this moment and what it might mean for people living in Sudan.</p> \n<h2>Five big stories</h2> \n<ol> \n <li><p><em><strong>Health |</strong></em> MPs in the women and equalities committee have <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/apr/18/mps-condemn-failure-to-tackle-glaring-racial-inequalities-in-uk-maternal-health\">accused ministers of failing to tackle</a> \u201cappalling\u201d and \u201cglaring\u201d racial disparities in maternal health despite repeated promises. They have called for new targets to eliminate inequalities.</p></li> \n <li><p><em><strong>UK news</strong></em> <em><strong>|</strong></em> A serving police sergeant in Plymouth <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/17/police-officer-david-stansbury-charged-with-raping-woman-while-on-duty-plymouth\">faces three rape charges</a> for allegedly raping a woman while he was on duty more than a decade ago. The alleged offences took place in 2009 and were reported to the police in 2020.</p></li> \n <li><p><em><strong>France</strong></em> <em><strong>|</strong></em> Air France and Airbus <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/air-france-and-airbus-cleared-of-involuntary-manslaughter-over-2009-crash\">have been cleared of involuntary manslaughter</a> over a 2009 crash that killed 228 people. The court ruled \u201cno certain causal link\u201d with the accident could be shown.</p></li> \n <li><p><em><strong>Ukraine</strong></em> <em><strong>|</strong></em> Slovakia has joined Poland and Hungary in their decision<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/slovakia-joins-poland-hungary-halting-ukraine-grain-imports\"> to stop imports of grain and other food products from Ukraine</a> to protect local farmers. The European Commission and Kyiv have criticised these bans and have asked the country\u2019s involved to offer an explanation for their decision, following reports that Bulgaria is considering following suit.</p></li> \n <li><p><em><strong>Economy |</strong></em> The price of basic staple foods like<em><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/18/cost-of-british-food-basics-increases-by-up-to-80-in-a-year\"> </a></strong></em><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/18/cost-of-british-food-basics-increases-by-up-to-80-in-a-year\">cheddar cheese, white bread and pork sausages</a><em><strong> </strong></em>has increased by up to 80% in some shops over the past year, in further evidence that inflation could be hitting poorer households hardest.</p></li> \n</ol> \n<h2>In depth: How Sudan got here \u2013 and what happens now</h2> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"404d62fe36c812a040092c93b2ccfaa307a70aaa\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/404d62fe36c812a040092c93b2ccfaa307a70aaa/0_374_6486_3892/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Gen. Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, the deputy head of the military council speaks at a press conference in Khartoum\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Gen. Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, the deputy head of the military council speaks at a press conference in Khartoum</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: AP</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>Signs that trouble was brewing became clear last week, when the RSF led by Hemedti (above) started stationing forces around the northern town of Merowe \u2013 a strategic location with an airport and an electric dam on the Nile \u2013 and in other major cities, despite objections from the military\u2019s leadership.</p> \n<p>The moves from the paramilitary group culminated in a violent confrontation on Saturday that is still ongoing. Both sides have traded blame over who started the fighting. Residents in Khartoum were caught off guard, as heavy gunfire, airstrikes, and artillery explosions shook the city. So far 185 people have reportedly been killed, including three people working for the UN World Food Programme, and more than 1,800 have been left injured.</p> \n<p>The violence has not been limited to the capital, with reports of conflict in cities and towns across the country, including in the war-torn Darfur region and on the borders with Ethiopia and Eritrea \u2013 countries that are experiencing their own domestic turmoil.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"4d92144a-a982-401c-ba17-9158cc5756a3\" data-atom-type=\"media\"> \n  <div>\n   <iframe frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" src=\"https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/WVlQ91l9Ciw?showinfo=0&amp;rel=0\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>***</p> \n<p><strong>How did Sudan get here?</strong></p> \n<p>In December, after months of negotiation, Sudan\u2019s military and civilian leaders signed a preliminary deal to end the military rule that has governed the country since October 2021. The point of the agreement was to begin the process of moving towards civilian-led democratic rule. It was a significant moment, however a number of important and complicated issues were left unresolved, including the crisis in Eastern Sudan and questions around reforming the military and security sector.</p> \n<p>Over the last four months, these issues left the RSF and the military at an impasse. The mounting tension between the rival leaders made coming to a resolution in these negotiations near impossible and earlier this month they were paused. Central to this hostility was the question of how the RSF should become integrated into the military \u2013 the army had said it should happen in two years and the RSF shot back with a far longer timeline: ten years. Hemedti then accused al-Burhan of refusing to relinquish control, further straining their deteriorating alliance.</p> \n<p>***</p> \n<p><strong>Impact on civilians</strong></p> \n<p>The violence threatens to deepen the humanitarian crisis in a country that is already struggling economically. The 2021 coup meant that Sudan <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/markets/us/exclusive-sudan-cut-off-650-million-international-funding-after-coup-2021-12-08/\">was unable to access</a> billions of dollars in foreign aid and debt forgiveness. Rising food prices, devastating flooding and disease outbreaks have left citizens incredibly vulnerable. Now millions of people are stuck in their homes, reportedly without water or electricity in the final days of Ramadan, too scared to go outside to get food or supplies in case they get caught in the violence.</p> \n<p>Those who are caught in the crossfire have to rely on Sudan\u2019s already frail healthcare system as it struggles to cope with a fresh influx of injured patients. Hundreds of patients have been evacuated and the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/sudan-death-toll-nears-100-as-fighting-rages-and-hospitals-run-short-of-supplies\">World Health Organization</a> has said that some hospitals are already running out of critical supplies to treat wounded citizens.</p> \n<p>***</p> \n<p><strong>The global response</strong></p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"548611be114d8b03720333a7592566b09e3181ca\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/548611be114d8b03720333a7592566b09e3181ca/0_216_5184_3110/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Demonstrators burn tires as they protest against framework agreement signed between the military and civilians in 2021\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Demonstrators burn tires as they protest against framework agreement signed between the military and civilians in 2021</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Anadolu Agency/Getty Images</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>There has been widespread condemnation of the violence. The US secretary of state, Antony Blinken, said on social media that he was \u201cdeeply concerned\u201d and urged both sides to immediately stop what they were doing.</p> \n<p>However, it is not just altruism that is fueling this alarm \u2013 a number of countries have a vested interest in Sudan\u2019s future. Operatives of the Russian mercenary group Wagner advised the country\u2019s brutal dictator Omar al-Bashir before he was toppled and an investigation found that the group had been <a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/2022/07/29/africa/sudan-russia-gold-investigation-cmd-intl/index.html\">plundering gold in the region</a> to boost Putin\u2019s war effort in Ukraine. As a result Sudan has become strategically important to the United States \u2013 it does not hurt that it is a resource rich country too.</p> \n<p>Neighbouring countries have expressed their dismay at the situation, with the presidents of Kenya, South Sudan and Djibouti planning to travel to Sudan to help mediate the crisis. Across the rest of the continent, the responses have varied; Ethiopia\u2019s prime minister Abiy Ahmed said the clashes \u201ccontradict the longstanding and deep-rooted Sudanese norms and values\u201d while the ruling junta in Chad has closed the border with Sudan and called on \u201cthe belligerents to commence dialogue\u201d.</p> \n<p>***</p> \n<p><strong>What happens next?</strong></p> \n<p>An immediate ceasefire seems unlikely \u2013 the fighting is widespread and both leaders have dug in, demanding that the other surrender. Whether one side can come out victorious is also unclear as they each have their own advantages: al-Burhan\u2019s military has far more troops, but Hemedti\u2019s RSF is better trained and equipped. Neither side will buckle easily.</p> \n<p>At the centre of all of this violence is a power struggle between two military leaders. As the deadlock continues, and Sudan\u2019s democratic future hangs in the balance, the only certainty is even more hardship for the longsuffering citizens of Sudan.</p> \n<h2>What else we\u2019ve been reading</h2> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"6d38c44b1d930a6bc9185a790f5a881c15fdd760\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/6d38c44b1d930a6bc9185a790f5a881c15fdd760/0_58_1847_1108/1000.jpg\" alt=\"An illustration for Tom Clark\u2019s case for a poverty \u2018triple lock\u2019.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">An illustration for Tom Clark\u2019s case for a poverty \u2018triple lock\u2019.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Illustration: Elia Barbieri/The Guardian</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<ul> \n <li><p>If reading about pension reform makes your head hurt and your blood boil, then <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/apr/17/the-big-idea-why-we-need-a-triple-lock-against-poverty\">Tom Clark\u2019s pointed</a> but clear case for a \u201c<strong>triple lock against poverty</strong>\u201d in the UK, for the \u201cbig idea\u201d series, is worth a read. <em><strong>Craille</strong></em></p></li> \n <li><p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/apr/17/barry-this-hitman-comedy-is-one-of-the-most-overlooked-and-brilliant-shows-on-tv\">Stuart Heritage calls</a> on all of us to give the critically acclaimed series <strong>Barry</strong> a chance as it enters its fourth and final season: \u201cBarry is so singular, so restless, so terrified of complacency, that it deserves to go down as one of the very best.\u201d I\u2019ve just started it and I agree. <em><strong>Nimo</strong></em></p></li> \n <li><p>Remember the viral feta pasta recipe that made the rounds on TikTok back in 2021? Well, FoodTok has turned much more revolting, as <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/apr/18/the-disgusting-food-of-tiktok-is-it-designed-to-eat-provoke-or-arouse\">Emma Beddington explores</a> the trend towards <strong>repulsive recipes</strong> (ironed toasties, frankfurters in jelly). <em><strong>Craille Maguire Gillies, production editor</strong></em></p></li> \n <li><p>I loved <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/food/2023/apr/17/hannah-fry-interview-mum-wasnt-focused-on-cooking-boiled-sardines\">Rebecca Nicholson\u2019s interview with</a> <strong>Prof Hannah Fry</strong>, whose affability and warmth jumped off the page. \u201cThis sounds really grand, but this is genuinely true. I would like to leave the world better than I found it,\u201d Fry says. <em><strong>Nimo</strong></em></p></li> \n <li><p>I\u2019m a bit late to Sam Fragoso\u2019s six-year-old podcast Talk Easy, produced by Malcom Gladwell, in which he often has intimate conversations with artists, actors, writers and the occasional political type. Sudan has found itself in the midst of another crisis, as fighting erupted in the capital, Khartoum, over the weekend between rival military groups after months of growing disquiet over the future of the country and its democracy. It has only been four years since the country\u2019s dictator, President Omar al-Bashir, was ousted after three decades of vicious rule and euphoria filled the streets as people demanded democratic rule. Things have not quite gone to plan \u2013 two of the country\u2019s most powerful generals, General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, and Lieutenant General Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo (more commonly known as Hemedti or \u201clittle Mohammed\u201d), came together in 2021 to take power in a military coup. It was an alliance that has proved short lived as al-Burhan, the head of the army, and Hemedti, the leader of the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces (RSF), have now turned on each other, with the people of Sudan stuck in the middle. In today\u2019s newsletter, I take a look at the events that have led up to this moment and what it might mean for people living in Sudan. Five big stories Health | MPs in the women and equalities committee have accused ministers of failing to tackle \u201cappalling\u201d and \u201cglaring\u201d racial disparities in maternal health despite repeated promises. They have called for new targets to eliminate inequalities. UK news | A serving police sergeant in Plymouth faces three rape charges for allegedly raping a woman while he was on duty more than a decade ago. The alleged offences took place in 2009 and were reported to the police in 2020. France | Air France and Airbus have been cleared of involuntary manslaughter over a 2009 crash that killed 228 people. The court ruled \u201cno certain causal link\u201d with the accident could be shown. Ukraine | Slovakia has joined Poland and Hungary in their decision to stop imports of grain and other food products from Ukraine to protect local farmers. The European Commission and Kyiv have criticised these bans and have asked the country\u2019s involved to offer an explanation for their decision, following reports that Bulgaria is considering following suit. Economy | The price of basic staple foods like cheddar cheese, white bread and pork sausages has increased by up to 80% in some shops over the past year, in further evidence that inflation could be hitting poorer households hardest. In depth: How Sudan got here \u2013 and what happens now Signs that trouble was brewing became clear last week, when the RSF led by Hemedti (above) started stationing forces around the northern town of Merowe \u2013 a strategic location with an airport and an electric dam on the Nile \u2013 and in other major cities, despite objections from the military\u2019s leadership. The moves from the paramilitary group culminated in a violent confrontation on Saturday that is still ongoing. Both sides have traded blame over who started the fighting. Residents in Khartoum were caught off guard, as heavy gunfire, airstrikes, and artillery explosions shook the city. So far 185 people have reportedly been killed, including three people working for the UN World Food Programme, and more than 1,800 have been left injured. The violence has not been limited to the capital, with reports of conflict in cities and towns across the country, including in the war-torn Darfur region and on the borders with Ethiopia and Eritrea \u2013 countries that are experiencing their own domestic turmoil. *** How did Sudan get here? In December, after months of negotiation, Sudan\u2019s military and civilian leaders signed a preliminary deal to end the military rule that has governed the country since October 2021. The point of the agreement was to begin the process of moving towards civilian-led democratic rule. It was a significant moment, however a number of important and complicated issues were left unresolved, including the crisis in Eastern Sudan and questions around reforming the military and security sector. Over the last four months, these issues left the RSF and the military at an impasse. The mounting tension between the rival leaders made coming to a resolution in these negotiations near impossible and earlier this month they were paused. Central to this hostility was the question of how the RSF should become integrated into the military \u2013 the army had said it should happen in two years and the RSF shot back with a far longer timeline: ten years. Hemedti then accused al-Burhan of refusing to relinquish control, further straining their deteriorating alliance. *** Impact on civilians The violence threatens to deepen the humanitarian crisis in a country that is already struggling economically. The 2021 coup meant that Sudan was unable to access billions of dollars in foreign aid and debt forgiveness. Rising food prices, devastating flooding and disease outbreaks have left citizens incredibly vulnerable. Now millions of people are stuck in their homes, reportedly without water or electricity in the final days of Ramadan, too scared to go outside to get food or supplies in case they get caught in the violence. Those who are caught in the crossfire have to rely on Sudan\u2019s already frail healthcare system as it struggles to cope with a fresh influx of injured patients. Hundreds of patients have been evacuated and the World Health Organization has said that some hospitals are already running out of critical supplies to treat wounded citizens. *** The global response There has been widespread condemnation of the violence. The US secretary of state, Antony Blinken, said on social media that he was \u201cdeeply concerned\u201d and urged both sides to immediately stop what they were doing. However, it is not just altruism that is fueling this alarm \u2013 a number of countries have a vested interest in Sudan\u2019s future. Operatives of the Russian mercenary group Wagner advised the country\u2019s brutal dictator Omar al-Bashir before he was toppled and an investigation found that the group had been plundering gold in the region to boost Putin\u2019s war effort in Ukraine. As a result Sudan has become strategically important to the United States \u2013 it does not hurt that it is a resource rich country too. Neighbouring countries have expressed their dismay at the situation, with the presidents of Kenya, South Sudan and Djibouti planning to travel to Sudan to help mediate the crisis. Across the rest of the continent, the responses have varied; Ethiopia\u2019s prime minister Abiy Ahmed said the clashes \u201ccontradict the longstanding and deep-rooted Sudanese norms and values\u201d while the ruling junta in Chad has closed the border with Sudan and called on \u201cthe belligerents to commence dialogue\u201d. *** What happens next? An immediate ceasefire seems unlikely \u2013 the fighting is widespread and both leaders have dug in, demanding that the other surrender. Whether one side can come out victorious is also unclear as they each have their own advantages: al-Burhan\u2019s military has far more troops, but Hemedti\u2019s RSF is better trained and equipped. Neither side will buckle easily. At the centre of all of this violence is a power struggle between two military leaders. As the deadlock continues, and Sudan\u2019s democratic future hangs in the balance, the only certainty is even more hardship for the longsuffering citizens of Sudan. What else we\u2019ve been reading If reading about pension reform makes your head hurt and your blood boil, then Tom Clark\u2019s pointed but clear case for a \u201ctriple lock against poverty\u201d in the UK, for the \u201cbig idea\u201d series, is worth a read. Craille Stuart Heritage calls on all of us to give the critically acclaimed series Barry a chance as it enters its fourth and final season: \u201cBarry is so singular, so restless, so terrified of complacency, that it deserves to go down as one of the very best.\u201d I\u2019ve just started it and I agree. Craille Maguire Gillies, production editor I loved Rebecca Nicholson\u2019s interview with Prof Hannah Fry, whose affability and warmth jumped off the page. \u201cThis sounds really grand, but this is genuinely true. I would like to leave the world better than I found it,\u201d Fry says. "bodyHtml": "<p>Good morning.</p> <p>Sudan has found itself in the midst of another crisis, as fighting erupted in the capital, Khartoum, over the weekend between rival military groups after months of growing disquiet over the future of the country and its democracy.</p> <p>It has only been four years since the country\u2019s dictator, President Omar al-Bashir, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/apr/11/omar-al-bashir-sudan-ousted-regime-president\">was ousted after three decades of vicious rule</a> and euphoria filled the streets as people demanded democratic rule. Things have not quite gone to plan \u2013 two of the country\u2019s most powerful generals, General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/mohamed-hamdan-dagalo-the-feared-ex-warlord-taking-on-sudan-army-hemedti\">Lieutenant General Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo</a> (more commonly known as Hemedti or \u201clittle Mohammed\u201d), came together in 2021 to take power in a military coup. It was an alliance that has proved short lived as al-Burhan, the head of the army, and Hemedti, the leader of the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces (RSF), have now turned on each other, with the people of Sudan stuck in the middle.</p> <p>In today\u2019s newsletter, I take a look at the events that have led up to this moment and what it might mean for people living in Sudan.</p> <h2>Five big stories</h2> <ol> <li><p><em><strong>Health |</strong></em> MPs in the women and equalities committee have <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/apr/18/mps-condemn-failure-to-tackle-glaring-racial-inequalities-in-uk-maternal-health\">accused ministers of failing to tackle</a> \u201cappalling\u201d and \u201cglaring\u201d racial disparities in maternal health despite repeated promises. They have called for new targets to eliminate inequalities.</p></li> <li><p><em><strong>UK news</strong></em> <em><strong>|</strong></em> A serving police sergeant in Plymouth <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/17/police-officer-david-stansbury-charged-with-raping-woman-while-on-duty-plymouth\">faces three rape charges</a> for allegedly raping a woman while he was on duty more than a decade ago. The alleged offences took place in 2009 and were reported to the police in 2020.</p></li> <li><p><em><strong>France</strong></em> <em><strong>|</strong></em> Air France and Airbus <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/air-france-and-airbus-cleared-of-involuntary-manslaughter-over-2009-crash\">have been cleared of involuntary manslaughter</a> over a 2009 crash that killed 228 people. The court ruled \u201cno certain causal link\u201d with the accident could be shown.</p></li> <li><p><em><strong>Ukraine</strong></em> <em><strong>|</strong></em> Slovakia has joined Poland and Hungary in their decision<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/slovakia-joins-poland-hungary-halting-ukraine-grain-imports\"> to stop imports of grain and other food products from Ukraine</a> to protect local farmers. The European Commission and Kyiv have criticised these bans and have asked the country\u2019s involved to offer an explanation for their decision, following reports that Bulgaria is considering following suit.</p></li> <li><p><em><strong>Economy |</strong></em> The price of basic staple foods like<em><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/18/cost-of-british-food-basics-increases-by-up-to-80-in-a-year\"> </a></strong></em><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/18/cost-of-british-food-basics-increases-by-up-to-80-in-a-year\">cheddar cheese, white bread and pork sausages</a><em><strong> </strong></em>has increased by up to 80% in some shops over the past year, in further evidence that inflation could be hitting poorer households hardest.</p></li> </ol> <h2>In depth: How Sudan got here \u2013 and what happens now</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"404d62fe36c812a040092c93b2ccfaa307a70aaa\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/404d62fe36c812a040092c93b2ccfaa307a70aaa/0_374_6486_3892/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Gen. Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, the deputy head of the military council speaks at a press conference in Khartoum\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Gen. Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, the deputy head of the military council speaks at a press conference in Khartoum</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: AP</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Signs that trouble was brewing became clear last week, when the RSF led by Hemedti (above) started stationing forces around the northern town of Merowe \u2013 a strategic location with an airport and an electric dam on the Nile \u2013 and in other major cities, despite objections from the military\u2019s leadership.</p> <p>The moves from the paramilitary group culminated in a violent confrontation on Saturday that is still ongoing. Both sides have traded blame over who started the fighting. Residents in Khartoum were caught off guard, as heavy gunfire, airstrikes, and artillery explosions shook the city. So far 185 people have reportedly been killed, including three people working for the UN World Food Programme, and more than 1,800 have been left injured.</p> <p>The violence has not been limited to the capital, with reports of conflict in cities and towns across the country, including in the war-torn Darfur region and on the borders with Ethiopia and Eritrea \u2013 countries that are experiencing their own domestic turmoil.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"4d92144a-a982-401c-ba17-9158cc5756a3\"         data-atom-type=\"media\"    > </gu-atom> </figure>   <p>***</p> <p><strong>How did Sudan get here?</strong></p> <p>In December, after months of negotiation, Sudan\u2019s military and civilian leaders signed a preliminary deal to end the military rule that has governed the country since October 2021. The point of the agreement was to begin the process of moving towards civilian-led democratic rule. It was a significant moment, however a number of important and complicated issues were left unresolved, including the crisis in Eastern Sudan and questions around reforming the military and security sector.</p> <p>Over the last four months, these issues left the RSF and the military at an impasse. The mounting tension between the rival leaders made coming to a resolution in these negotiations near impossible and earlier this month they were paused. Central to this hostility was the question of how the RSF should become integrated into the military \u2013 the army had said it should happen in two years and the RSF shot back with a far longer timeline: ten years. Hemedti then accused al-Burhan of refusing to relinquish control, further straining their deteriorating alliance.</p> <p>***</p> <p><strong>Impact on civilians</strong></p> <p>The violence threatens to deepen the humanitarian crisis in a country that is already struggling economically. The 2021 coup meant that Sudan <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/markets/us/exclusive-sudan-cut-off-650-million-international-funding-after-coup-2021-12-08/\">was unable to access</a> billions of dollars in foreign aid and debt forgiveness. Rising food prices, devastating flooding and disease outbreaks have left citizens incredibly vulnerable. Now millions of people are stuck in their homes, reportedly without water or electricity in the final days of Ramadan, too scared to go outside to get food or supplies in case they get caught in the violence.</p> <p>Those who are caught in the crossfire have to rely on Sudan\u2019s already frail healthcare system as it struggles to cope with a fresh influx of injured patients. Hundreds of patients have been evacuated and the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/17/sudan-death-toll-nears-100-as-fighting-rages-and-hospitals-run-short-of-supplies\">World Health Organization</a> has said that some hospitals are already running out of critical supplies to treat wounded citizens.</p> <p>***</p> <p><strong>The global response</strong></p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"548611be114d8b03720333a7592566b09e3181ca\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/548611be114d8b03720333a7592566b09e3181ca/0_216_5184_3110/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Demonstrators burn tires as they protest against framework agreement signed between the military and civilians in 2021\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Demonstrators burn tires as they protest against framework agreement signed between the military and civilians in 2021</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Anadolu Agency/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>There has been widespread condemnation of the violence. The US secretary of state, Antony Blinken, said on social media that he was \u201cdeeply concerned\u201d and urged both sides to immediately stop what they were doing.</p> <p>However, it is not just altruism that is fueling this alarm \u2013 a number of countries have a vested interest in Sudan\u2019s future. Operatives of the Russian mercenary group Wagner advised the country\u2019s brutal dictator Omar al-Bashir before he was toppled and an investigation found that the group had been <a href=\"https://edition.cnn.com/2022/07/29/africa/sudan-russia-gold-investigation-cmd-intl/index.html\">plundering gold in the region</a> to boost Putin\u2019s war effort in Ukraine. As a result Sudan has become strategically important to the United States \u2013 it does not hurt that it is a resource rich country too.</p> <p>Neighbouring countries have expressed their dismay at the situation, with the presidents of Kenya, South Sudan and Djibouti planning to travel to Sudan to help mediate the crisis. Across the rest of the continent, the responses have varied; Ethiopia\u2019s prime minister Abiy Ahmed said the clashes \u201ccontradict the longstanding and deep-rooted Sudanese norms and values\u201d while the ruling junta in Chad has closed the border with Sudan and called on \u201cthe belligerents to commence dialogue\u201d.</p> <p>***</p> <p><strong>What happens next?</strong></p> <p>An immediate ceasefire seems unlikely \u2013 the fighting is widespread and both leaders have dug in, demanding that the other surrender. Whether one side can come out victorious is also unclear as they each have their own advantages: al-Burhan\u2019s military has far more troops, but Hemedti\u2019s RSF is better trained and equipped. Neither side will buckle easily.</p> <p>At the centre of all of this violence is a power struggle between two military leaders. As the deadlock continues, and Sudan\u2019s democratic future hangs in the balance, the only certainty is even more hardship for the longsuffering citizens of Sudan.</p> <h2>What else we\u2019ve been reading</h2>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"6d38c44b1d930a6bc9185a790f5a881c15fdd760\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/6d38c44b1d930a6bc9185a790f5a881c15fdd760/0_58_1847_1108/1000.jpg\" alt=\"An illustration for Tom Clark\u2019s case for a poverty \u2018triple lock\u2019.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">An illustration for Tom Clark\u2019s case for a poverty \u2018triple lock\u2019.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Illustration: Elia Barbieri/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <ul> <li><p>If reading about pension reform makes your head hurt and your blood boil, then <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/apr/17/the-big-idea-why-we-need-a-triple-lock-against-poverty\">Tom Clark\u2019s pointed</a> but clear case for a \u201c<strong>triple lock against poverty</strong>\u201d in the UK, for the \u201cbig idea\u201d series, is worth a read. <em><strong>Craille</strong></em></p></li> <li><p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2023/apr/17/barry-this-hitman-comedy-is-one-of-the-most-overlooked-and-brilliant-shows-on-tv\">Stuart Heritage calls</a> on all of us to give the critically acclaimed series <strong>Barry</strong> a chance as it enters its fourth and final season: \u201cBarry is so singular, so restless, so terrified of complacency, that it deserves to go down as one of the very best.\u201d I\u2019ve just started it and I agree. <em><strong>Nimo</strong></em></p></li> <li><p>Remember the viral feta pasta recipe that made the rounds on TikTok back in 2021? Sudan has found itself in the midst of another crisis, as fighting erupted in the capital, Khartoum, over the weekend between rival military groups after months of growing disquiet over the future of the country and its democracy. It has only been four years since the country\u2019s dictator, President Omar al-Bashir, was ousted after three decades of vicious rule and euphoria filled the streets as people demanded democratic rule. Things have not quite gone to plan \u2013 two of the country\u2019s most powerful generals, General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, and Lieutenant General Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo (more commonly known as Hemedti or \u201clittle Mohammed\u201d), came together in 2021 to take power in a military coup. It was an alliance that has proved short lived as al-Burhan, the head of the army, and Hemedti, the leader of the paramilitary group Rapid Support Forces (RSF), have now turned on each other, with the people of Sudan stuck in the middle. In today\u2019s newsletter, I take a look at the events that have led up to this moment and what it might mean for people living in Sudan. Five big stories Health | MPs in the women and equalities committee have accused ministers of failing to tackle \u201cappalling\u201d and \u201cglaring\u201d racial disparities in maternal health despite repeated promises. They have called for new targets to eliminate inequalities. UK news | A serving police sergeant in Plymouth faces three rape charges for allegedly raping a woman while he was on duty more than a decade ago. The alleged offences took place in 2009 and were reported to the police in 2020. France | Air France and Airbus have been cleared of involuntary manslaughter over a 2009 crash that killed 228 people. The court ruled \u201cno certain causal link\u201d with the accident could be shown. Ukraine | Slovakia has joined Poland and Hungary in their decision to stop imports of grain and other food products from Ukraine to protect local farmers. The European Commission and Kyiv have criticised these bans and have asked the country\u2019s involved to offer an explanation for their decision, following reports that Bulgaria is considering following suit. Economy | The price of basic staple foods like cheddar cheese, white bread and pork sausages has increased by up to 80% in some shops over the past year, in further evidence that inflation could be hitting poorer households hardest. In depth: How Sudan got here \u2013 and what happens now\nSigns that trouble was brewing became clear last week, when the RSF led by Hemedti (above) started stationing forces around the northern town of Merowe \u2013 a strategic location with an airport and an electric dam on the Nile \u2013 and in other major cities, despite objections from the military\u2019s leadership. The moves from the paramilitary group culminated in a violent confrontation on Saturday that is still ongoing. Both sides have traded blame over who started the fighting. Residents in Khartoum were caught off guard, as heavy gunfire, airstrikes, and artillery explosions shook the city. So far 185 people have reportedly been killed, including three people working for the UN World Food Programme, and more than 1,800 have been left injured. The violence has not been limited to the capital, with reports of conflict in cities and towns across the country, including in the war-torn Darfur region and on the borders with Ethiopia and Eritrea \u2013 countries that are experiencing their own domestic turmoil.\n*** How did Sudan get here? In December, after months of negotiation, Sudan\u2019s military and civilian leaders signed a preliminary deal to end the military rule that has governed the country since October 2021. The point of the agreement was to begin the process of moving towards civilian-led democratic rule. It was a significant moment, however a number of important and complicated issues were left unresolved, including the crisis in Eastern Sudan and questions around reforming the military and security sector. Over the last four months, these issues left the RSF and the military at an impasse. The mounting tension between the rival leaders made coming to a resolution in these negotiations near impossible and earlier this month they were paused. Central to this hostility was the question of how the RSF should become integrated into the military \u2013 the army had said it should happen in two years and the RSF shot back with a far longer timeline: ten years. Hemedti then accused al-Burhan of refusing to relinquish control, further straining their deteriorating alliance. *** Impact on civilians The violence threatens to deepen the humanitarian crisis in a country that is already struggling economically. The 2021 coup meant that Sudan was unable to access billions of dollars in foreign aid and debt forgiveness. Rising food prices, devastating flooding and disease outbreaks have left citizens incredibly vulnerable. Now millions of people are stuck in their homes, reportedly without water or electricity in the final days of Ramadan, too scared to go outside to get food or supplies in case they get caught in the violence. Those who are caught in the crossfire have to rely on Sudan\u2019s already frail healthcare system as it struggles to cope with a fresh influx of injured patients. Hundreds of patients have been evacuated and the World Health Organization has said that some hospitals are already running out of critical supplies to treat wounded citizens. *** The global response\nThere has been widespread condemnation of the violence. The US secretary of state, Antony Blinken, said on social media that he was \u201cdeeply concerned\u201d and urged both sides to immediately stop what they were doing. However, it is not just altruism that is fueling this alarm \u2013 a number of countries have a vested interest in Sudan\u2019s future. Operatives of the Russian mercenary group Wagner advised the country\u2019s brutal dictator Omar al-Bashir before he was toppled and an investigation found that the group had been plundering gold in the region to boost Putin\u2019s war effort in Ukraine. As a result Sudan has become strategically important to the United States \u2013 it does not hurt that it is a resource rich country too. Neighbouring countries have expressed their dismay at the situation, with the presidents of Kenya, South Sudan and Djibouti planning to travel to Sudan to help mediate the crisis. Across the rest of the continent, the responses have varied; Ethiopia\u2019s prime minister Abiy Ahmed said the clashes \u201ccontradict the longstanding and deep-rooted Sudanese norms and values\u201d while the ruling junta in Chad has closed the border with Sudan and called on \u201cthe belligerents to commence dialogue\u201d. *** What happens next? An immediate ceasefire seems unlikely \u2013 the fighting is widespread and both leaders have dug in, demanding that the other surrender. Whether one side can come out victorious is also unclear as they each have their own advantages: al-Burhan\u2019s military has far more troops, but Hemedti\u2019s RSF is better trained and equipped. Neither side will buckle easily. At the centre of all of this violence is a power struggle between two military leaders. As the deadlock continues, and Sudan\u2019s democratic future hangs in the balance, the only certainty is even more hardship for the longsuffering citizens of Sudan. Craille Stuart Heritage calls on all of us to give the critically acclaimed series Barry a chance as it enters its fourth and final season: \u201cBarry is so singular, so restless, so terrified of complacency, that it deserves to go down as one of the very best.\u201d I\u2019ve just started it and I agree. "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/world", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/world", "editions": [{"id": "world", "webTitle": "World news", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/world", "politics/2023/apr/18/mps-condemn-failure-to-tackle-glaring-racial-inequalities-in-uk-maternal-health", "type": "article", "sectionId": "politics", "sectionName": "Politics", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:35:41Z", "webTitle": "MPs condemn failure to tackle \u2018glaring\u2019 racial inequalities in UK maternal health", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/apr/18/mps-condemn-failure-to-tackle-glaring-racial-inequalities-in-uk-maternal-health", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/politics/2023/apr/18/mps-condemn-failure-to-tackle-glaring-racial-inequalities-in-uk-maternal-health", "fields": {"headline": "MPs condemn failure to tackle \u2018glaring\u2019 racial inequalities in UK maternal health", "standfirst": "<p>Committee says too many black women receive treatment that falls short of acceptable standards</p>", "trailText": "Committee says too many black women receive treatment that falls short of acceptable standards", "byline": "Andrew Gregory and Mabel Banfield-Nwachi", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"2f8f462c7b4d32a134d4c5bf089a120055de260e\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/2f8f462c7b4d32a134d4c5bf089a120055de260e/168_292_5000_3002/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Pregnant woman having ultrasound\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Black women are almost four times more likely to die from childbirth than white women, the MPs\u2019 report says.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: MBI/Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Ministers have failed to tackle \u201cappalling\u201d and \u201cglaring\u201d racial disparities in maternal health despite repeated promises, MPs have said, as they called for new targets to eliminate inequalities.</p> <p>In a scathing report, the women and equalities committee said maternal death rates in deprived areas were on the rise, with women in the poorest areas about two and half times more likely to die in childbirth than those in the richest areas.</p> <p>Black women are still almost four times more likely to die from childbirth than white women, the report says, and too many black women receive treatment that \u201cfalls short of acceptable standards\u201d. The government and NHS leaders have \u201cunderestimated the extent to which racism plays a role\u201d, it adds.</p> <p>It comes after Kemi Badenoch, the equalities minister, admitted on Monday that less than half the measures set out in the government\u2019s plan to tackle racial inequality and level up communities had been delivered.</p> <p>In February last year, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/feb/13/radical-action-needed-to-tackle-racial-health-inequality-in-nhs-says-damning-report\">the Guardian exposed </a>how radical action was needed to tackle \u201coverwhelming\u201d racial health inequalities, after a leaked report concluded that \u201cvast\u201d and \u201cwidespread\u201d inequity in all aspects of healthcare was harming the health of millions of patients.</p> <p>Racism, racial discrimination, barriers to accessing healthcare and woeful collection of ethnicity data had \u201cnegatively impacted\u201d the health of black, Asian and minority ethnic people for years, according to the review, commissioned by the NHS Race and Health Observatory. But more than a year on, MPs say there has been \u201cmuch talk and little action\u201d.</p> <p>A government taskforce set up to tackle disparities in maternity care \u2013 announced nine days after the Guardian\u2019s report \u2013 has met just three times, the committee found. The last time it met was nine months ago, in July 2022. Other government measures have proved \u201cinsufficient\u201d, the report says.</p> <p>The inaction was \u201cfrankly shameful\u201d, said the committee\u2019s chair, Caroline Nokes. \u201cNHS births are among the safest in the world and yet we continue to see appalling disparities in maternal deaths,\u201d she said. \u201cIt is shocking that black women are almost four times more likely to die from childbirth than white women.\u201d</p> <p>Health leaders and campaigners said they were saddened but not surprised by the MPs\u2019 findings. \u201cWe are tired of this issue being a talking point \u2013 we\u2019re ready for tangible action,\u201d said Dr Habib Naqvi, the chief executive of the NHS Race and Health Observatory, an independent expert group.</p> <p>\u201cThe stark outcomes that black women face as a result of racial discrimination in maternity care has to be urgently prioritised and tackled. Evidence clearly shows that black and other minority ethnic women are often paying with their lives for the lack of action on racial bias in healthcare,\u201d Naqvi said.</p> <p>\u201cIt is not acceptable that, today in 2023, these women are subject to higher risk of dying during pregnancy or childbirth, nor should they be experiencing higher rates of stillbirth or neonatal deaths in comparison to their white counterparts.\u201d</p> <p>Janaki Mahadevan and Shanthi Gunesekera, the joint chief executives of the charity Birthrights, called the committee\u2019s report \u201cdeeply concerning\u201d.</p> <p>They said: \u201cHow many more reports or statistics do we need to see about the racism that exists in the structures, cultures and practices that govern maternity care in the UK before serious and meaningful action is taken?\u201d</p> <p>The voices of black and ethnic minority mothers were still too often ignored or dismissed, they added. \u201cLayer on to this racial microaggressions and stereotyping, failure to recognise serious medical conditions due to skin colour, and a lack of respect for culture and religion, and the inequalities in outcomes are unsurprising.\u201d</p> <p>The committee said a target was needed to eliminate the disparity between black and other minority ethnic women and white women, and the related gap between those living in the most and least deprived areas.</p> <p>Among their recommendations, MPs called for Health Education England to lead a coordinated review involving the Royal College of Midwives and others \u201cto ensure that both the training curricula and continuing professional development requirements for all maternity staff include evidence-based learning on maternal health disparities, its possible causes and how to deliver culturally competent, personalised and evidence-led care.\u201d</p> <p>The committee also called for \u201ccontinuity of carer\u201d for patients \u2013 something it said was currently difficult \u201cdue to the considerable staffing shortages across maternity services\u201d.</p> <p>MPs said a fully staffed, properly funded maternity workforce was \u201cfundamental to delivering safe, personalised care to pregnant women and new mothers\u201d and they called on ministers to commit to an annual uplift of up to \u00a3350m for maternity units.</p> <p>Better data was also needed, they said, warning that black women were \u201cregularly under-represented in research or data and therefore in policymaking\u201d and that ethnicity data held by trusts was \u201cincomplete or inaccurate\u201d.</p> <p>Nokes said: \u201cWe cannot let these women remain invisible to the systems supposed to serve them. We are also afraid the government and NHS have not fully grasped that racism has played a key part in the complex reasons underlying the disparities, and that eradicating it is part of the solution.\u201d</p> <p>Laura Seebohm, the chief executive of the Maternal Mental Health Alliance, said: \u201cEnduring inequalities in maternity care continue to be deeply shocking. All women, babies and families have a right to high-quality, compassionate care during and after pregnancy. The human and economic consequences of failing to provide this are significant, making it vital that such disparities in maternal experiences and outcomes are addressed.\u201d</p> <p>The NHS said it was \u201ccommitted to ensuring all women receive high-quality care\u201d and had provided \u00a36.8m to help local health systems reduce health inequalities.</p> <p>A spokesperson acknowledged there was \u201cmore to be done\u201d and said the service would review the committee\u2019s recommendations.</p> <p> A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: \u201cWhile the NHS is already one of the safest places to give birth in the world, we are absolutely clear that we must ensure maternity care is of the same high standard, regardless of race.</p> <p>\u201cWe\u2019ve invested \u00a3165m since 2021 to grow the maternity workforce and are promoting careers in midwifery with an extra 3,650 training places per year, while every local NHS maternity system has a plan in place to "https://media.guim.co.uk/2f8f462c7b4d32a134d4c5bf089a120055de260e/168_292_5000_3002/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Ministers have failed to tackle \u201cappalling\u201d and \u201cglaring\u201d racial disparities in maternal health despite repeated promises, MPs have said, as they called for new targets to eliminate inequalities. In a scathing report, the women and equalities committee said maternal death rates in deprived areas were on the rise, with women in the poorest areas about two and half times more likely to die in childbirth than those in the richest areas. Black women are still almost four times more likely to die from childbirth than white women, the report says, and too many black women receive treatment that \u201cfalls short of acceptable standards\u201d. The government and NHS leaders have \u201cunderestimated the extent to which racism plays a role\u201d, it adds. It comes after Kemi Badenoch, the equalities minister, admitted on Monday that less than half the measures set out in the government\u2019s plan to tackle racial inequality and level up communities had been delivered. In February last year, the Guardian exposed how radical action was needed to tackle \u201coverwhelming\u201d racial health inequalities, after a leaked report concluded that \u201cvast\u201d and \u201cwidespread\u201d inequity in all aspects of healthcare was harming the health of millions of patients. Racism, racial discrimination, barriers to accessing healthcare and woeful collection of ethnicity data had \u201cnegatively impacted\u201d the health of black, Asian and minority ethnic people for years, according to the review, commissioned by the NHS Race and Health Observatory. But more than a year on, MPs say there has been \u201cmuch talk and little action\u201d. A government taskforce set up to tackle disparities in maternity care \u2013 announced nine days after the Guardian\u2019s report \u2013 has met just three times, the committee found. The last time it met was nine months ago, in July 2022. Other government measures have proved \u201cinsufficient\u201d, the report says. The inaction was \u201cfrankly shameful\u201d, said the committee\u2019s chair, Caroline Nokes. \u201cNHS births are among the safest in the world and yet we continue to see appalling disparities in maternal deaths,\u201d she said. \u201cIt is shocking that black women are almost four times more likely to die from childbirth than white women.\u201d Health leaders and campaigners said they were saddened but not surprised by the MPs\u2019 findings. \u201cWe are tired of this issue being a talking point \u2013 we\u2019re ready for tangible action,\u201d said Dr Habib Naqvi, the chief executive of the NHS Race and Health Observatory, an independent expert group. \u201cThe stark outcomes that black women face as a result of racial discrimination in maternity care has to be urgently prioritised and tackled. Evidence clearly shows that black and other minority ethnic women are often paying with their lives for the lack of action on racial bias in healthcare,\u201d Naqvi said. \u201cIt is not acceptable that, today in 2023, these women are subject to higher risk of dying during pregnancy or childbirth, nor should they be experiencing higher rates of stillbirth or neonatal deaths in comparison to their white counterparts.\u201d Janaki Mahadevan and Shanthi Gunesekera, the joint chief executives of the charity Birthrights, called the committee\u2019s report \u201cdeeply concerning\u201d. They said: \u201cHow many more reports or statistics do we need to see about the racism that exists in the structures, cultures and practices that govern maternity care in the UK before serious and meaningful action is taken?\u201d The voices of black and ethnic minority mothers were still too often ignored or dismissed, they added. \u201cLayer on to this racial microaggressions and stereotyping, failure to recognise serious medical conditions due to skin colour, and a lack of respect for culture and religion, and the inequalities in outcomes are unsurprising.\u201d The committee said a target was needed to eliminate the disparity between black and other minority ethnic women and white women, and the related gap between those living in the most and least deprived areas. Among their recommendations, MPs called for Health Education England to lead a coordinated review involving the Royal College of Midwives and others \u201cto ensure that both the training curricula and continuing professional development requirements for all maternity staff include evidence-based learning on maternal health disparities, its possible causes and how to deliver culturally competent, personalised and evidence-led care.\u201d The committee also called for \u201ccontinuity of carer\u201d for patients \u2013 something it said was currently difficult \u201cdue to the considerable staffing shortages across maternity services\u201d. MPs said a fully staffed, properly funded maternity workforce was \u201cfundamental to delivering safe, personalised care to pregnant women and new mothers\u201d and they called on ministers to commit to an annual uplift of up to \u00a3350m for maternity units. Better data was also needed, they said, warning that black women were \u201cregularly under-represented in research or data and therefore in policymaking\u201d and that ethnicity data held by trusts was \u201cincomplete or inaccurate\u201d. Nokes said: \u201cWe cannot let these women remain invisible to the systems supposed to serve them. We are also afraid the government and NHS have not fully grasped that racism has played a key part in the complex reasons underlying the disparities, and that eradicating it is part of the solution.\u201d Laura Seebohm, the chief executive of the Maternal Mental Health Alliance, said: \u201cEnduring inequalities in maternity care continue to be deeply shocking. All women, babies and families have a right to high-quality, compassionate care during and after pregnancy. The human and economic consequences of failing to provide this are significant, making it vital that such disparities in maternal experiences and outcomes are addressed.\u201d The NHS said it was \u201ccommitted to ensuring all women receive high-quality care\u201d and had provided \u00a36.8m to help local health systems reduce health inequalities. A spokesperson acknowledged there was \u201cmore to be done\u201d and said the service would review the committee\u2019s recommendations. A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: \u201cWhile the NHS is already one of the safest places to give birth in the world, we are absolutely clear that we must ensure maternity care is of the same high standard, regardless of race. \u201cWe\u2019ve invested \u00a3165m since 2021 to grow the maternity workforce and are promoting careers in midwifery with an extra 3,650 training places per year, while every local NHS maternity system has a plan in place to tackle disparities on a local level. \u201cThe maternity disparities taskforce \u2013 a collective of mothers, clinicians and key organisations \u2013 is being chaired today by minister Maria Caulfield to focus on how we can eradicate disparities and improve maternity outcomes for all mothers.\u201d On Monday, Badenoch admitted that only 32 of the 74 measures in the Inclusive Britain strategy published just over a year ago had been completed.
