A government taskforce set up to tackle disparities in maternity care \u2013 announced nine days after the Guardian\u2019s report \u2013 has met just three times, the committee found. The last time it met was nine months ago, in July 2022. Other government measures have proved \u201cinsufficient\u201d, the report says. The inaction was \u201cfrankly shameful\u201d, said the committee\u2019s chair, Caroline Nokes. \u201cNHS births are among the safest in the world and yet we continue to see appalling disparities in maternal deaths,\u201d she said. \u201cIt is shocking that black women are almost four times more likely to die from childbirth than white women.\u201d Health leaders and campaigners said they were saddened but not surprised by the MPs\u2019 findings. \u201cWe are tired of this issue being a talking point \u2013 we\u2019re ready for tangible action,\u201d said Dr Habib Naqvi, the chief executive of the NHS Race and Health Observatory, an independent expert group. \u201cThe stark outcomes that black women face as a result of racial discrimination in maternity care has to be urgently prioritised and tackled. Evidence clearly shows that black and other minority ethnic women are often paying with their lives for the lack of action on racial bias in healthcare,\u201d Naqvi said. \u201cIt is not acceptable that, today in 2023, these women are subject to higher risk of dying during pregnancy or childbirth, nor should they be experiencing higher rates of stillbirth or neonatal deaths in comparison to their white counterparts.\u201d Janaki Mahadevan and Shanthi Gunesekera, the joint chief executives of the charity Birthrights, called the committee\u2019s report \u201cdeeply concerning\u201d. They said: \u201cHow many more reports or statistics do we need to see about the racism that exists in the structures, cultures and practices that govern maternity care in the UK before serious and meaningful action is taken?\u201d The voices of black and ethnic minority mothers were still too often ignored or dismissed, they added. \u201cLayer on to this racial microaggressions and stereotyping, failure to recognise serious medical conditions due to skin colour, and a lack of respect for culture and religion, and the inequalities in outcomes are unsurprising.\u201d The committee said a target was needed to eliminate the disparity between black and other minority ethnic women and white women, and the related gap between those living in the most and least deprived areas. Among their recommendations, MPs called for Health Education England to lead a coordinated review involving the Royal College of Midwives and others \u201cto ensure that both the training curricula and continuing professional development requirements for all maternity staff include evidence-based learning on maternal health disparities, its possible causes and how to deliver culturally competent, personalised and evidence-led care.\u201d The committee also called for \u201ccontinuity of carer\u201d for patients \u2013 something it said was currently difficult \u201cdue to the considerable staffing shortages across maternity services\u201d. MPs said a fully staffed, properly funded maternity workforce was \u201cfundamental to delivering safe, personalised care to pregnant women and new mothers\u201d and they called on ministers to commit to an annual uplift of up to \u00a3350m for maternity units. Better data was also needed, they said, warning that black women were \u201cregularly under-represented in research or data and therefore in policymaking\u201d and that ethnicity data held by trusts was \u201cincomplete or inaccurate\u201d. Nokes said: \u201cWe cannot let these women remain invisible to the systems supposed to serve them. We are also afraid the government and NHS have not fully grasped that racism has played a key part in the complex reasons underlying the disparities, and that eradicating it is part of the solution.\u201d Laura Seebohm, the chief executive of the Maternal Mental Health Alliance, said: \u201cEnduring inequalities in maternity care continue to be deeply shocking. All women, babies and families have a right to high-quality, compassionate care during and after pregnancy. The human and economic consequences of failing to provide this are significant, making it vital that such disparities in maternal experiences and outcomes are addressed.\u201d The NHS said it was \u201ccommitted to ensuring all women receive high-quality care\u201d and had provided \u00a36.8m to help local health systems reduce health inequalities. A spokesperson acknowledged there was \u201cmore to be done\u201d and said the service would review the committee\u2019s recommendations. A Department of Health and Social Care spokesperson said: \u201cWhile the NHS is already one of the safest places to give birth in the world, we are absolutely clear that we must ensure maternity care is of the same high standard, regardless of race. \u201cWe\u2019ve invested \u00a3165m since 2021 to grow the maternity workforce and are promoting careers in midwifery with an extra 3,650 training places per year, while every local NHS maternity system has a plan in place to tackle disparities on a local level. \u201cThe maternity disparities taskforce \u2013 a collective of mothers, clinicians and key organisations \u2013 is being chaired today by minister Maria Caulfield to focus on how we can eradicate disparities and improve maternity outcomes for all mothers.\u201d On Monday, Badenoch admitted that only 32 of the 74 measures in the Inclusive Britain strategy published just over a year ago had been completed. The Black Equity Organisation, an independent group, said there needed to be an acceptance that structural racism exists, and until then ministers would \u201ccontinue to tinker around the edges\u201d of the problem.", "attributes": {}, "published": true, "createdDate": "2023-04-17T23:01:28Z", "lastModifiedDate": "2023-04-17T18:52:55Z", "contributors": [], "elements": [{"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>Ministers have failed to tackle \u201cappalling\u201d and \u201cglaring\u201d racial disparities in maternal health despite repeated promises, MPs have said, as they called for new targets to eliminate inequalities.</p> \n<p>In a scathing report, the women and equalities committee said maternal death rates in deprived areas were on the rise, with women in the poorest areas about two and half times more likely to die in childbirth than those in the richest areas.</p> \n<p>Black women are still almost four times more likely to die from childbirth than white women, the report says, and too many black women receive treatment that \u201cfalls short of acceptable standards\u201d. The government and NHS leaders have \u201cunderestimated the extent to which racism plays a role\u201d, it adds.</p> \n<p>It comes after Kemi Badenoch, the equalities minister, admitted on Monday that less than half the measures set out in the government\u2019s plan to tackle racial inequality and level up communities had been delivered.</p> \n<p>In February last year, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/society/2022/feb/13/radical-action-needed-to-tackle-racial-health-inequality-in-nhs-says-damning-report\">the Guardian exposed </a>how radical action was needed to tackle \u201coverwhelming\u201d racial health inequalities, after a leaked report concluded that \u201cvast\u201d and \u201cwidespread\u201d inequity in all aspects of healthcare was harming the health of millions of patients.</p> \n<p>Racism, racial discrimination, barriers to accessing healthcare and woeful collection of ethnicity data had \u201cnegatively impacted\u201d the health of black, Asian and minority ethnic people for years, according to the review, commissioned by the NHS Race and Health Observatory. But more than a year on, MPs say there has been \u201cmuch talk and little action\u201d.</p> \n<p>A government taskforce set up to tackle disparities in maternity care \u2013 announced nine days after the Guardian\u2019s report \u2013 has met just three times, the committee found. "https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/tv-and-radio", "code": "default"}]}, "isHosted": false, "pillarId": "pillar/arts", "pillarName": "Arts"}, {"id": "business/2023/apr/18/uk-has-no-public-electric-charger-or-hydrogen-refilling-station-solely-for-hgvs", "type": "article", "sectionId": "business", "sectionName": "Business", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:01:35Z", "webTitle": "UK has no public electric charger or hydrogen refilling station solely for HGVs", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/18/uk-has-no-public-electric-charger-or-hydrogen-refilling-station-solely-for-hgvs", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/business/2023/apr/18/uk-has-no-public-electric-charger-or-hydrogen-refilling-station-solely-for-hgvs", "fields": {"headline": "UK has no public electric charger or hydrogen refilling station solely for HGVs", "standfirst": "<p>Automotive sector\u2019s lobby group warns deadline to end sale of fossil fuel trucks by 2040 may be missed</p>", "trailText": "Automotive sector\u2019s lobby group warns deadline to end sale of fossil fuel trucks by 2040 may be missed", "byline": "Jasper Jolly", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"df725f4fc83a3955d8c89419b8e778f142702aa4\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/df725f4fc83a3955d8c89419b8e778f142702aa4/0_117_3500_2102/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A fully electric heavy goods vehicle\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Lorries are far behind the car industry in commercialising electric technology.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Adam Gasson/PA</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>The UK does not have a single public electric charger or hydrogen refilling station dedicated to lorries, with fewer than 12 years until the first ban on diesel engines comes into force, according to the automotive industry\u2019s lobby group.</p> <p>The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said the government must urgently set out a strategy to help the sector to decarbonise or risk missing the target to stop the sale of fossil fuel trucks by 2040.</p> <p>The lobby group said the lack of infrastructure \u201cmakes it impossible for the vast majority of operators to contemplate investments to decarbonise their fleets\u201d. It also called for larger subsidies for zero-emission trucks to match the likes of France and Finland, which offer grants up to three times the size of the UK\u2019s.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/17/jim-ratcliffe-ineos-electric-grenadier-austria\">Brexit backer Jim Ratcliffe\u2019s Ineos to build electric Grenadier in Austria</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Heavy goods vehicles were responsible for 20% of the UK\u2019s transport carbon emissions in 2021, or 21.4m tonnes, making them the second-biggest transport emitter, <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/final-uk-greenhouse-gas-emissions-national-statistics-1990-to-2021\">according to government data</a>. However, unlike for cars and vans, there is no clear consensus on <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/apr/29/hgv-manufacturers-race-to-decarbonise-trucks-lorries-carbon-footprint-uk\">which zero-emission technology will become dominant</a>.</p> <p>Manufacturers have started building and selling electric lorries, while others are experimenting with hydrogen fuel cells. However, the lorry sector is far behind the car industry in commercialising the technology: only one in 600 trucks on UK roads produce zero emissions.</p> <p>Electric lorries will require chargers capable of delivering more power than their car equivalents to prevent long wait times at filling stations, while there is no existing supply of the green hydrogen \u2013 produced from renewable power \u2013 that some companies are betting will be better suited to making longer trips.</p> <p>The first ban on internal combustion engines in new lorries is scheduled to come into force in 2035, when all trucks under 26 tonnes must produce zero carbon emissions. <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/jul/14/ban-on-polluting-lorries-pledged-in-tories-transport-greenprint\">All larger diesel lorries will be banned after 2040</a>.</p> <p>Mike Hawes, the SMMT\u2019s chief executive, said: \u201cWith just over a decade until the UK begins to phase out new diesel trucks, we cannot afford to delay a strategy that will deliver the world\u2019s first decarbonised HGV sector.</p> <p>\u201cManufacturers are investing billions in electric and hydrogen vehicles that will deliver massive CO<sub>2</sub> savings, and it is vital that operators making long-term decisions today have full confidence in these technologies, that they will be commercially viable and allow them to keep costs down for consumers.\u201d</p> <p>Rod McKenzie, a director of the Road Haulage Association, a lobby group for delivery companies, said: \u201cThe UK is reliant on its supply chain driven by trucks and supplying all the things people need. But there is no clear roadmap from the government on how we get to a net zero future. We need clarity on what type of fuel is best, investment in charging infrastructure, and help for small business operators to lease affordable new-generation trucks which currently cost three times as much.\u201d</p> <p>The UK government is also considering a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/jul/27/uk-government-backs-scheme-for-motorway-cables-to-power-lorries\">trial of an electric road system</a>, technology that would pair smaller, cheaper batteries with overhead cables to power trucks on the go when driving on the country\u2019s most important roads. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said the government must urgently set out a strategy to help the sector to decarbonise or risk missing the target to stop the sale of fossil fuel trucks by 2040. The lobby group said the lack of infrastructure \u201cmakes it impossible for the vast majority of operators to contemplate investments to decarbonise their fleets\u201d. It also called for larger subsidies for zero-emission trucks to match the likes of France and Finland, which offer grants up to three times the size of the UK\u2019s. Heavy goods vehicles were responsible for 20% of the UK\u2019s transport carbon emissions in 2021, or 21.4m tonnes, making them the second-biggest transport emitter, according to government data. However, unlike for cars and vans, there is no clear consensus on which zero-emission technology will become dominant. Manufacturers have started building and selling electric lorries, while others are experimenting with hydrogen fuel cells. However, the lorry sector is far behind the car industry in commercialising the technology: only one in 600 trucks on UK roads produce zero emissions. Electric lorries will require chargers capable of delivering more power than their car equivalents to prevent long wait times at filling stations, while there is no existing supply of the green hydrogen \u2013 produced from renewable power \u2013 that some companies are betting will be better suited to making longer trips. The first ban on internal combustion engines in new lorries is scheduled to come into force in 2035, when all trucks under 26 tonnes must produce zero carbon emissions. All larger diesel lorries will be banned after 2040. Mike Hawes, the SMMT\u2019s chief executive, said: \u201cWith just over a decade until the UK begins to phase out new diesel trucks, we cannot afford to delay a strategy that will deliver the world\u2019s first decarbonised HGV sector. \u201cManufacturers are investing billions in electric and hydrogen vehicles that will deliver massive CO2 savings, and it is vital that operators making long-term decisions today have full confidence in these technologies, that they will be commercially viable and allow them to keep costs down for consumers.\u201d Rod McKenzie, a director of the Road Haulage Association, a lobby group for delivery companies, said: \u201cThe UK is reliant on its supply chain driven by trucks and supplying all the things people need. But there is no clear roadmap from the government on how we get to a net zero future. We need clarity on what type of fuel is best, investment in charging infrastructure, and help for small business operators to lease affordable new-generation trucks which currently cost three times as much.\u201d The UK government is also considering a trial of an electric road system, technology that would pair smaller, cheaper batteries with overhead cables to power trucks on the go when driving on the country\u2019s most important roads. the south-east of the country.</p> <p>Richborough was a site on a small island in the Wantsum Channel, a stretch of water that separated Kent from Thanet. The Roman troops built fortifications at Richborough to protect Roman ships in the Channel. They built the first Roman road running from Richborough to north Wales.</p> <p>Over time, Richborough \u2013 known as Rutupiae to the Romans \u2013 grew from a military base into a thriving port town where goods from across the empire entered the new Roman province of Britannia. Objects found at the site include hundreds of brooches and thousands of coins.</p> <p>An amphitheatre seating up to 5,000 people was the venue for gladiatorial contests and occasional executions.</p> <p>The gateway has been reconstructed in oak, using Roman dovetail, lap and scarf joints. A tower above it was where soldiers and supplies were assembled.</p> <p>The reconstruction was a historic moment, said Paul Pattison, English Heritage\u2019s senior properties historian. \u201cTo be able to rebuild a structure as accurately as possible, and one that stands on the exact spot of the original at Richborough almost 2,000 years ago, is remarkable.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ca6bab5d3a3fc3261665ce5e8506c0ef680bcf67\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ca6bab5d3a3fc3261665ce5e8506c0ef680bcf67/0_1285_11648_6989/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Four women\u2019s hairpins found at the site\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">An exhibition of items found at the site includes women\u2019s hairpins.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Jim Holden/English Heritage</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cThe Roman invasion was a major milestone in our history. The original structure was built to allow soldiers a clear view of any threat to the military base they created at Richborough in Kent, the main entry point to Britain from mainland Europe and often referred to as the \u201cgateway to Britannia\u201d. Built by English Heritage, the charity that looks after more than 400 historic buildings, monuments and sites, the reconstructed gateway opens on Wednesday alongside a display of items found at the site. They include a 2,000-year-old cup made from blown glass from the Middle East, and women\u2019s hairpins, introduced as a fashion item by the Romans. A Roman army of about 40,000 soldiers landed in Britain in AD43 and established control of the south-east of the country. Richborough was a site on a small island in the Wantsum Channel, a stretch of water that separated Kent from Thanet. The Roman troops built fortifications at Richborough to protect Roman ships in the Channel. They built the first Roman road running from Richborough to north Wales. Over time, Richborough \u2013 known as Rutupiae to the Romans \u2013 grew from a military base into a thriving port town where goods from across the empire entered the new Roman province of Britannia. Objects found at the site include hundreds of brooches and thousands of coins. An amphitheatre seating up to 5,000 people was the venue for gladiatorial contests and occasional executions. The gateway has been reconstructed in oak, using Roman dovetail, lap and scarf joints. A tower above it was where soldiers and supplies were assembled. The reconstruction was a historic moment, said Paul Pattison, English Heritage\u2019s senior properties historian. \u201cTo be able to rebuild a structure as accurately as possible, and one that stands on the exact spot of the original at Richborough almost 2,000 years ago, is remarkable. \u201cThe Roman invasion was a major milestone in our history. The original structure was built to allow soldiers a clear view of any threat to the military base they created at Richborough in Kent, the main entry point to Britain from mainland Europe and often referred to as the \u201cgateway to Britannia\u201d. Built by English Heritage, the charity that looks after more than 400 historic buildings, monuments and sites, the reconstructed gateway opens on Wednesday alongside a display of items found at the site. They include a 2,000-year-old cup made from blown glass from the Middle East, and women\u2019s hairpins, introduced as a fashion item by the Romans.\nA Roman army of about 40,000 soldiers landed in Britain in AD43 and established control of the south-east of the country. Richborough was a site on a small island in the Wantsum Channel, a stretch of water that separated Kent from Thanet. The Roman troops built fortifications at Richborough to protect Roman ships in the Channel. They built the first Roman road running from Richborough to north Wales. Over time, Richborough \u2013 known as Rutupiae to the Romans \u2013 grew from a military base into a thriving port town where goods from across the empire entered the new Roman province of Britannia. Objects found at the site include hundreds of brooches and thousands of coins. An amphitheatre seating up to 5,000 people was the venue for gladiatorial contests and occasional executions. The gateway has been reconstructed in oak, using Roman dovetail, lap and scarf joints. A tower above it was where soldiers and supplies were assembled. class=\"gu-image\"> \n</figure>", "body": "<p>The royal family have the use of a fleet of luxury cars, including vintage Rolls-Royces, Bentleys, Jaguars and an Aston Martin. But untangling which vehicles are owned privately, which are held by the sovereign in right of the crown, and which are leased from the manufacturer is no simple task.</p> \n<p>The royal mews at Buckingham Palace is the primary home of the motorcade of limousines and other luxury vehicles used by the family for formal occasions. These are often referred to as \u201cstate cars\u201d, but the term does not necessarily mean they are owned by the state.</p> \n<p>Many were provided to the royal household by car manufacturers,<strong> </strong>which presumably want to associate their brand<strong> </strong>with the British royal family.</p> \n<p>Bentley, for example, provided two limousines in 2002 for Queen Elizabeth\u2019s golden jubilee, and one was reportedly flown out by the company to Germany for Charles\u2019s first state visit as king last month. An estimation of the value of the royal cars suggests these two vehicles alone could be worth at least \u00a31.4m.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"04b14b1a-cba5-4829-916e-65f6d219a40c\" data-atom-type=\"guide\"> \n  <div>\n   <div class=\"atom-Guide\">\n    <p></p>\n    <p>The Guardian identified 12 cars at the Sandringham estate, ranging from a 1900 Daimler Mail Phaeton first purchased by Edward VII to a 1999 Metrocab London Taxi formerly used by Prince Philip, which we assumed to be privately owned. King Charles\u2019s Aston Martin DB6, and a Rolls-Royce Phantom IV bought by the queen and Philip in the early years of their marriage were also considered to be private.</p>\n    <p>We used estimated valuations for each of the cars. Where we had two values, we took a conservative approach and used the lower figures throughout.</p>\n    <p>We visited the royal mews in Buckingham Palace, and conducted archive research to identify other cars that appear to be privately owned.</p>\n    <p>The Guardian approached Buckingham Palace four weeks before publication of this story with a list of cars considered to be private. Despite several requests, the palace refused to identify which specific cars in the mews were \"owned by the sovereign in right of the crown\" or leased from the manufacturer.</p>\n    <p><br></p>\n    <p></p>\n   </div>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>Bentley declined to explain the terms of its provision of cars to the palace, however some loaned or leased vehicles are understood to be returned to the manufacturer after being used by the royals.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"69658cfd40851353fff9976444d3eb557c35380a\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/69658cfd40851353fff9976444d3eb557c35380a/0_168_6000_3600/1000.jpg\" alt=\"King Charles and Camilla, the Queen Consort, in a state limousine after a welcome ceremony at Brandenburg Gate in Berlin on 29 March.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">King Charles and Camilla, the Queen Consort, in a state limousine after a welcome ceremony at Brandenburg Gate in Berlin on 29 March.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Ronny Hartmann/AFP/Getty Images</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>While Buckingham Palace declined to comment on the ownership of specific vehicles at the royal mews, it would appear that some are held by the sovereign in right of the crown, meaning they are not the king\u2019s personal property. But a visit to the mews by the Guardian suggests others are owned privately by the Windsors.</p> \n<p>A 1950 Rolls-Royce Phantom IV estimated to be worth at least \u00a32.5m, for instance, was bought by Elizabeth and Philip before she became queen. Only 18 Phantom IVs were made. On Elizabeth\u2019s accession, it was repainted in royal claret, and became a \u201cstate car\u201d, but there is nothing to suggest its ownership changed.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"bc6be0951ef65234793f02f7b575c1535fc4ea2d\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/bc6be0951ef65234793f02f7b575c1535fc4ea2d/0_97_3264_1958/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The Rolls-Royce Phantom IV at the royal mews in central London.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Rolls-Royce Phantom IV at the royal mews in central London.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: AFP/Getty Images</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>The mews also houses a 1962 Rolls-Royce Phantom V, which was bought by the queen mother and is understood to belong to Charles.</p> \n<p>A palace spokesperson said state cars housed at the royal mews were \u201cpredominantly owned by the sovereign in right of the crown or are leased\u201d. But they did not dispute that some of the vehicles were owned privately.</p> \n<p>Confusing matters further, even vehicles in the royal mews designated as \u201cstate cars\u201d are sometimes used in a private capacity.</p> \n<p>During her wedding in 2018, Princess Eugenie, who has never been a working royal, arrived in a <a href=\"https://www.royal.uk/wedding-princess-eugenie-and-jack-brooksbank-bridal-car\">1977 Rolls-Royce Phantom VI</a> worth \u00a31.3m. This state car was given to the queen as an official gift by the UK motor industry to mark her silver jubilee.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"2e648b45fb4c2eb2098bbca901f33cad03b9684d\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/2e648b45fb4c2eb2098bbca901f33cad03b9684d/0_245_4144_2487/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A cleaner works on the Rolls-Royce Phantom VI given to the queen as a silver jubilee gift.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A cleaner works on the Rolls-Royce Phantom VI given to the queen as a silver jubilee gift.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tim Graham Photo Library/Getty Images</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<h2>Sandringham fleet</h2> \n<p>A separate fleet of cars resides at the Windsors\u2019 private Sandringham estate in Norfolk.</p> \n<p>Housed in a former stable block is a collection of 12 vintage cars, estimated to be worth at least \u00a31.8m in total. All were formerly used by the royal household and are believed to be private property.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"bcd01839-2ba7-49bf-83a4-819906029401\" data-atom-type=\"guide\"> \n  <div>\n   <div class=\"atom-Guide\">\n    <p><strong></strong></p>\n    <p></p>\n    <p> Cost of the crown is an investigation into royal wealth and finances. The series, published ahead of the coronation of King Charles III, is seeking to overcome centuries of secrecy to better understand how the royal family is funded, the extent to which individual members have profited from their public roles, and the dubious origins of some of their wealth. The Guardian believes it is in the public interest to clarify what can legitimately be called private wealth, what belongs to the British people, and what, as so often is the case, straddles the two.</p>\n    <p>\u2022 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/05/how-the-british-royal-family-hides-its-wealth-from-public-scrutiny\">Read more about the investigation</a></p>\n    <p></p>\n   </div>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>The most expensive car is a 1961 Rolls-Royce Phantom V, worth at least \u00a3700,000. Its origins are unknown but it was used as a state car from 1961 to 2002.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"937ee212cd96e23126c5b5bec0909627b91f532c\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/937ee212cd96e23126c5b5bec0909627b91f532c/0_230_3916_2351/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Prince William and his wife, Catherine, drive from Buckingham Palace to Clarence House in his father\u2019s Aston Martin on their wedding day.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Prince William and his wife, Catherine, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/apr/30/prince-william-new-wife-aston-martin\">drive from Buckingham Palace to Clarence House</a> in his father\u2019s Aston Martin on their wedding day in 2011.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tom Jenkins/The Guardian</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>The palace did not say how the former state car ended up on the family\u2019s private estate. A spokesperson declined to comment on the ownership of the vehicles in Sandringham, adding: \u201cWe would not comment on any private property owned by members of the royal family.\u201d</p> \n<p>In addition to the cars in the palace and at Sandringham, Charles owns a 1970 Aston Martin DB6 Volante, which was a gift from the late queen on his 21st birthday. The car, converted in 2008 to run on bioethanol \u2013 or, as Charles described it, \u201cwine and cheese\u201d \u2013 could<strong> </strong>be worth at least \u00a32m at auction.</p> \n<p>The Guardian\u2019s analysis suggests that overall<strong> </strong>the king privately owns a fleet of cars worth, in total, at least \u00a36.3m.</p> \n<h2>And something for the ponies</h2> \n<p>Not included in the tally is another Aston Martin, a 1987 V8 Vantage Volante, given to Charles by the emir of Bahrain on a state visit. It was customised to the extent that it included a leather-trimmed sugar-lump jar for Charles\u2019s polo ponies in its glove box.</p> \n<p>In December 1995, Charles sold the car at Sotheby\u2019s for \u00a3110,000, and gave the funds to the Prince\u2019s Trust, his own charity. Earlier that year, the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/07/what-are-the-rules-on-gifts-for-the-royal-family#:~:text=Official%20gifts%20cannot%20be%20sold,manage%20the%20country's%20royal%20heritage.\">palace introduced a policy on gifts for the first time</a>. Updated in 2003, it now states: \u201cUnder no circumstances should official gifts be sold or exchanged.\u201d</p> \n<p>The palace declined to comment on how the disposal of an official state gift was compatible with the rules.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/from-tool/generic/index.html?vertical=News&amp;opinion-tint=false&amp;title=Story%20tips%3F&amp;description=Do%20you%20have%20information%20about%20this%20story%3F%20Email%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22mailto%3Ainvestigations%40theguardian.com%22%3Einvestigations%40theguardian.com%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20or%20use%20Signal%20or%20WhatsApp%20to%20message%20(UK)%20%2B44%207584%20640566%20or%20(US)%20%2B1%20646%20886%208761.%20For%20the%20most%20secure%20communications%2C%20use%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22nothttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fsecuredrop%22%3ESecureDrop%3C%2Fa%3E%20or%20see%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fhelp%2Fng-interactive%2F2017%2Fmar%2F17%2Fcontact-the-guardian-securely%22%3Eour%20guide%3C%2Fa%3E.&amp;link=false\" data-alt=\"Do you have information about this story? But untangling which vehicles are owned privately, which are held by the sovereign in right of the crown, and which are leased from the manufacturer is no simple task. The royal mews at Buckingham Palace is the primary home of the motorcade of limousines and other luxury vehicles used by the family for formal occasions. These are often referred to as \u201cstate cars\u201d, but the term does not necessarily mean they are owned by the state. Many were provided to the royal household by car manufacturers, which presumably want to associate their brand with the British royal family. Bentley, for example, provided two limousines in 2002 for Queen Elizabeth\u2019s golden jubilee, and one was reportedly flown out by the company to Germany for Charles\u2019s first state visit as king last month. An estimation of the value of the royal cars suggests these two vehicles alone could be worth at least \u00a31.4m. Bentley declined to explain the terms of its provision of cars to the palace, however some loaned or leased vehicles are understood to be returned to the manufacturer after being used by the royals. While Buckingham Palace declined to comment on the ownership of specific vehicles at the royal mews, it would appear that some are held by the sovereign in right of the crown, meaning they are not the king\u2019s personal property. But a visit to the mews by the Guardian suggests others are owned privately by the Windsors. A 1950 Rolls-Royce Phantom IV estimated to be worth at least \u00a32.5m, for instance, was bought by Elizabeth and Philip before she became queen. Only 18 Phantom IVs were made. On Elizabeth\u2019s accession, it was repainted in royal claret, and became a \u201cstate car\u201d, but there is nothing to suggest its ownership changed. The mews also houses a 1962 Rolls-Royce Phantom V, which was bought by the queen mother and is understood to belong to Charles. A palace spokesperson said state cars housed at the royal mews were \u201cpredominantly owned by the sovereign in right of the crown or are leased\u201d. But they did not dispute that some of the vehicles were owned privately. Confusing matters further, even vehicles in the royal mews designated as \u201cstate cars\u201d are sometimes used in a private capacity. During her wedding in 2018, Princess Eugenie, who has never been a working royal, arrived in a 1977 Rolls-Royce Phantom VI worth \u00a31.3m. This state car was given to the queen as an official gift by the UK motor industry to mark her silver jubilee. Sandringham fleet A separate fleet of cars resides at the Windsors\u2019 private Sandringham estate in Norfolk. Housed in a former stable block is a collection of 12 vintage cars, estimated to be worth at least \u00a31.8m in total. All were formerly used by the royal household and are believed to be private property. The most expensive car is a 1961 Rolls-Royce Phantom V, worth at least \u00a3700,000. Its origins are unknown but it was used as a state car from 1961 to 2002. The palace did not say how the former state car ended up on the family\u2019s private estate. A spokesperson declined to comment on the ownership of the vehicles in Sandringham, adding: \u201cWe would not comment on any private property owned by members of the royal family.\u201d In addition to the cars in the palace and at Sandringham, Charles owns a 1970 Aston Martin DB6 Volante, which was a gift from the late queen on his 21st birthday. The car, converted in 2008 to run on bioethanol \u2013 or, as Charles described it, \u201cwine and cheese\u201d \u2013 could be worth at least \u00a32m at auction. The Guardian\u2019s analysis suggests that overall the king privately owns a fleet of cars worth, in total, at least \u00a36.3m. And something for the ponies Not included in the tally is another Aston Martin, a 1987 V8 Vantage Volante, given to Charles by the emir of Bahrain on a state visit. It was customised to the extent that it included a leather-trimmed sugar-lump jar for Charles\u2019s polo ponies in its glove box. In December 1995, Charles sold the car at Sotheby\u2019s for \u00a3110,000, and gave the funds to the Prince\u2019s Trust, his own charity. Earlier that year, the palace introduced a policy on gifts for the first time. Updated in 2003, it now states: \u201cUnder no circumstances should official gifts be sold or exchanged.\u201d The palace declined to comment on how the disposal of an official state gift was "imageType": "Composite", "role": "showcase"}}]}, "body": [{"id": "6436e9d38f08791e579d3977", "bodyHtml": "<p>The royal family have the use of a fleet of luxury cars, including vintage Rolls-Royces, Bentleys, Jaguars and an Aston Martin. But untangling which vehicles are owned privately, which are held by the sovereign in right of the crown, and which are leased from the manufacturer is no simple task.</p> <p>The royal mews at Buckingham Palace is the primary home of the motorcade of limousines and other luxury vehicles used by the family for formal occasions. These are often referred to as \u201cstate cars\u201d, but the term does not necessarily mean they are owned by the state.</p> <p>Many were provided to the royal household by car manufacturers,<strong> </strong>which presumably want to associate their brand<strong> </strong>with the British royal family.</p> <p>Bentley, for example, provided two limousines in 2002 for Queen Elizabeth\u2019s golden jubilee, and one was reportedly flown out by the company to Germany for Charles\u2019s first state visit as king last month. An estimation of the value of the royal cars suggests these two vehicles alone could be worth at least \u00a31.4m.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"04b14b1a-cba5-4829-916e-65f6d219a40c\"         data-atom-type=\"guide\"    > </gu-atom> </figure>   <p>Bentley declined to explain the terms of its provision of cars to the palace, however some loaned or leased vehicles are understood to be returned to the manufacturer after being used by the royals.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"69658cfd40851353fff9976444d3eb557c35380a\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/69658cfd40851353fff9976444d3eb557c35380a/0_168_6000_3600/1000.jpg\" alt=\"King Charles and Camilla, the Queen Consort, in a state limousine after a welcome ceremony at Brandenburg Gate in Berlin on 29 March.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">King Charles and Camilla, the Queen Consort, in a state limousine after a welcome ceremony at Brandenburg Gate in Berlin on 29 March.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Ronny Hartmann/AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>While Buckingham Palace declined to comment on the ownership of specific vehicles at the royal mews, it would appear that some are held by the sovereign in right of the crown, meaning they are not the king\u2019s personal property. But a visit to the mews by the Guardian suggests others are owned privately by the Windsors.</p> <p>A 1950 Rolls-Royce Phantom IV estimated to be worth at least \u00a32.5m, for instance, was bought by Elizabeth and Philip before she became queen. Only 18 Phantom IVs were made. On Elizabeth\u2019s accession, it was repainted in royal claret, and became a \u201cstate car\u201d, but there is nothing to suggest its ownership changed.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"bc6be0951ef65234793f02f7b575c1535fc4ea2d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/bc6be0951ef65234793f02f7b575c1535fc4ea2d/0_97_3264_1958/1000.jpg\" alt=\"The Rolls-Royce Phantom IV at the royal mews in central London.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">The Rolls-Royce Phantom IV at the royal mews in central London.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: AFP/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The mews also houses a 1962 Rolls-Royce Phantom V, which was bought by the queen mother and is understood to belong to Charles.</p> <p>A palace spokesperson said state cars housed at the royal mews were \u201cpredominantly owned by the sovereign in right of the crown or are leased\u201d. But they did not dispute that some of the vehicles were owned privately.</p> <p>Confusing matters further, even vehicles in the royal mews designated as \u201cstate cars\u201d are sometimes used in a private capacity.</p> <p>During her wedding in 2018, Princess Eugenie, who has never been a working royal, arrived in a <a href=\"https://www.royal.uk/wedding-princess-eugenie-and-jack-brooksbank-bridal-car\">1977 Rolls-Royce Phantom VI</a> worth \u00a31.3m. This state car was given to the queen as an official gift by the UK motor industry to mark her silver jubilee.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"2e648b45fb4c2eb2098bbca901f33cad03b9684d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/2e648b45fb4c2eb2098bbca901f33cad03b9684d/0_245_4144_2487/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A cleaner works on the Rolls-Royce Phantom VI given to the queen as a silver jubilee gift.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A cleaner works on the Rolls-Royce Phantom VI given to the queen as a silver jubilee gift.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tim Graham Photo Library/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <h2>Sandringham fleet</h2> <p>A separate fleet of cars resides at the Windsors\u2019 private Sandringham estate in Norfolk.</p> <p>Housed in a former stable block is a collection of 12 vintage cars, estimated to be worth at least \u00a31.8m in total. All were formerly used by the royal household and are believed to be private property.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"bcd01839-2ba7-49bf-83a4-819906029401\"         data-atom-type=\"guide\"    > </gu-atom> </figure>   <p>The most expensive car is a 1961 Rolls-Royce Phantom V, worth at least \u00a3700,000. Its origins are unknown but it was used as a state car from 1961 to 2002.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"937ee212cd96e23126c5b5bec0909627b91f532c\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/937ee212cd96e23126c5b5bec0909627b91f532c/0_230_3916_2351/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Prince William and his wife, Catherine, drive from Buckingham Palace to Clarence House in his father\u2019s Aston Martin on their wedding day.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Prince William and his wife, Catherine, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/apr/30/prince-william-new-wife-aston-martin\">drive from Buckingham Palace to Clarence House</a> in his father\u2019s Aston Martin on their wedding day in 2011.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Tom Jenkins/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The palace did not say how the former state car ended up on the family\u2019s private estate. A spokesperson declined to comment on the ownership of the vehicles in Sandringham, adding: \u201cWe would not comment on any private property owned by members of the royal family.\u201d</p> <p>In addition to the cars in the palace and at Sandringham, Charles owns a 1970 Aston Martin DB6 Volante, which was a gift from the late queen on his 21st birthday. The car, converted in 2008 to run on bioethanol \u2013 or, as Charles described it, \u201cwine and cheese\u201d \u2013 could<strong> </strong>be worth at least \u00a32m at auction.</p> <p>The Guardian\u2019s analysis suggests that overall<strong> </strong>the king privately owns a fleet of cars worth, in total, at least \u00a36.3m.</p> <h2>And something for the ponies</h2> <p>Not included in the tally is another Aston Martin, a 1987 V8 Vantage Volante, given to Charles by the emir of Bahrain on a state visit. It was customised to the extent that it included a leather-trimmed sugar-lump jar for Charles\u2019s polo ponies in its glove box.</p> <p>In December 1995, Charles sold the car at Sotheby\u2019s for \u00a3110,000, and gave the funds to the Prince\u2019s Trust, his own charity. Earlier that year, the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/apr/07/what-are-the-rules-on-gifts-for-the-royal-family#:~:text=Official%20gifts%20cannot%20be%20sold,manage%20the%20country's%20royal%20heritage.\">palace introduced a policy on gifts for the first time</a>. Updated in 2003, it now states: \u201cUnder no circumstances should official gifts be sold or exchanged.\u201d</p> <p>The palace declined to comment on how the disposal of an official state gift was compatible with the rules.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/from-tool/generic/index.html?vertical=News&amp;opinion-tint=false&amp;title=Story%20tips%3F&amp;description=Do%20you%20have%20information%20about%20this%20story%3F%20Email%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22mailto%3Ainvestigations%40theguardian.com%22%3Einvestigations%40theguardian.com%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20or%20use%20Signal%20or%20WhatsApp%20to%20message%20(UK)%20%2B44%207584%20640566%20or%20(US)%20%2B1%20646%20886%208761.%20For%20the%20most%20secure%20communications%2C%20use%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22nothttps%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fsecuredrop%22%3ESecureDrop%3C%2Fa%3E%20or%20see%20%3Ca%20style%3D%22color%3A%23ab0613%22%20href%3D%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fhelp%2Fng-interactive%2F2017%2Fmar%2F17%2Fcontact-the-guardian-securely%22%3Eour%20guide%3C%2Fa%3E.&amp;link=false\" data-alt=\"Do you have information about this story? owned hairdressers and beauty salons were by far <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/mar/14/uk-hair-salons-and-chippies-among-indie-shops-most-hit-by-cost-of-living-crisis\">the The next worst affected category \u2013 newsagents \u2013 saw only a net 225 shut.</p> <p>The National Hair &amp; Beauty Federation said about a quarter of salons were making a loss, up from 19% in the autumn, and two-thirds expected to put up prices this spring amid more uncertainty about business survival. It has called for more government support with bills.</p> <p>Paul Faulkner, the owner of The Retreat Hairdressing in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, said his energy bills had risen by almost a third and he was locked into those costs after signing a three-year deal because of fears that prices would go even higher.</p> <p>He said the increase in the minimum wage this month had added another \u00a3200 a week to his costs while the price of products, such as shampoo and serum, had risen by about 5%.</p> <p>\u201cEverybody is finding it hard,\u201d Faulkner said, adding that his suppliers \u201cjust keep putting things up\u201d.</p> <p>\u201cThe rising cost of energy is a major issue for my business,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need to continue to provide the best possible service for customers without having to raise prices, but it is unfortunately becoming more and more difficult.\u201d</p> <p>The Retreat has made changes to adapt, such as putting in energy-saving LED strip lights instead of chandeliers and asking staff to charge their phones at home in order to save on energy.</p> <p>It owns its own building and so has not suffered from higher rental costs, unlike many other similar businesses locally, and has been able to avoid increasing its prices. This has meant the salon has held on to its customers, but Faulkner said some were coming less often.</p> <p>Louise Howard-Long, the owner of Architect Hair in Headingley, Leeds, said she was worried about what would happen with energy bills when she came to the end of a fixed deal in September.</p> <p>She said: \u201cI am lucky because I signed a fixed deal but so many [salons] are going under because of energy costs.</p> <p>\u201cWe have a lot of regular clients who are still coming in but some are embracing their grey. Rather than come in for a colour every four weeks they are coming in for a cut every eight.\u201d</p> <p> Howard-Long said her profit margins had already been squeezed by an increase in the price of hair dyes \u2013 by as much as a quarter \u2013 and other necessities from refreshments for customers to shampoo. Two-fifths of salon owners say they are anxious about the future, with almost a quarter struggling to pay their energy costs and one in five having to ask family and friends for financial help, according to a survey by the comparison site Uswitch. Independently owned hairdressers and beauty salons were by far the hardest hit by rising energy bills and the consumer spending squeeze among independent retailers last year \u2013 with a net 624 closing, according to the Local Data Company. The next worst affected category \u2013 newsagents \u2013 saw only a net 225 shut. The National Hair &amp; Beauty Federation said about a quarter of salons were making a loss, up from 19% in the autumn, and two-thirds expected to put up prices this spring amid more uncertainty about business survival. It has called for more government support with bills. Paul Faulkner, the owner of The Retreat Hairdressing in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, said his energy bills had risen by almost a third and he was locked into those costs after signing a three-year deal because of fears that prices would go even higher. He said the increase in the minimum wage this month had added another \u00a3200 a week to his costs while the price of products, such as shampoo and serum, had risen by about 5%. \u201cEverybody is finding it hard,\u201d Faulkner said, adding that his suppliers \u201cjust keep putting things up\u201d. \u201cThe rising cost of energy is a major issue for my business,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need to continue to provide the best possible service for customers without having to raise prices, but it is unfortunately becoming more and more difficult.\u201d The Retreat has made changes to adapt, such as putting in energy-saving LED strip lights instead of chandeliers and asking staff to charge their phones at home in order to save on energy. It owns its own building and so has not suffered from higher rental costs, unlike many other similar businesses locally, and has been able to avoid increasing its prices. This has meant the salon has held on to its customers, but Faulkner said some were coming less often. Louise Howard-Long, the owner of Architect Hair in Headingley, Leeds, said she was worried about what would happen with energy bills when she came to the end of a fixed deal in September. She said: \u201cI am lucky because I signed a fixed deal but so many [salons] are going under because of energy costs. \u201cWe have a lot of regular clients who are still coming in but some are embracing their grey. The next worst affected category \u2013 newsagents \u2013 saw only a net 225 shut.</p> <p>The National Hair &amp; Beauty Federation said about a quarter of salons were making a loss, up from 19% in the autumn, and two-thirds expected to put up prices this spring amid more uncertainty about business survival. It has called for more government support with bills.</p> <p>Paul Faulkner, the owner of The Retreat Hairdressing in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, said his energy bills had risen by almost a third and he was locked into those costs after signing a three-year deal because of fears that prices would go even higher.</p> <p>He said the increase in the minimum wage this month had added another \u00a3200 a week to his costs while the price of products, such as shampoo and serum, had risen by about 5%.</p> <p>\u201cEverybody is finding it hard,\u201d Faulkner said, adding that his suppliers \u201cjust keep putting things up\u201d.</p> <p>\u201cThe rising cost of energy is a major issue for my business,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need to continue to provide the best possible service for customers without having to raise prices, but it is unfortunately becoming more and more difficult.\u201d</p> <p>The Retreat has made changes to adapt, such as putting in energy-saving LED strip lights instead of chandeliers and asking staff to charge their phones at home in order to save on energy.</p> <p>It owns its own building and so has not suffered from higher rental costs, unlike many other similar businesses locally, and has been able to avoid increasing its prices. This has meant the salon has held on to its customers, but Faulkner said some were coming less often.</p> <p>Louise Howard-Long, the owner of Architect Hair in Headingley, Leeds, said she was worried about what would happen with energy bills when she came to the end of a fixed deal in September.</p> <p>She said: \u201cI am lucky because I signed a fixed deal but so many [salons] are going under because of energy costs.</p> <p>\u201cWe have a lot of regular clients who are still coming in but some are embracing their grey. Rather than come in for a colour every four weeks they are coming in for a cut every eight.\u201d</p> <p> Howard-Long said her profit margins had already been squeezed by an increase in the price of hair dyes \u2013 by as much as a quarter \u2013 and other necessities from refreshments for customers to shampoo. She is also having to repay a government-backed loan taken out to keep the business going during the pandemic lockdowns.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "More than a quarter of hairdressers are thinking of closing sites or reducing the size of their salon as stylists struggle with high bills and fewer clients, research suggests. Two-fifths of salon owners say they are anxious about the future, with almost a quarter struggling to pay their energy costs and one in five having to ask family and friends for financial help, according to a survey by the comparison site Uswitch. Independently owned hairdressers and beauty salons were by far the hardest hit by rising energy bills and the consumer spending squeeze among independent retailers last year \u2013 with a net 624 closing, according to the Local Data Company. The next worst affected category \u2013 newsagents \u2013 saw only a net 225 shut. The National Hair & Beauty Federation said about a quarter of salons were making a loss, up from 19% in the autumn, and two-thirds expected to put up prices this spring amid more uncertainty about business survival. It has called for more government support with bills. Paul Faulkner, the owner of The Retreat Hairdressing in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, said his energy bills had risen by almost a third and he was locked into those costs after signing a three-year deal because of fears that prices would go even higher. He said the increase in the minimum wage this month had added another \u00a3200 a week to his costs while the price of products, such as shampoo and serum, had risen by about 5%. \u201cEverybody is finding it hard,\u201d Faulkner said, adding that his suppliers \u201cjust keep putting things up\u201d. \u201cThe rising cost of energy is a major issue for my business,\u201d he said. \u201cWe need to continue to provide the best possible service for customers without having to raise prices, but it is unfortunately becoming more and more difficult.\u201d The Retreat has made changes to adapt, such as putting in energy-saving LED strip lights instead of chandeliers and asking staff to charge their phones at home in order to save on energy. It owns its own building and so has not suffered from higher rental costs, unlike many other similar businesses locally, and has been able to avoid increasing its prices. This has meant the salon has held on to its customers, but Faulkner said some were coming less often. Louise Howard-Long, the owner of Architect Hair in Headingley, Leeds, said she was worried about what would happen with energy bills when she came to the end of a fixed deal in September. She said: \u201cI am lucky because I signed a fixed deal but so many [salons] are going under because of energy costs. \u201cWe have a lot of regular clients who are still coming in but some are embracing their grey. Rather than come in for a colour every four weeks they are coming in for a cut every eight.\u201d Howard-Long said her profit margins had already been squeezed by an increase in the price of hair dyes \u2013 by as much as a quarter \u2013 and other necessities from refreshments for customers to shampoo. Vladimir Putin to use \u201cwhatever tools he\u2019s got left\u201d including nuclear threats and cyber-attacks in response to an expected Ukrainian counter-offensive against Russia.</p> <p>British officials at the G7 foreign ministers\u2019 summit in Japan said they were expecting Russia to retaliate and \u201cmust be prepared\u201d for extreme tactics as it attempted to hold on to Ukrainian territory.</p> <p>The former Russian president Dmitry Medvedev said last month that Moscow was ready for the Ukrainians to hit back, warning that his country would use \u201cabsolutely any weapon\u201d if Kyiv attempted to retake Crimea, which was annexed by Russia in 2014.</p> <p>There appeared to be an acknowledgment in Moscow that its forces might soon find themselves on the defensive in Ukraine as Russia\u2019s own winter offensive appeared to be slowing down.</p> <p>Russia\u2019s nuclear rhetoric has united the G7 ministers, who issued a statement after their two-hour meeting on Monday condemning the threats as \u201cunacceptable\u201d and criticising Putin\u2019s plan to deploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus.</p> <p>G7 officials said there was an \u201copen exchange of views\u201d in the talks on the approach to the Ukrainian conflict, including on \u201cfuture prospects\u201d for bringing the war to an end, which Rishi Sunak has said would eventually be around the negotiating table.</p> <p>However, Foreign Office sources suggested that the only way to finally resolve the conflict would be for Putin to withdraw his troops from Crimea and for the west to give Kyiv the tools to finish the job.</p> <p>Despite pressure from Ukraine, and others including the former UK prime minister Boris Johnson, to increase military support \u2013 including more tanks and fighter jets \u2013 the UK believes it is providing what the country needs. Sources said it was already committing its \u201crainy day fund\u201d.</p> <p>A transatlantic group of former senior diplomats and high-level military advisers said on Monday that the war in Ukraine was on course to become a stalemate unless the west went \u201call in\u201d and increased its level of military support.</p> <p>The group said that \u201cdeclarations of unwavering support\u201d were not enough and \u201cactions still fail to match the rhetoric\u201d in a reflection of military assessments in European capitals and Washington.</p> <p>At the G7 summit, the ministers reaffirmed their commitment to \u201cintensifying, fully coordinating and enforcing\u201d sanctions against Russia, agreeing to be more coordinated to prevent evasion of the measures and to target third parties supplying weapons to Moscow.</p> <p>It came as the foreign secretary, James Cleverly, demanded the release of a British-Russian opposition leader after he was sentenced to 25 years in prison by a court in Moscow, paying tribute to Vladimir Kara-Murza Jr for \u201cbravely\u201d denouncing Putin\u2019s invasion of Ukraine.</p> <p>The Kremlin critic, who has twice survived poisonings, was convicted on charges of treason and denigrating the Russian military in what he denounced as a show trial.</p> <p>The Russian ambassador to the UK, Andrei Kelin, was summoned to the Foreign Office for a dressing down on Monday over Russia\u2019s human rights obligations, including the right to a fair trial.</p> <p>Meanwhile, the US secretary of state Antony Blinken\u2019s G7 bilateral talks with his French counterpart, Catherine Colonna, over-ran, prompting speculation her talks with the US had been fraught.</p> <p>The French president, Emmanuel Macron, provoked controversy last week when he said, on a flight back from China, that Europe should not become a \u201cvassal\u201d to the US on foreign policy.</p> <p>He had previously been accused of naivety when he said Moscow must not be \u201chumiliated\u201d and would need security guarantees. G7 officials stressed that all member nations, including France, were united on the need to prevent Putin\u2019s attempts to divide and conquer.</p> <p>Eastern European governments, in particular, had accused Macron of failing to learn the lessons of the war. Without US military and financial support for Kyiv, more than 30 times that of France, Ukrainian resistance would have already crumbled, they believe.</p> <p>In separate talks in Japan, G7 nations including UK, US, Canada, Japan and France formed an alliance to develop shared supply chains for nuclear fuel, aimed at pushing Russia out of the international nuclear energy market.</p> <p>The UK\u2019s Department for Energy Security and Net Zero said the five countries would use their civil nuclear power sectors to undermine Russia\u2019s grip on supply chains, cutting off another means for Putin to fund his invasion of Ukraine.</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "16", "wordcount": "717", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:00:37Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T07:55:43Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-18T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnfn4", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/efa05ed884dec4c3ea25183bc526d3ca6f509862/0_336_5143_3086/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Western leaders are preparing for Vladimir Putin to use \u201cwhatever tools he\u2019s got left\u201d including nuclear threats and cyber-attacks in response to an expected Ukrainian counter-offensive against Russia. British officials at the G7 foreign ministers\u2019 summit in Japan said they were expecting Russia to retaliate and \u201cmust be prepared\u201d for extreme tactics as it attempted to hold on to Ukrainian territory. The former Russian president Dmitry Medvedev said last month that Moscow was ready for the Ukrainians to hit back, warning that his country would use \u201cabsolutely any weapon\u201d if Kyiv attempted to retake Crimea, which was annexed by Russia in 2014. There appeared to be an acknowledgment in Moscow that its forces might soon find themselves on the defensive in Ukraine as Russia\u2019s own winter offensive appeared to be slowing down. Russia\u2019s nuclear rhetoric has united the G7 ministers, who issued a statement after their two-hour meeting on Monday condemning the threats as \u201cunacceptable\u201d and criticising Putin\u2019s plan to deploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus. G7 officials said there was an \u201copen exchange of views\u201d in the talks on the approach to the Ukrainian conflict, including on \u201cfuture prospects\u201d for bringing the war to an end, which Rishi Sunak has said would eventually be around the negotiating table. However, Foreign Office sources suggested that the only way to finally resolve the conflict would be for Putin to withdraw his troops from Crimea and for the west to give Kyiv the tools to finish the job. Despite pressure from Ukraine, and others including the former UK prime minister Boris Johnson, to increase military support \u2013 including more tanks and fighter jets \u2013 the UK believes it is providing what the country needs. Sources said it was already committing its \u201crainy day fund\u201d. A transatlantic group of former senior diplomats and high-level military advisers said on Monday that the war in Ukraine was on course to become a stalemate unless the west went \u201call in\u201d and increased its level of military support. The group said that \u201cdeclarations of unwavering support\u201d were not enough and \u201cactions still fail to match the rhetoric\u201d in a reflection of military assessments in European capitals and Washington. At the G7 summit, the ministers reaffirmed their commitment to \u201cintensifying, fully coordinating and enforcing\u201d sanctions against Russia, agreeing to be more coordinated to prevent evasion of the measures and to target third parties supplying weapons to Moscow. It came as the foreign secretary, James Cleverly, demanded the release of a British-Russian opposition leader after he was sentenced to 25 years in prison by a court in Moscow, paying tribute to Vladimir Kara-Murza Jr for \u201cbravely\u201d denouncing Putin\u2019s invasion of Ukraine. The Kremlin critic, who has twice survived poisonings, was convicted on charges of treason and denigrating the Russian military in what he denounced as a show trial. The Russian ambassador to the UK, Andrei Kelin, was summoned to the Foreign Office for a dressing down on Monday over Russia\u2019s human rights obligations, including the right to a fair trial. Meanwhile, the US secretary of state Antony Blinken\u2019s G7 bilateral talks with his French counterpart, Catherine Colonna, over-ran, prompting speculation her talks with the US had been fraught. The French president, Emmanuel Macron, provoked controversy last week when he said, on a flight back from China, that Europe should not become a \u201cvassal\u201d to the US on foreign policy. He had previously been accused of naivety when he said Moscow must not be \u201chumiliated\u201d and would need security guarantees. G7 officials stressed that all member nations, including France, were united on the need to prevent Putin\u2019s attempts to divide and conquer. Eastern European governments, in particular, had accused Macron of failing to learn the lessons of the war. Without US military and financial support for Kyiv, more than 30 times that of France, Ukrainian resistance would have already crumbled, they believe. In separate talks in Japan, G7 nations including UK, US, Canada, Japan and France formed an alliance to develop shared supply chains for nuclear fuel, aimed at pushing Russia out of the international nuclear energy market. Moscow was ready for the Ukrainians to hit back, warning that his country would use \u201cabsolutely any weapon\u201d if Kyiv attempted to retake Crimea, which was annexed by Russia in 2014.</p> <p>There appeared to be an acknowledgment in Moscow that its forces might soon find themselves on the defensive in Ukraine as Russia\u2019s own winter offensive appeared to be slowing down.</p> <p>Russia\u2019s nuclear rhetoric has united the G7 ministers, who issued a statement after their two-hour meeting on Monday condemning the threats as \u201cunacceptable\u201d and criticising Putin\u2019s plan to deploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus.</p> <p>G7 officials said there was an \u201copen exchange of views\u201d in the talks on the approach to the Ukrainian conflict, including on \u201cfuture prospects\u201d for bringing the war to an end, which Rishi Sunak has said would eventually be around the negotiating table.</p> <p>However, Foreign Office sources suggested needs. was on course to become a stalemate unless the west went \u201call in\u201d and increased its level of military support.</p> <p>The group said that \u201cdeclarations of unwavering support\u201d were court in Moscow, paying tribute to Vladimir Kara-Murza Jr for \u201cbravely\u201d denouncing Putin\u2019s invasion of Ukraine.</p> <p>The Kremlin critic, who has twice survived poisonings, was convicted on charges of treason and denigrating the Russian military in what he denounced as a show trial.</p> <p>The Russian ambassador to the UK, Andrei Kelin, was summoned to the Foreign Office for \u201chumiliated\u201d and would need security guarantees. "https://content.guardianapis.com/business/nils-pratley-on-finance/2023/apr/18/private-equity-london-stock-exchange-thg-john-wood", "fields": {"headline": "Private equity\u2019s dominance has gone too far", "standfirst": "<p>London Stock Exchange should try to create stepping stone between private ownership and quoted status</p>", "trailText": "London Stock Exchange should try to create stepping stone between private ownership and quoted status", "byline": "Nils Pratley", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"bab7955a4add8ebf0030db5e365d48c844190aec\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/bab7955a4add8ebf0030db5e365d48c844190aec/0_289_4500_2701/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Person holding phone displaying logo of British e-commerce business THG on screen\"
