Monday.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Timon Schneider/Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Here it is then: private equity\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/17/thg-shares-surge-on-takeover-move-amid-spate-of-us-private-equity-offers-for-uk-firms\">long-predicted raid</a> on the UK\u2019s ranks of mid-sized quoted companies. Last week, Dechra Pharmaceuticals, a veterinary medicine group, said it had received a potential cash bid of \u00a34.6bn from EQT, the Swedish private equity firm. Then Network International, a payments processor in the Middle East and Africa, said it was in talks with the European private equity titan CVC plus Francisco Partners from the US.</p> <p>On Monday, the Aberdeen-based oilfield services group John Wood, after putting up stout resistance for weeks, said it was open to talks with Apollo of the US. And Apollo popped up again mid-morning with a tentative approach to THG, the headline-hogging e-commerce retailer formerly called The Hut Group.</p> <p>The reasons for this flurry of activity aren\u2019t hard to guess. Would-be buyers are increasingly confident that interest rates are close to their peak, a crucial consideration for them given the quantities of debt that private equity tends to load on to everything it acquires.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/17/thg-shares-surge-on-takeover-move-amid-spate-of-us-private-equity-offers-for-uk-firms\">THG shares soar on takeover move amid spate of private equity bids for UK firms</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The UK stock market, even after a good run, also looks cheap by international standards. And, now that Liz Truss and Kwasi Kwarteng are off the scene, the pound is no longer seen as a currency that can <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/sep/25/city-braces-for-more-volatility-mini-budget-rocks-pound-parity-dollar-bond-tax\">crumble after a mini-budget</a>. So, yes, for a private equity industry heavy with cash that must be converted into real investments, the UK stock market is an obvious place to look.</p> <p>London\u2019s battalions of advisers, lawyers and hangers-on will be delighted but anybody worried about the long-term health and vitality of the UK\u2019s stock market has fewer reasons to be cheerful. Some of these targets (think THG) may be suited to private life, but stock markets are still meant to be more than just a hunting ground for private equity\u2019s raiders.</p> <p>The decline in the number of quoted companies isn\u2019t a London-only phenomenon, and nor can it be pinned solely on the 20-year-plus fashion for \u201cprivate investments\u201d. Even so, the numbers are remarkable: there were 2,101 companies on the UK\u2019s main market in 2003; now there are 1,097.</p> <p>What\u2019s to be done? There\u2019s little point bemoaning the existence of bids and takeovers. In a loose sense, a quoted company is up for sale every day. And, while one can grumble (justifiably) about fund managers\u2019 short-termism, freedom to accept an offer is part of the share-owning game. It is more useful to ask why new companies aren\u2019t arriving at the old pace. We\u2019d be less bothered about leavers if newcomers took their place.</p> <p>On that front, private equity\u2019s less-publicised impact on stock markets is its ability to scoop up privately owned companies before they have even got close to a float, or IPO. Too often, the original backers regard a quick sale to private equity as an easier \u201ccrystallisation event\u201d than jumping through the regulatory hoops of an IPO.</p> <p>Here, though, is an intriguing idea within the many consultations to invigorate the UK\u2019s capital markets: create a regulated platform that would allow private companies to operate share-trading windows \u2013 once a week, once a month, or whenever \u2013 as a stepping stone towards the public arena.</p> <p>The aim is to lessen the perceived cliff edge between private ownership and quoted life. A company would get access to a bit of public market liquidity without the full-blown reporting demands of a proper IPO. Early-stage backers would be able to cash in a few chips, which might dampen their lobbying for an all-or-nothing outcome in which a trade sale too often beats an IPO. Big UK institutional investors would be able to test the waters, get familiar with a company and maybe, over time, exert influence in favour of the stock market.</p> <p>The proposal is clearly not a cure-all (reforming the regulatory rulebook in areas where London\u2019s setup just looks more cumbersome than other venues is probably more important). Nor is it likely to happen soon, since stock exchange officials are clear that some serious rewriting of rules would be necessary, not least to ensure equality of information between all investors while still preserving the looser touch of private life. Nor, obviously, would all companies on such a new platform convert to the full market. But, after a taster experience, some might.</p> <p>At the very least, it is a genuinely novel idea since it isn\u2019t being done elsewhere. If the London Stock Exchange wants to be \u201cyoung and scrappy\u201d to compete, as <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/bfe7f1c2-246a-4191-bf05-fd78178e0044\">newish boss Julia Hoggett has argued</a>, this is the sort of thing it should be trying. The dominance of private equity has gone too far.</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "27", "wordcount": "754", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:00:36Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T05:00:36Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-18T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnghf", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/bab7955a4add8ebf0030db5e365d48c844190aec/0_289_4500_2701/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Here it is then: private equity\u2019s long-predicted raid on the UK\u2019s ranks of mid-sized quoted companies. Last week, Dechra Pharmaceuticals, a veterinary medicine group, said it had received a potential cash bid of \u00a34.6bn from EQT, the Swedish private equity firm. Then Network International, a payments processor in the Middle East and Africa, said it was in talks with the European private equity titan CVC plus Francisco Partners from the US. On Monday, the Aberdeen-based oilfield services group John Wood, after putting up stout resistance for weeks, said it was open to talks with Apollo of the US. And Apollo popped up again mid-morning with a tentative approach to THG, the headline-hogging e-commerce retailer formerly called The Hut Group. The reasons for this flurry of activity aren\u2019t hard to guess. Would-be buyers are increasingly confident that interest rates are close to their peak, a crucial consideration for them given the quantities of debt that private equity tends to load on to everything it acquires. The UK stock market, even after a good run, also looks cheap by international standards. And, now that Liz Truss and Kwasi Kwarteng are off the scene, the pound is no longer seen as a currency that can crumble after a mini-budget. So, yes, for a private equity industry heavy with cash that must be converted into real investments, the UK stock market is an obvious place to look. London\u2019s battalions of advisers, lawyers and hangers-on will be delighted but anybody worried about the long-term health and vitality of the UK\u2019s stock market has fewer reasons to be cheerful. Some of these targets (think THG) may be suited to private life, but stock markets are still meant to be more than just a hunting ground for private equity\u2019s raiders. The decline in the number of quoted companies isn\u2019t a London-only phenomenon, and nor can it be pinned solely on the 20-year-plus fashion for \u201cprivate investments\u201d. Even so, the numbers are remarkable: there were 2,101 companies on the UK\u2019s main market in 2003; now there are 1,097. What\u2019s to be done? There\u2019s little point bemoaning the existence of bids and takeovers. In a loose sense, a quoted company is up for sale every day. And, while one can grumble (justifiably) about fund managers\u2019 short-termism, freedom to accept an offer is part of the share-owning game. It is more useful to ask why new companies aren\u2019t arriving at the old pace. We\u2019d be less bothered about leavers if newcomers took their place. On that front, private equity\u2019s less-publicised impact on stock markets is its ability to scoop up privately owned companies before they have even got close to a float, or IPO. Too often, the original backers regard a quick sale to private equity as an easier \u201ccrystallisation event\u201d than jumping through the regulatory hoops of an IPO. Here, though, is an intriguing idea within the many consultations to invigorate the UK\u2019s capital markets: create a regulated platform that would allow private companies to operate share-trading windows \u2013 once a week, once a month, or whenever \u2013 as a stepping stone towards the public arena. The aim is to lessen the perceived cliff edge between private ownership and quoted life. A company would get access to a bit of public market liquidity without the full-blown reporting demands of a proper IPO. Early-stage backers would be able to cash in a few chips, which might dampen their lobbying for an all-or-nothing outcome in which a trade sale too often beats an IPO. Big UK institutional investors would be able to test the waters, get familiar with a company and maybe, over time, exert influence in favour of the stock market. The proposal is clearly not a cure-all (reforming the regulatory rulebook in areas where London\u2019s setup just looks more cumbersome than other venues is probably more important). Nor is it likely to happen soon, since stock exchange officials are clear that some serious rewriting of rules would be necessary, not least to ensure equality of information between all investors while still preserving the looser touch of private life. Nor, obviously, would all companies on such a new platform convert to the full market. But, after a taster experience, some might. At the very least, it is a genuinely novel idea since it isn\u2019t being done elsewhere. If the London Stock Exchange wants to be \u201cyoung and scrappy\u201d to compete, as newish boss Julia Hoggett has argued, this is the sort of thing it should be trying. And, now that Liz Truss and Kwasi Kwarteng are off the scene, the pound is no longer seen as a currency that can <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2022/sep/25/city-braces-for-more-volatility-mini-budget-rocks-pound-parity-dollar-bond-tax\">crumble after a mini-budget</a>. So, yes, for a private equity industry heavy with cash that must be converted into real investments, the UK stock market is an obvious place to look.</p> \n<p>London\u2019s battalions of advisers, lawyers and hangers-on will be delighted but anybody worried about the long-term health and vitality of the UK\u2019s stock market has fewer reasons to be cheerful. Some of these targets (think THG) may be suited to private life, but stock markets are still meant to be more than just a hunting ground for private equity\u2019s raiders.</p> \n<p>The decline in the number of quoted companies isn\u2019t a London-only phenomenon, and nor can it be pinned solely on the 20-year-plus fashion for \u201cprivate investments\u201d. Even so, the numbers are remarkable: there were 2,101 companies on the UK\u2019s main market in 2003; now there are 1,097.</p> \n<p>What\u2019s to be done? There\u2019s little point bemoaning the existence of bids and takeovers. In a loose sense, a quoted company is up for sale every day. And, while one can grumble (justifiably) about fund managers\u2019 short-termism, freedom to accept an offer is part of the share-owning game. It is more useful to ask why new companies aren\u2019t arriving at the old pace. We\u2019d be less bothered about leavers if newcomers took their place.</p> \n<p>On that front, private equity\u2019s less-publicised impact on stock markets is its ability to scoop up privately owned companies before they have even got close to a float, or IPO. Too often, the original backers regard a quick sale to private equity as an easier \u201ccrystallisation event\u201d than jumping through the regulatory hoops of an IPO.</p> \n<p>Here, though, is an intriguing idea within the many consultations to invigorate the UK\u2019s capital markets: create a regulated platform that would allow private companies to operate share-trading windows \u2013 once a week, once a month, or whenever \u2013 as a stepping stone towards the public arena.</p> \n<p>The aim is to lessen the perceived cliff edge between private ownership and quoted life. A company would get access to a bit of public market liquidity without the full-blown reporting demands of a proper IPO. Early-stage backers would be able to cash in a few chips, which might dampen their lobbying for an all-or-nothing outcome in which a trade sale too often beats an IPO. Big UK institutional investors would be able to test the waters, get familiar with a company and maybe, over time, exert influence in favour of the stock market.</p> \n<p>The proposal is clearly not a cure-all (reforming the regulatory rulebook in areas where London\u2019s setup just looks more cumbersome than other venues is probably more important). Nor is it likely to happen soon, since stock exchange officials are clear that some serious rewriting of rules would be necessary, not least to ensure equality of information between all investors while still preserving the looser touch of private life. Nor, obviously, would all companies on such a new platform convert to the full market. But, after a taster experience, some might.</p> \n<p>At the very least, it is a genuinely novel idea since it isn\u2019t being done elsewhere. If the London Stock Exchange wants to be \u201cyoung and scrappy\u201d to compete, as <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/bfe7f1c2-246a-4191-bf05-fd78178e0044\">newish boss Julia Hoggett has argued</a>, this is the sort of thing it should be trying. The dominance of private equity has gone too far.</p>"}}]}], "totalBodyBlocks": 1}, "rights": {"syndicatable": "true", "subscriptionDatabases": "true", "developerCommunity": "true"}, "section": {"id": "business", "webTitle": "Business", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/business", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/business", "editions": [{"id": "business", "webTitle": "Business", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/business", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/business", "code": "default"}, {"id": "uk/business", "webTitle": "Business", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/uk/business", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/uk/business", "code": "uk"}, {"id": "us/business", "webTitle": "Business", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/us/business", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/us/business", "code": "us"}, {"id": "au/business", "webTitle": "Business", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/au/business", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/au/business", "code": "au"}]}, "isHosted": false, "pillarId": "pillar/news", "pillarName": "News"}, {"id": "technology/2023/apr/18/mastodon-users-twitter-elon-musk-social-media", "type": "article", "sectionId": "technology", "sectionName": "Technology", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:00:36Z", "webTitle": "Thousands fled to Mastodon after Musk bought Twitter. Are they still \u2018tooting\u2019?", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/apr/18/mastodon-users-twitter-elon-musk-social-media", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/technology/2023/apr/18/mastodon-users-twitter-elon-musk-social-media", "fields": {"headline": "Thousands fled to Mastodon after Musk bought Twitter. Are they still \u2018tooting\u2019?", "standfirst": "<p>The decentralized social network has seen user numbers drop in recent months, but tech-savvy users remain passionate</p>", "trailText": "The decentralized social network has seen user numbers drop in recent months, but tech-savvy users remain passionate", "byline": "Wilfred Chan", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"81362d0c085d98e5efc0b9aa63623c3a8d0982a5\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/81362d0c085d98e5efc0b9aa63623c3a8d0982a5/0_333_6000_3600/1000.jpg\" alt=\"image of mastodon on a phone, featuring cartoon pictures of mastodon animals. the phone is being held over a background of twitter logos\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Mastodon was designed to be resistant to takeovers by billionaires.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: NurPhoto/Rex/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>When Elon Musk bought Twitter nearly six months ago, bringing back white supremacists and booting journalists who had criticized him, many users felt it was the right time to leave the platform.</p> <p>Thousands of tweeters \u2013 myself included \u2013 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/nov/01/mastodon-twitter-elon-musk-takeover\">fled to Mastodon</a>: a scrappy social media project designed from its start in 2016 to be resistant against takeovers by billionaires. Mastodon is decentralized: instead of a single website, it\u2019s a network of thousands of independently run servers \u2013 each with their own moderators and users \u2013 who can interact with each other\u2019s posts, called \u201ctoots\u201d, using an open protocol called ActivityPub. Other social media services can connect to ActivityPub as well, so no one app can monopolize the broader network that Mastodon is part of, called the \u201cfediverse\u201d.</p> <p>All that posed a bit of a learning curve. In addition to learning the new terms, I had to carefully choose a server, which would determine who would be in charge of my data, and what toots I would see most often.</p> <p>Mastodon\u2019s creator, a German programmer named Eugen Rochko, told me at the time that his creation could be \u201cslightly more difficult to grasp\u201d than Twitter. \u201cBut we\u2019re not trying to be an exact copy,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to make something better.\u201d</p> <p>Musk has appeared threatened at times. In December, he banned links to Mastodon on Twitter and suspended users who posted their Mastodon handles, including Mastodon\u2019s official account. Days later, he suddenly reversed course, calling the ban a \u201cmistake\u201d during a Twitter Spaces livestream. \u201cFucking post Mastodon all goddamn day long, I don\u2019t care,\u201d he said.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"bca825eb5ae6c15de929b3b5ac094e24d25e0de0\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/bca825eb5ae6c15de929b3b5ac094e24d25e0de0/0_0_4802_3202/1000.jpg\" alt=\"elon musk with mic\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Elon Musk banned links to Mastodon on Twitter in December but later reversed course.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Mike Blake/Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Nearly half a year later, has Mastodon seized the momentum? Data shows that it saw a huge surge of interest late last year: its monthly active users increased more than eightfold to a high of 2.6 million about a month after Musk\u2019s Twitter purchase. But that number has since dropped to just 1.2 million \u2013 a sign that Mastodon remains far from the levels of hype that would threaten a behemoth like Twitter.</p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s definitely the case that it\u2019s slowed down,\u201d says Nathan Schneider, a University of Colorado Boulder professor who researches collective ownership models and runs a small Mastodon server called <a href=\"https://social.coop\">social.coop</a>. \u201cI think a lot of people came and found it a little hard. Using Mastodon can feel like eating your vegetables.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>Is bigger actually better?</strong></h2> <p>Some of Mastodon\u2019s most passionate users \u2013 who tend to be more tech-savvy than average \u2013 say it\u2019s no problem if the community stays small. Here, things aren\u2019t designed to go viral quickly. There\u2019s no global search or global hashtags. Servers can easily be made private, and admins can block other servers to combat trolls. There\u2019s also a feature to put posts behind content warnings, which users are encouraged to do for sensitive topics.</p> <p>J Logan Carey, an illustrator, has a much smaller following on Mastodon than he did on Twitter, \u201cbut people seem to actually see the things I post on there whereas on Twitter I feel like everything gets algorithmically squashed unless you\u2019re a brand or a celebrity\u201d, he says. Brett Elliff, a systems engineer, says he has been \u201creally loving\u201d Mastodon after using it for a few months: \u201cI only see what I want to follow, and there are actual conversations happening instead of people shouting into the ether.\u201d And Tiffany Li, a technology attorney and law professor, says Mastodon\u2019s small user base \u201cmeans that there are fewer trolls and generally unpleasant people\u201d.</p> <p>Another enthusiastic Mastodon adopter is Jeff Jarvis, a professor at the City University of New York\u2019s Newmark Journalism School. Jarvis arranged for the school to fund a year\u2019s worth of operating costs for <a href=\"https://journa.host/\">journa.host</a>, a Mastodon server home to a few thousand journalists who have been verified by volunteers.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ed8f5589f0479d251d7d69239e5c801067d12f31\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ed8f5589f0479d251d7d69239e5c801067d12f31/0_0_6240_4160/1000.jpg\" alt=\"image of phone with twitter and mastodon apps\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">On Mastodon, \u2018there are actual conversations happening instead of people shouting into the ether\u2019, says a user.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: mundissima/Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cI find the discourse in general to be richer and nicer,\u201d Jarvis says about Mastodon. \u201cI think mass media corrupted the internet with its definitions of scale, that you had to be huge because you had to get a big audience to go to advertisers.\u201d</p> <p>Mastodon\u2019s diminutive size has turned off digital marketers, who have mostly shunned it and other Twitter alternatives as niche <a href=\"https://digiday.com/marketing/bereal-still-has-potential-for-advertisers-but-its-hype-period-is-well-and-truly-over/\">\u201cdistractions\u201d</a> that would be a waste of ad dollars. But it\u2019s also disappointing some activists searching for a way to get their message out without feeding Elon Musk\u2019s machine.</p> <p>In January, Hannah Roditi, the executive director of <a href=\"https://socialmovementtechnologies.org/\">Social Movement Technologies</a>, a non-profit that provides digital tools training for progressive activists, hosted a Mastodon training session. It was the most popular session the group had ever hosted, with more than 600 attendees from over 100 countries.</p> <p>Attendees were tired of Twitter\u2019s hate speech problem and opaque policies: some human rights campaigners had lost their accounts when their governments asked Twitter to take them down. But while Mastodon feels safer, Roditi finds it less useful. \u201cWe want to be able to hijack hashtags and get material in front of people instantly,\u201d she says. \u201cBut a big portion of the world is on Twitter. They\u2019re not on Mastodon. It\u2019s more limiting.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/nov/01/mastodon-twitter-elon-musk-takeover\"> Mastodon gained 70,000 users after Musk\u2019s Twitter takeover. I joined them</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Andrea Learned, the host of a climate podcast, has also found Mastodon too challenging. \u201cI have been frustrated by how non-intuitive it is to make a list and follow other climate media,\u201d she tells me over email. \u201cWe are all waiting for our various communities (in my case #BikeTwitter , urbanists, #PlantBased) to \u2018land\u2019 some one place. So \u2013 we all dabble on several platforms and no big momentum is seen.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>\u2018The homeowners\u2019 association of social media\u2019</strong></h2> <p>Mastodon may be more of a village than a global arena \u2013 but that doesn\u2019t mean it\u2019s always welcoming.</p> <p>Johnathan Flowers, an assistant professor of philosophy at California State University Northridge, started a Mastodon account last November after Musk bought Twitter. But after he posted some observations about the racial politics of the platform, users demanded that Flowers, who is Black, hide those posts behind content warnings.</p> <p>\u201cTheir problem was that I wasn\u2019t following the cultural codes that they felt should prevail in the digital space \u2026 [they felt there should be] a social entitlement to comfort around issues of race and racism,\u201d he says.</p> <p>When he declined to use content warnings, he received a torrent of racist abuse in his inbox. \u201cOn Twitter, it took me a little over two years to say something that got me a bunch of racist trolls in my DMs and mentions,\u201d he says. \u201cOn Mastodon, it took 48 hours.\u201d</p> <p>The scholar was also hassled by users who were unhappy that he was using a tool to cross-post his posts from Twitter to Mastodon. \u201cI\u2019m just like, \u2018What are you guys doing? Why are you being cops?\u2019 There\u2019s no wonder that we started calling Mastodon the homeowners\u2019 association of social media,\u201d he says.</p> <p>In February, Flowers brought up some of his observations to Rochko, Mastodon\u2019s creator. \u201cI am hopeful that it gave him a more nuanced perspective on the platform that he\u2019s running,\u201d Flowers says. \u201cBut as for whether it\u2019ll spark real change, your guess is as good as mine. This isn\u2019t a technical problem that one could fix with new features. This is a cultural problem.\u201d (Rochko did not respond to a request to comment for this story.)</p> <p>These days, Flowers has mostly stopped using Mastodon, not necessarily over the race issue, but because its weak discovery and search features made it too hard to find the people he wanted to follow. \u201cIt took me weeks to find some of my best friends and academic colleagues,\u201d he says. Now he logs in for two main reasons: to check on \u201cthe kind of interestingly diverse Star Trek community there,\u201d and to look at cat pictures.</p> <h2><strong>Mastodon versus the monopolists</strong></h2> <p>Until recently, the Mastodon non-profit had just one full-time employee maintaining the software: Rochko. The organization is funded primarily through donations on <a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/mastodon\">Patreon</a>, which add up to around $32,000 a month \u2013 a drop in the bucket compared with the trillions thrown around by tech giants.</p> <p>It\u2019s also facing new competition from established names: Meta has said it\u2019s working on its own decentralized social network, code-named P92, which will reportedly connect to ActivityPub. And Twitter\u2019s co-founder and former CEO Jack Dorsey is getting ready to unveil Bluesky, a decentralized social media app that will come with a new protocol of its own.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ffe9cfee12c740fba48af568ab757e0ad10555dc\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ffe9cfee12c740fba48af568ab757e0ad10555dc/0_0_4929_3500/1000.jpg\" alt=\"thumbs up sign on meta\u2019s campus\" width=\"1000\" height=\"710\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Meta has said it\u2019s working on its own decentralized social network.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Despite this, Rochko has swatted away Silicon Valley <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/dec/28/mastodon-founder-elon-musk-twitter-takeover\">investment offers</a> worth \u201chundreds of thousands of dollars\u201d, arguing that it would compromise his project. \u201cMastodon will not turn into everything you hate about Twitter,\u201d he said. \u201cThe fact that it can be sold to a controversial billionaire, the fact that it can be shut down, go bankrupt and so on. It\u2019s the difference in paradigms [between the platforms].\u201d</p> <p>Schneider, the collective ownership researcher, says it\u2019s heartening that Rochko refused the money. \u201cIf he took that investment, if it adopted that kind of monopolistic business model that venture capital tends to require, this would cease to be the thing that it\u2019s meant to be.\u201d</p> <p>But it doesn\u2019t change the fact that there aren\u2019t great alternative models. \u201cIt continues to reflect what remains my major anxiety of this whole moment, which is that we as a society are chronically incapable of investing in something better,\u201d he says.</p>", "wordcount": "1530", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:00:36Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T05:22:04Z", "productionOffice": "US", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnxhv", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/81362d0c085d98e5efc0b9aa63623c3a8d0982a5/0_333_6000_3600/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "When Elon Musk bought Twitter nearly six months ago, bringing back white supremacists and booting journalists who had criticized him, many users felt it was the right time to leave the platform. "64396cec8f0885230b2dafed", "bodyHtml": "<p>When Elon Musk bought Twitter nearly six months ago, bringing back white supremacists and booting journalists who had criticized him, many users felt it was the right time to leave the platform.</p> <p>Thousands of tweeters \u2013 myself included \u2013 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/nov/01/mastodon-twitter-elon-musk-takeover\">fled to Mastodon</a>: a scrappy social media project designed from its start in 2016 to be resistant against takeovers by billionaires. Mastodon is decentralized: instead of a single website, it\u2019s a network of thousands of independently run servers \u2013 each with their own moderators and users \u2013 who can interact with each other\u2019s posts, called \u201ctoots\u201d, using an open protocol called ActivityPub. Other social media services can connect to ActivityPub as well, so no one app can monopolize the broader network that Mastodon is part of, called the \u201cfediverse\u201d.</p> <p>All that posed a bit of a learning curve. In addition to learning the new terms, I had to carefully choose a server, which would determine who would be in charge of my data, and what toots I would see most often.</p> <p>Mastodon\u2019s creator, a German programmer named Eugen Rochko, told me at the time that his creation could be \u201cslightly more difficult to grasp\u201d than Twitter. \u201cBut we\u2019re not trying to be an exact copy,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re trying to make something better.\u201d</p> <p>Musk has appeared threatened at times. In December, he banned links to Mastodon on Twitter and suspended users who posted their Mastodon handles, including Mastodon\u2019s official account. Days later, he suddenly reversed course, calling the ban a \u201cmistake\u201d during a Twitter Spaces livestream. \u201cFucking post Mastodon all goddamn day long, I don\u2019t care,\u201d he said.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"bca825eb5ae6c15de929b3b5ac094e24d25e0de0\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/bca825eb5ae6c15de929b3b5ac094e24d25e0de0/0_0_4802_3202/1000.jpg\" alt=\"elon musk with mic\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Elon Musk banned links to Mastodon on Twitter in December but later reversed course.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Mike Blake/Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Nearly half a year later, has Mastodon seized the momentum? Data shows that it saw a huge surge of interest late last year: its monthly active users increased more than eightfold to a high of 2.6 million about a month after Musk\u2019s Twitter purchase. But that number has since dropped to just 1.2 million \u2013 a sign that Mastodon remains far from the levels of hype that would threaten a behemoth like Twitter.</p> <p>\u201cIt\u2019s definitely the case that it\u2019s slowed down,\u201d says Nathan Schneider, a University of Colorado Boulder professor who researches collective ownership models and runs a small Mastodon server called <a href=\"https://social.coop\">social.coop</a>. \u201cI think a lot of people came and found it a little hard. Using Mastodon can feel like eating your vegetables.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>Is bigger actually better?</strong></h2> <p>Some of Mastodon\u2019s most passionate users \u2013 who tend to be more tech-savvy than average \u2013 say it\u2019s no problem if the community stays small. Here, things aren\u2019t designed to go viral quickly. There\u2019s no global search or global hashtags. Servers can easily be made private, and admins can block other servers to combat trolls. There\u2019s also a feature to put posts behind content warnings, which users are encouraged to do for sensitive topics.</p> <p>J Logan Carey, an illustrator, has a much smaller following on Mastodon than he did on Twitter, \u201cbut people seem to actually see the things I post on there whereas on Twitter I feel like everything gets algorithmically squashed unless you\u2019re a brand or a celebrity\u201d, he says. Brett Elliff, a systems engineer, says he has been \u201creally loving\u201d Mastodon after using it for a few months: \u201cI only see what I want to follow, and there are actual conversations happening instead of people shouting into the ether.\u201d And Tiffany Li, a technology attorney and law professor, says Mastodon\u2019s small user base \u201cmeans that there are fewer trolls and generally unpleasant people\u201d.</p> <p>Another enthusiastic Mastodon adopter is Jeff Jarvis, a professor at the City University of New York\u2019s Newmark Journalism School. Jarvis arranged for the school to fund a year\u2019s worth of operating costs for <a href=\"https://journa.host/\">journa.host</a>, a Mastodon server home to a few thousand journalists who have been verified by volunteers.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ed8f5589f0479d251d7d69239e5c801067d12f31\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ed8f5589f0479d251d7d69239e5c801067d12f31/0_0_6240_4160/1000.jpg\" alt=\"image of phone with twitter and mastodon apps\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">On Mastodon, \u2018there are actual conversations happening instead of people shouting into the ether\u2019, says a user.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: mundissima/Alamy</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>\u201cI find the discourse in general to be richer and nicer,\u201d Jarvis says about Mastodon. \u201cI think mass media corrupted the internet with its definitions of scale, that you had to be huge because you had to get a big audience to go to advertisers.\u201d</p> <p>Mastodon\u2019s diminutive size has turned off digital marketers, who have mostly shunned it and other Twitter alternatives as niche <a href=\"https://digiday.com/marketing/bereal-still-has-potential-for-advertisers-but-its-hype-period-is-well-and-truly-over/\">\u201cdistractions\u201d</a> that would be a waste of ad dollars. But it\u2019s also disappointing some activists searching for a way to get their message out without feeding Elon Musk\u2019s machine.</p> <p>In January, Hannah Roditi, the executive director of <a href=\"https://socialmovementtechnologies.org/\">Social Movement Technologies</a>, a non-profit that provides digital tools training for progressive activists, hosted a Mastodon training session. It was the most popular session the group had ever hosted, with more than 600 attendees from over 100 countries.</p> <p>Attendees were tired of Twitter\u2019s hate speech problem and opaque policies: some human rights campaigners had lost their accounts when their governments asked Twitter to take them down. But while Mastodon feels safer, Roditi finds it less useful. \u201cWe want to be able to hijack hashtags and get material in front of people instantly,\u201d she says. \u201cBut a big portion of the world is on Twitter. They\u2019re not on Mastodon. It\u2019s more limiting.\u201d</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/nov/01/mastodon-twitter-elon-musk-takeover\"> Mastodon gained 70,000 users after Musk\u2019s Twitter takeover. I joined them</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Andrea Learned, the host of a climate podcast, has also found Mastodon too challenging. \u201cI have been frustrated by how non-intuitive it is to make a list and follow other climate media,\u201d she tells me over email. \u201cWe are all waiting for our various communities (in my case #BikeTwitter , urbanists, #PlantBased) to \u2018land\u2019 some one place. So \u2013 we all dabble on several platforms and no big momentum is seen.\u201d</p> <h2><strong>\u2018The homeowners\u2019 association of social media\u2019</strong></h2> <p>Mastodon may be more of a village than a global arena \u2013 but that doesn\u2019t mean it\u2019s always welcoming.</p> <p>Johnathan Flowers, an assistant professor of philosophy at California State University Northridge, started a Mastodon account last November after Musk bought Twitter. But after he posted some observations about the racial politics of the platform, users demanded that Flowers, who is Black, hide those posts behind content warnings.</p> <p>\u201cTheir problem was that I wasn\u2019t following the cultural codes that they felt should prevail in the digital space \u2026 [they felt there should be] a social entitlement to comfort around issues of race and racism,\u201d he says.</p> <p>When he declined to use content warnings, he received a torrent of racist abuse in his inbox. \u201cOn Twitter, it took me a little over two years to say something that got me a bunch of racist trolls in my DMs and mentions,\u201d he says. \u201cOn Mastodon, it took 48 hours.\u201d</p> <p>The scholar was also hassled by users who were unhappy that he was using a tool to cross-post his posts from Twitter to Mastodon. \u201cI\u2019m just like, \u2018What are you guys doing? Why are you being cops?\u2019 There\u2019s no wonder that we started calling Mastodon the homeowners\u2019 association of social media,\u201d he says.</p> <p>In February, Flowers brought up some of his observations to Rochko, Mastodon\u2019s creator. \u201cI am hopeful that it gave him a more nuanced perspective on the platform that he\u2019s running,\u201d Flowers says. \u201cBut as for whether it\u2019ll spark real change, your guess is as good as mine. This isn\u2019t a technical problem that one could fix with new features. This is a cultural problem.\u201d (Rochko did not respond to a request to comment for this story.)</p> <p>These days, Flowers has mostly stopped using Mastodon, not necessarily over the race issue, but because its weak discovery and search features made it too hard to find the people he wanted to follow. \u201cIt took me weeks to find some of my best friends and academic colleagues,\u201d he says. Now he logs in for two main reasons: to check on \u201cthe kind of interestingly diverse Star Trek community there,\u201d and to look at cat pictures.</p> <h2><strong>Mastodon versus the monopolists</strong></h2> <p>Until recently, the Mastodon non-profit had just one full-time employee maintaining the software: Rochko. The organization is funded primarily through donations on <a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/mastodon\">Patreon</a>, which add up to around $32,000 a month \u2013 a drop in the bucket compared with the trillions thrown around by tech giants.</p> <p>It\u2019s also facing new competition from established names: Meta has said it\u2019s working on its own decentralized social network, code-named P92, which will reportedly connect to ActivityPub. And Twitter\u2019s co-founder and former CEO Jack Dorsey is getting ready to unveil Bluesky, a decentralized social media app that will come with a new protocol of its own.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"ffe9cfee12c740fba48af568ab757e0ad10555dc\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/ffe9cfee12c740fba48af568ab757e0ad10555dc/0_0_4929_3500/1000.jpg\" alt=\"thumbs up sign on meta\u2019s campus\" width=\"1000\" height=\"710\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Meta has said it\u2019s working on its own decentralized social network.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Despite this, Rochko has swatted away Silicon Valley <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2022/dec/28/mastodon-founder-elon-musk-twitter-takeover\">investment offers</a> worth \u201chundreds of thousands of dollars\u201d, arguing that it would compromise his project. \u201cMastodon will not turn into everything you hate about Twitter,\u201d he said. \u201cThe fact that it can be sold to a controversial billionaire, the fact that it can be shut down, go bankrupt and so on. It\u2019s the difference in paradigms [between the platforms].\u201d</p> <p>Schneider, the collective ownership researcher, says it\u2019s heartening that Rochko refused the money. \u201cIf he took that investment, if it adopted that kind of monopolistic business model that venture capital tends to require, this would cease to be the thing that it\u2019s meant to be.\u201d</p> <p>But it doesn\u2019t change the fact that there aren\u2019t great alternative models. \u201cIt continues to reflect what remains my major anxiety of this whole moment, which is that we as a society are chronically incapable of investing in something better,\u201d he says.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "When Elon Musk bought Twitter nearly six months ago, bringing back white supremacists and booting journalists who had criticized him, many users felt it was the right time to leave the platform. Data shows that it saw a huge surge of interest late last year: its monthly active users increased more than eightfold to a high of 2.6 million about a month after Musk\u2019s Twitter purchase. But that number has since dropped to just 1.2 million \u2013 a sign that Mastodon remains far from the levels of hype that would threaten a behemoth like Twitter.</p> \n<p>\u201cIt\u2019s definitely the case that it\u2019s slowed down,\u201d says Nathan Schneider, a University of Colorado Boulder professor who researches collective ownership models and runs a small Mastodon server called <a href=\"https://social.coop\">social.coop</a>. \u201cI think a lot of people came and found it a little hard. Using Mastodon can feel like eating your vegetables.\u201d</p> \n<h2><strong>Is bigger actually better?</strong></h2> \n<p>Some of Mastodon\u2019s most passionate users \u2013 who tend to be more tech-savvy than average \u2013 say it\u2019s no problem if the community stays small. Here, things aren\u2019t designed to go viral quickly. There\u2019s no global search or global hashtags. Servers can easily be made private, and admins can block other servers to combat trolls. There\u2019s also a feature to put posts behind content warnings, which users are encouraged to do for sensitive topics.</p> \n<p>J Logan Carey, an illustrator, has a much smaller following on Mastodon than he did on Twitter, \u201cbut people seem to actually see the things I post on there whereas on Twitter I feel like everything gets algorithmically squashed unless you\u2019re a brand or a celebrity\u201d, he says. height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018Desert gardens\u2019 featuring cacti and other succulents are being used at top shows.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Biswarup Ganguly/Pacific Press/Rex/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>Wilting flowers, dried-up soil and sweltering tents have become the norm at flower shows in England as the country faces more frequent heatwaves and droughts in summer.</p> <p>Now, \u201cdesert gardens\u201d <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2019/dec/29/james-wong-gardens-keep-cactus-alive-succulent-overwatering\">featuring cacti</a> and other succulents are being used at top shows as horticulturists struggle with a changing climate.</p> <p>This year\u2019s Royal Horticultural Society Hampton Court flower show will feature gardens using creative methods to mitigate against heatwaves.</p> <p>The show, held in July, faced struggles last year with plants coming into bloom too early, wilting and having to be swapped out. An RHS spokesperson said: \u201cWhilst the heat did pose challenges, the designers managed to keep on top of it. The drought-tolerant gardens are a reaction to last year\u2019s heat. Caroline and Peter Clayton, who designed a garden called Nurturing Nature in the City, have used drought-tolerant planting as a means to create more resilient gardens and to reduce the need to water.</p> <p>Last year, show designers had to install a new ventilation system to help cool the tent down, and exhibitors had to set up extra gazebos to keep plants cool before planting them in the gardens, and were watering in the early morning or late evening when it was cooler.</p> <p>As climate breakdown hits the UK, plants that once thrived in a typical garden are struggling, and garden designers have for some time been experimenting with plants from hotter climes. While Mediterranean flowers and shrubs have recently been a popular choice, gardeners are this year taking inspiration from deserts.</p> <p>One new garden, America\u2019s Wild, features plants grown in the arid conditions of parts of the US. It uses dry planting to exhibit interesting drought-tolerant plants suitable for growing in the UK. These include agaves and <em>Dasylirion serratifolium</em>, a spiny Mexican succulent. The desert area of the garden draws on principles for dry terrain known as xeriscaping, using sandy substrate for a free-draining soil, creating conditions ideal for drought-tolerant plants. The garden also features a specimen tree and cooling walls to create shade and protect plants from being scorched.</p> <p>The Claytons\u2019 garden, Nurturing Nature in the City, features drought-tolerant plants such as echinacea, verbena and achillea and will be mulching soil with waste stone to help seal moisture in the soil below. After last year\u2019s drought, many gardeners are expected to showcase creative ways to lock moisture into the soil and store it in the back yard, whether that is in ponds or water butts. It takes inspiration from inner-city green developments along disused urban railways such as the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2014/sep/22/final-stretch-new-york-high-line-complete\">High Line</a> in New York City and Parkland Walk in Highgate, London, with plenty of pollinator-friendly plants.</p> <p>Another garden, The Inghams Working with Nature, demonstrates how to reduce additional watering needs by using water runoff. It is directed into a dry riverbed and then flows into plant-packed swale pits. The garden also features drought-tolerant plants at its highest points, from which water will naturally drain away.</p> <p>Helena Pettit, the RHS director of gardens and shows, said: \u201cClimatic extremes are becoming increasingly common in the UK and our green spaces will need to adapt to weather them. The gardens at RHS Hampton Court provide plenty of inspiration for visitors to try at home to help make their own gardens more resilient.\u201d</p> <p>Climate has become a leading theme at RHS shows, with a deliberately messy \u201crewilding\u201d garden winning the best in show prize at Chelsea flower show last year. The designers were attempting to show how gardens could be left wild for nature, and in future even become a beaver habitat. This year at Chelsea, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/oct/20/unpopular-insects-to-be-stars-of-chelsea-flower-show-royal-entomological-society\">slugs and snails</a> will be the stars of the show as gardeners try to demonstrate how to attract wildlife and demonstrate the benefits of species often considered pests by gardeners.</p> <p>Specialists at the RHS have been receiving more calls from members for advice on climate-resilient planting. Last year, a <a href=\"https://www.rhs.org.uk/press/releases/RHS-survey-shows-garden-favourites-suffered\">survey</a> of more than 8,000 RHS gardeners found that plants were scorched and destroyed in the heatwave, with the worst-affected being hydrangeas, acers and fuchsias.</p> <h2>Drought gardens: best plants for a climate that is heating up</h2> <p>The RHS experts say: \u201cMany drought-tolerant plants have silver or grey-green leaves, their light leaf colour reflecting the harsh rays of the sun. Some have a coating of fine hairs on their leaves or stems, helping to trap moisture around the plant tissues.\u201d</p> <p><strong>Five examples of plants that will thrive in drought conditions:</strong></p> <ol> <li><p>The pretty, pink palm-like shrub <em>Cordyline australis</em> brings some colour while being tolerant to heat.</p></li> <li><p><em>Juniperus </em>conifers are drought-tolerant and many varieties have an attractive gold hue.</p></li> <li><p>The Judas tree, <em>Cercis siliquastrum</em>, has heart-shaped leaves and does not need too much water.</p></li> <li><p>Jasmine plants provide pretty little flowers and a heady scent, and are also able to grow in warm climes.</p></li> <li><p>The <em>Abelia</em> \u00d7 <em>grandiflora </em>is recommended by the RHS as it provides dainty, well-scented flowers over a long period in summer, and tolerates heat well.</p></li> </ol>", "newspaperPageNumber": "3", "wordcount": "817", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:00:36Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T09:30:11Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-18T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nng5q", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/c451eeba484dc2bba91e1d62921c84c5104a41e4/0_200_6000_3600/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Wilting flowers, dried-up soil and sweltering tents have become the norm at flower shows in England as the country faces more frequent heatwaves and droughts in summer. The desert area of the garden draws on principles for dry terrain known as xeriscaping, using sandy substrate for a free-draining soil, creating conditions ideal for drought-tolerant plants. The garden also features a specimen tree and cooling walls to create shade and protect plants from being scorched. The Claytons\u2019 garden, Nurturing Nature in the City, features drought-tolerant plants such as echinacea, verbena and achillea and will be mulching soil with waste stone to help seal moisture in the soil below. After last year\u2019s drought, many gardeners are expected to showcase creative ways to lock moisture into the soil and store it in the back yard, whether that is in ponds or water butts. It takes inspiration from inner-city green developments along disused urban railways such as the High Line in New York City and Parkland Walk in Highgate, London, with plenty of pollinator-friendly plants. Another garden, The Inghams Working with Nature, demonstrates how to reduce additional watering needs by using water runoff. It is directed into a dry riverbed and then flows into plant-packed swale pits. The garden also features drought-tolerant plants at its highest points, from which water will naturally drain away. Helena Pettit, the RHS director of gardens and shows, said: \u201cClimatic extremes are becoming increasingly common in the UK and our green spaces will need to adapt to weather them. The gardens at RHS Hampton Court provide plenty of inspiration for visitors to try at home to help make their own gardens more resilient.\u201d Climate has become a leading theme at RHS shows, with a deliberately messy \u201crewilding\u201d garden winning the best in show prize at Chelsea flower show last year. The designers were attempting to show how gardens could be left wild for nature, and in future even become a beaver habitat. This year at Chelsea, slugs and snails will be the stars of the show as gardeners try to demonstrate how to attract wildlife and demonstrate the benefits of species often considered pests by gardeners. Specialists at the RHS have been receiving more calls from members for advice on climate-resilient planting. Last year, a survey of more than 8,000 RHS gardeners found that plants were scorched and destroyed in the heatwave, with the worst-affected being hydrangeas, acers and fuchsias. Drought gardens: best plants for a climate that is heating up The RHS experts say: \u201cMany drought-tolerant plants have silver or grey-green leaves, their light leaf colour reflecting the harsh rays of the sun. Some have a coating of fine hairs on their leaves or stems, helping to trap moisture around the plant tissues.\u201d Five examples of plants that will thrive in drought conditions: The pretty, pink palm-like shrub Cordyline australis brings some colour while being tolerant to heat. Juniperus conifers are drought-tolerant and many varieties have an attractive gold hue. The Judas tree, Cercis siliquastrum, has heart-shaped leaves and does not need too much water. Jasmine plants provide pretty little flowers and a heady scent, and are also able to grow in warm climes. The Abelia \u00d7 grandiflora is recommended by the RHS as it provides dainty, well-scented flowers over a long period in summer, and tolerates heat well.", "charCount": "5057", href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2019/dec/29/james-wong-gardens-keep-cactus-alive-succulent-overwatering\">featuring cacti</a> and other succulents are being used at top shows as heatwaves.</p> <p>The show, held in July, faced struggles last year with plants coming into bloom too early, wilting and having to be swapped out. An RHS spokesperson said: \u201cWhilst the heat did pose challenges, the designers managed to keep on top of it. The drought-tolerant gardens are a reaction to last year\u2019s heat. Caroline and Peter Clayton, who designed a garden called Nurturing Nature in the City, have used drought-tolerant planting as a means to create more resilient gardens and to reduce the need to water.</p> <p>Last year, show designers had to install a new ventilation system to help cool the tent down, and exhibitors had to set up extra gazebos to keep plants cool before planting them in the gardens, and were watering in the early morning or late evening when it was cooler.</p> <p>As climate breakdown hits the UK, plants that once thrived in a typical garden are struggling, and garden designers have for some time been experimenting with plants from hotter climes. While Mediterranean flowers and shrubs have recently been a popular choice, gardeners are this year taking inspiration from deserts.</p> <p>One new garden, America\u2019s Wild, features plants grown in the arid conditions of parts of the US. It uses dry planting to exhibit interesting drought-tolerant plants suitable for growing in the UK. These include agaves and <em>Dasylirion serratifolium</em>, a spiny Mexican succulent. The desert area of the garden draws on principles for dry terrain known as xeriscaping, using sandy substrate for a free-draining soil, creating conditions ideal for drought-tolerant plants. The garden also features a specimen tree and cooling walls to create shade and protect plants from being scorched.</p> <p>The Claytons\u2019 garden, Nurturing Nature in the City, features drought-tolerant plants such as echinacea, verbena and achillea and will be mulching soil with waste stone to help seal moisture in the soil below. Our best defence? Talk about it", "standfirst": "<p>There has been too little publicity to help people comply. If ministers won\u2019t spread the word, we should do so ourselves</p>", "trailText": "If ministers won\u2019t spread the word, we should do so ourselves, says Guardian columnist Gaby Hinsliff", "byline": "Gaby Hinsliff", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"05f9030b6e6902fec85796d39d79b347d5e8b6f9\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/05f9030b6e6902fec85796d39d79b347d5e8b6f9/184_0_3816_2290/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A leaflet showing that British voters now need photo ID in order to cast their ballot.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A leaflet showing that British voters now need photo ID in order to cast their ballot.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Dinendra Haria/SOPA Images/REX/Shutterstock</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>When the polling card for this May\u2019s local elections arrived, as usual I stuck it on the fridge absent-mindedly without looking. It was only when it fell off the fridge at the weekend that, in picking it up, I noticed the small print about <a href=\"https://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/i-am-a/voter/voter-id?gclsrc=aw.ds\">bringing photo ID to vote</a> for the first time this year.</p> <p>Like countless other married women, I live a double life. I kept my maiden name for work and assorted official purposes, but use my married name for the personal stuff: school runs, doctor\u2019s appointments, taking the dog to the vet. Having two identities feels like a useful marker of where \u201cwork me\u201d clocks off and the private one takes over, but administratively speaking \u2026 well, let\u2019s not mention the time my husband booked a surprise weekend abroad, and I unromantically pointed out en route to Heathrow that my ticket was in the wrong name.</p> <p>My passport and driving licence both belong to work me. Unfortunately, it was private me who filled out the electoral register. According to the Electoral Commission, the fact that my acceptable photo ID is in the wrong name won\u2019t matter just so long as I also bring my wedding certificate to the polling booth, which would be great if I could actually find my wedding certificate. But as things stand, I have until 5pm on Tuesday 25 April to dredge up a passport-style photo and apply for what\u2019s called a <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/apply-for-photo-id-voter-authority-certificate\">voter authority certificate</a> designed for the identity-less, or until 23:59 on Monday 17 April (apologies if you\u2019re reading this in a sweat) to <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/register-to-vote\">change the name under which I\u2019m registered to vote</a>. This is, I should add, only a concern for voters in Great Britain; voter ID is a long-established part of the process in Northern Ireland.</p> <p>Compulsory voter ID isn\u2019t a dealbreaker, of course, for anyone strongly motivated to vote who can either afford to have a passport and driving licence or is confident dealing with officialdom, and is lucky not to live a life so grindingly tough that they just have no bandwidth left for such things. Although even then, it helps to know that voter ID is actually coming in \u2013 surveys suggest that <a href=\"https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/one-four-voters-wrongly-believe-29552560\">a quarter of people don\u2019t know</a> \u2013 and to have the idea that May equals elections engraved on your cold, journalistic heart.</p> <p>But plenty of people don\u2019t fit these neat boxes, which is why organisations including the <a href=\"https://www.electoral-reform.org.uk/campaigns/voter-id/\">Electoral Reform Society</a> and the anti-poverty campaigner the <a href=\"https://www.jrf.org.uk/blog/government-must-not-disenfranchise-low-income-voters-polls\">Joseph Rowntree Foundation</a> warned that voter ID laws passed last year would disfranchise poor and marginalised people and those consumed by the struggle just to get by. Joining those, I suspect, will be some who simply won\u2019t realise they were affected until they\u2019re being politely turned away from polling booths.</p> <p>With the honourable exception of the 60-year-old managing director of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z5D_OKO_sgM\">South Norfolk council</a>, who has gamely produced a rap-style voter ID video so endearingly naff it may well go viral by accident, there has been worryingly little publicity despite this election being a crucial chance to get everyone used to the changes before next year\u2019s general election.</p> <p>In the US, voter ID laws are associated with <a href=\"https://www.brennancenter.org/issues/ensure-every-american-can-vote/vote-suppression\">accusations of voter suppression</a>, or deliberately rigging things to deter young, black, and low-income voters, who are most likely to lean Democrat, from turning out. Some suspect the Tories of something similar here, given that the incidence of electoral fraud is <a href=\"https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/politics/tory-voter-id-checks-slammed-29618622\">so small</a> (one caution for an offence last year, plus one case in which court proceedings have started) as to make this sledgehammer a dangerously crude way to crack a nut.</p> <p>But Britain isn\u2019t the US, and there may be important nuances here. Research commissioned by the government \u2013 which found <a href=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/984918/Photographic_ID_research-_headline_findings_report.pdf\">91% of Britons</a> own approved photo ID that is both still in date and looks recognisably like them \u2013 shows that under-29s are actually the age group most likely to own something suitable, and ethnic minorities are marginally more likely to do so than white Britons.</p> <p>Those at greatest risk of disenfranchisement are, however, disproportionately likely to be unemployed, disabled or lacking educational qualifications, and those who have never voted before. The additional caveat, meanwhile, is that owning a passport or driving licence or over-60s bus pass (the full list of eligible ID is on the back of your polling card) isn\u2019t the same as knowing you\u2019re supposed to bring it with you to the polling booth. Critically, more than a quarter of those without ID said the change would make them less likely to vote.</p> <p>Having watched years of speakers at Conservative party conference fringe meetings waxing indignant about electoral fraud scandals <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-47535867\">in Tower Hamlets</a>, before huffing that a bit of extra paperwork is hardly a big ask in the circumstances, I suspect Tory support for this has less to do with naked skulduggery than with a basic lack of imagination. If everybody you know drives and holidays abroad every year, while having plenty of time and energy left over for tedious admin, you may well wonder what the problem is. But behavioural science and common sense both indicate that if governments really want people to do something, they should make it easier, not harder.</p> <p>To introduce a new hurdle, like voter ID, is effectively to treat those who will lose out as acceptable collateral damage. This is precisely the sort of general political ethos, obviously, that many Guardian readers will want to vote against. But until then, if you know anyone you think may be at risk of missing out, from octogenarians who haven\u2019t been abroad in years to disorganised 18-year-olds and anyone in between, then nudge them. You may be the only person who does.</p> <p>\u2022 Gaby Hinsliff is a Guardian columnist</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "3", "wordcount": "950", "commentCloseDate": "2023-04-18T15:15:00Z", "commentable": "true", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:00:35Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T15:00:21Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-18T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnhda", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/05f9030b6e6902fec85796d39d79b347d5e8b6f9/184_0_3816_2290/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "When the polling card for this May\u2019s local elections arrived, as usual I stuck it on the fridge absent-mindedly without looking. It was only when it fell off the fridge at the weekend that, in picking it up, I noticed the small print about <a href=\"https://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/i-am-a/voter/voter-id?gclsrc=aw.ds\">bringing photo ID to vote</a> for the first time this year.</p> <p>Like countless other married women, I live a double life. I kept my maiden name for work and assorted official purposes, but use my married name for the personal stuff: school runs, doctor\u2019s appointments, taking the dog to the vet. Having two identities feels like a useful marker of where \u201cwork me\u201d clocks off and the private one takes over, but administratively speaking \u2026 well, let\u2019s not mention the time my husband booked a surprise weekend abroad, and I unromantically pointed out en route to Heathrow that my ticket was in the wrong name.</p> <p>My passport and driving licence both belong to work me. Unfortunately, it was private me who filled out the electoral register. According to the Electoral Commission, the fact that my acceptable photo ID is in the wrong name won\u2019t matter just so long as I also bring my wedding certificate to the polling booth, which would be great if I could actually find my wedding certificate. But as things stand, I have until 5pm on Tuesday 25 April to dredge up a passport-style photo and apply for what\u2019s called a <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/apply-for-photo-id-voter-authority-certificate\">voter authority certificate</a> designed for the identity-less, or until 23:59 on Monday 17 April (apologies if you\u2019re reading this in a sweat) to <a href=\"https://www.gov.uk/register-to-vote\">change the name under which I\u2019m registered to vote</a>. This is, I should add, only a concern for voters in Great Britain; voter ID is a long-established part of the process in Northern Ireland.</p> <p>Compulsory voter ID isn\u2019t a dealbreaker, of course, for anyone strongly motivated to vote who can either afford to have a passport and driving licence or is confident dealing with officialdom, and is lucky not to live a life so grindingly tough that they just have no bandwidth left for such things. Joining those, I suspect, will be some who simply won\u2019t realise they were affected until they\u2019re being politely turned away from polling booths.</p> <p>With the honourable exception of the 60-year-old managing director of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z5D_OKO_sgM\">South Norfolk council</a>, who has gamely produced a rap-style voter ID video so endearingly naff it may well go viral by accident, there has been worryingly little publicity despite this election being a crucial chance to get everyone used to the changes before next year\u2019s general election.</p> <p>In the US, voter ID laws are associated with <a href=\"https://www.brennancenter.org/issues/ensure-every-american-can-vote/vote-suppression\">accusations of voter suppression</a>, or deliberately rigging things to deter young, black, and low-income voters, who are most likely to lean Democrat, from turning out. Research commissioned by the government \u2013 which found <a href=\"https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/984918/Photographic_ID_research-_headline_findings_report.pdf\">91% of Britons</a> own approved photo ID that is both still in date and looks recognisably like them \u2013 shows that under-29s are actually the age group most likely to own something suitable, and ethnic minorities are marginally more likely to do so than white Britons.</p> <p>Those at greatest risk of disenfranchisement are, however, disproportionately likely to be unemployed, disabled or lacking educational qualifications, and those who have never voted before. The additional caveat, meanwhile, is that owning a passport or driving licence or over-60s bus pass (the full list of eligible ID is on the back of your polling card) isn\u2019t the same as knowing you\u2019re supposed to bring it with you to the polling booth. Critically, more than a quarter of those without ID said the change would make them less likely to vote.</p> <p>Having watched years of speakers at Conservative party conference fringe meetings waxing indignant about electoral fraud scandals <a href=\"https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-47535867\">in Tower Hamlets</a>, before huffing that a bit of extra paperwork is hardly a big ask in the circumstances, I suspect Tory support for this has less to do with naked skulduggery than with a basic lack of imagination. If everybody you know drives and holidays abroad every year, while having plenty of time and energy left over for tedious admin, you may well wonder what the problem is. But behavioural science and common sense both indicate that if governments really want people to do something, they should make it easier, not harder.</p> <p>To introduce a new hurdle, like voter ID, is effectively to treat those who will lose out as acceptable collateral damage. This is precisely the sort of general political ethos, obviously, that many Guardian readers will want to vote against. But until then, if you know anyone you think may be at risk of missing out, from octogenarians who haven\u2019t been abroad in years to disorganised 18-year-olds and anyone in between, then nudge them. You may be the only person who does.</p> <p>\u2022 Gaby Hinsliff is a Guardian columnist</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "When the polling card for this May\u2019s local elections arrived, as usual I stuck it on the fridge absent-mindedly without looking. It was only when it fell off the fridge at the weekend that, in picking it up, I noticed the small print about bringing photo ID to vote for the first time this year. Like countless other married women, I live a double life. I kept my maiden name for work and assorted official purposes, but use my married name for the personal stuff: school runs, doctor\u2019s appointments, taking the dog to the vet. Having two identities feels like a useful marker of where \u201cwork me\u201d clocks off and the private one takes over, but administratively speaking \u2026 well, let\u2019s not mention the time my husband booked a surprise weekend abroad, and I unromantically pointed out en route to Heathrow that my ticket was in the wrong name. My passport and driving licence both belong to work me. Unfortunately, it was private me who filled out the electoral register. According to the Electoral Commission, the fact that my acceptable photo ID is in the wrong name won\u2019t matter just so long as I also bring my wedding certificate to the polling booth, which would be great if I could actually find my wedding certificate. But as things stand, I have until 5pm on Tuesday 25 April to dredge up a passport-style photo and apply for what\u2019s called a voter authority certificate designed for the identity-less, or until 23:59 on Monday 17 April (apologies if you\u2019re reading this in a sweat) to change the name under which I\u2019m registered to vote. This is, I should add, only a concern for voters in Great Britain; voter ID is a long-established part of the process in Northern Ireland. Compulsory voter ID isn\u2019t a dealbreaker, of course, for anyone strongly motivated to vote who can either afford to have a passport and driving licence or is confident dealing with officialdom, and is lucky not to live a life so grindingly tough that they just have no bandwidth left for such things. Although even then, it helps to know that voter ID is actually coming in \u2013 surveys suggest that a quarter of people don\u2019t know \u2013 and to have the idea that May equals elections engraved on your cold, journalistic heart. But plenty of people don\u2019t fit these neat boxes, which is why organisations including the Electoral Reform Society and the anti-poverty campaigner the Joseph Rowntree Foundation warned that voter ID laws passed last year would disfranchise poor and marginalised people and those consumed by the struggle just to get by. Joining those, I suspect, will be some who simply won\u2019t realise they were affected until they\u2019re being politely turned away from polling booths. With the honourable exception of the 60-year-old managing director of South Norfolk council, who has gamely produced a rap-style voter ID video so endearingly naff it may well go viral by accident, there has been worryingly little publicity despite this election being a crucial chance to get everyone used to the changes before next year\u2019s general election. In the US, voter ID laws are associated with accusations of voter suppression, or deliberately rigging things to deter young, black, and low-income voters, who are most likely to lean Democrat, from turning out. Some suspect the Tories of something similar here, given that the incidence of electoral fraud is so small (one caution for an offence last year, plus one case in which court proceedings have started) as to make this sledgehammer a dangerously crude way to crack a nut. But Britain isn\u2019t the US, and there may be important nuances here. Research commissioned by the government \u2013 which found 91% of Britons own approved photo ID that is both still in date and looks recognisably like them \u2013 shows that under-29s are actually the age group most likely to own something suitable, and ethnic minorities are marginally more likely to do so than white Britons. Those at greatest risk of disenfranchisement are, however, disproportionately likely to be unemployed, disabled or lacking educational qualifications, and those who have never voted before. The additional caveat, meanwhile, is that owning a passport or driving licence or over-60s bus pass (the full list of eligible ID is on the back of your polling card) isn\u2019t the same as knowing you\u2019re supposed to bring it with you to the polling booth. Critically, more than a quarter of those without ID said the change would make them less likely to vote. Having watched years of speakers at Conservative party conference fringe meetings waxing indignant about electoral fraud scandals in Tower Hamlets, before huffing that a bit of extra paperwork is hardly a big ask in the circumstances, I suspect Tory support for this has less to do with naked skulduggery than with a basic lack of imagination. If everybody you know drives and holidays abroad every year, while having plenty of time and energy left over for tedious admin, you may well wonder what the problem is. But behavioural science and common sense both indicate that if governments really want people to do something, they should make it easier, not harder. To introduce a new hurdle, like voter ID, is effectively to treat those who will lose out as acceptable collateral damage. This is precisely the sort of general political ethos, obviously, that many Guardian readers will want to vote against. But until then, if you know anyone you think may be at risk of missing out, from octogenarians who haven\u2019t been abroad in years to disorganised 18-year-olds and anyone in between, then nudge them.
