But on FoodTok, the recipes are more bafflingly repulsive than ever </p>", "trailText": "Social media has a long history of gross-out content. But on FoodTok, the recipes are more bafflingly repulsive than ever", "byline": "Emma Beddington", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image element--showcase\" data-media-id=\"71119af54dd780c4ff7542279f2e1d6665234bfc\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/71119af54dd780c4ff7542279f2e1d6665234bfc/31_0_2064_1240/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Enjoy your meal \u2026 frankfurters in pickle juice jelly.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Enjoy your meal \u2026 frankfurters in pickle juice jelly.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Composite: @myjanebrain</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>I have just ironed my husband a toasted sandwich like some kind of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2020/jan/27/tradwives-new-trend-submissive-women-dark-heart-history\">tradwife</a> and to be honest, I\u2019m disappointed with his reaction. Admittedly, there were a few issues. The steam didn\u2019t help, plus I wrapped it in too much tinfoil, so the heat couldn\u2019t penetrate. The main problem, though, was that holding an iron meant I automatically started ironing the package, pressing hard and going to and fro industriously. The result is flat, very flat. \u201cWe have a sandwich toaster,\u201d my husband points out, holding the crepe-thin delicacy between finger and thumb. He should be thrilled: this is the closest I\u2019ve come to cooking for him in months. He tries it, reluctantly. \u201cIt\u2019s very soft. Did you put mustard in it?\u201d</p> <p>\u201cI thought it would help,\u201d I say.</p> <p>\u201cIt doesn\u2019t.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"5aed856f9a8245373927c3fb0c839b72846e5f97\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5aed856f9a8245373927c3fb0c839b72846e5f97/0_268_8021_4815/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Deranged \u2026 Emma irons her toastie.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Deranged \u2026 Emma irons her toastie.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Christopher Thomond/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Unless you are a particularly online person, you are probably asking why, at this point. It\u2019s a question I have asked myself repeatedly, in a rising pitch of incredulity and distress as I dived deep into TikTok food \u2013 or FoodTok, if you will. Because that is where the ironed toastie comes from: it\u2019s part of a new generation of TikTok recipe hacks that embody a provocative, frankly deranged \u201cwhy not?\u201d philosophy. We\u2019ve come a long, wrong way since <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@feelgoodfoodie/video/6922938178559069446?lang=en\">2021\u2019s viral feta pasta</a>. Now, in addition to ironed toasties, you can enjoy a beatifically smiling blonde <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@foodsfuns3/video/7209089125515939114\">putting dried pasta in a blender</a> to create an approximation of flour, then adding an egg to create a sort of dough. She then fashions lumpy, fat noodles, which she boils, tops with tomato sauce and declares \u201cexactly like fresh pasta\u201d. Comments include the likes of \u201cYOU VIOLATED THE PASTA\u201d, \u201cMa\u2019am, blink twice if someone is holding you hostage\u201d and many irate Italians.</p> <p>But that is not even as bad as the unholy tacos made by <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@myjanebrain/video/7180875279290649861\">boiling beef, eggs and cheese in a bag of Doritos</a>. There\u2019s a whole genre of sponsored-by-diabetes content, where beautiful, young, slim women combine terrifying quantities of marshmallows, sweets, chocolate, butter, cereal, preprepared cookie dough and the like into \u201cincredible\u201d desserts that should be illegal. Many videos are titled: \u201cWhy am I just finding out about \u2026\u201d to which the answer is surely: \u201cBecause it should be on trial at The Hague.\u201d You can watch people <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@elis_kitchen/video/6919198339904949509?lang=fr\">boil up crisps to make mashed potato</a>, or dump uncooked dried pasta in the oven covered in a house-brick sized portion of cream cheese and a jar of sauce. <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@myjanebrain/video/7120382043669810438\">Dry packet ramen oven-baked in tomato sauce and cheese</a> is called \u201cpizza\u201d (I worry for Italy\u2019s collective blood pressure). How about marinading chicken in the sink, or massaging mountains of mac and cheese on a worktop? \u201cEverybody\u2019s so creative!\u201d TikToker @Tanaradoublechocolate, who seeks out culinary atrocities to comment upon, says.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"560c02348970336518d17b04b7acfccb87306b03\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/560c02348970336518d17b04b7acfccb87306b03/52_23_667_631/500.jpg\" alt=\"Unholy \u2026 Doritos tacos.\" width=\"500\" height=\"473\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Unholy \u2026 Doritos tacos.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: @myjanebrain</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At the risk of sounding like Grampa Simpson yelling at clouds \u2013 which is exactly how I feel exploring FoodTok \u2013 what is going on? \u201cThere\u2019s a long and storied history of gross-out food on social media,\u201d says <a href=\"https://www.stokel-walker.com/\">Chris Stokel-Walker</a>, social media expert and the author of TikTok Boom. Twisted, the social media food brand that just announced a collaboration with Iceland, started out in 2016 and dared us to make the likes of <a href=\"https://ffwd.medium.com/the-company-behind-that-crazy-bbq-chicken-recipe-video-would-like-to-clarify-a-few-things-32bd11dcba24\">deep-fried barbecue chicken-stuffed pizzadilla</a>. Now, says Stokel-Walker, \u201cIt\u2019s been supercharged by the arrival of TikTok.\u201d The app is designed and engineered to \u201ccapture people\u2019s attention as they are scrolling through that endless feed of content\u201d and one good way to do it is precisely \u201cthe outlandish, the gross-out\u201d. It is a notion echoed by <a href=\"https://jonahberger.com/\">Jonah Berger</a>, professor at the Wharton school in Pennsylvania and bestselling author of Contagious, a study of social transmission and virality, who notes that these videos combine surprise and often disgust. \u201cThe more surprising something is, the more likely we are to share it with others. And disgust is a high arousal emotion that also causes us to pass things on.\u201d</p> <p>So is this content engineered to provoke? Some of it, definitely. \u201cI never work to appear genuine,\u201d says Eli Betchik of <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@elis_kitchen?lang=fr\">@elis_kitchen</a>, the self-proclaimed \u201cmost evil chef on TikTok\u201d. \u201cIf anyone asks, I say: \u2018Yeah, I do this for attention.\u2019 I think it\u2019s pretty obvious I do.\u201d It is a mark of Betchik\u2019s evil genius that every video of theirs makes me shout \u201cNo!\u201d in genuine anger at some point. Betchik was behind the much-reviled potato crisp mash, and a horrifying sandwich made of blended peas, pineapple, cheese and nuts, with the bread coated with mayo, then fried, among other outrages.</p> <p>Betchik is a <a href=\"https://www.betchik.com/\">fine art jeweller</a>, who started their channel after discovering TikTok at jewellery school. \u201cI thought, I already love experimenting with food and trying new things \u2013 I could probably take that a few steps further and use it for some good old-fashioned shock-value entertainment.\u201d Their first video was fried mayonnaise. I make a strangled noise hearing this. \u201cYeah, it was horrible,\u201d confirms Betchik. Another early favourite was meatballs boiled in lime juice \u201cuntil the juice was a thick syrup. I\u2019m salivating because I can still taste the sourness. It was the most violent flavour I\u2019ve ever had.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"7b83a7936e8ebf4bcc6df3fe2a34933eb8e1b240\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7b83a7936e8ebf4bcc6df3fe2a34933eb8e1b240/23_156_722_940/384.jpg\" alt=\"Evil \u2026 @elis_kitchen\u2019s pea, pineapple, nuts and cheese sandwich fried in mayonnaise.\" width=\"384\" height=\"500\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Evil \u2026 @elis_kitchen\u2019s pea, pineapple, nuts and cheese sandwich fried in mayonnaise.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: @elis_kitchen/Tik Tok</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Outrage is the point, and, Betchik says, people enjoy feeling it. \u201cObviously, what I\u2019m doing is to gross people out, but people keep coming back \u2013 they wouldn\u2019t keep coming back if they didn\u2019t get something out of it. I find that sometimes people get happy when they\u2019re upset in the right way.\u201d On their jewellery TikTok account <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@eli_metal?lang=en\">@eli_metal</a>, Betchik says, a mean comment would take days to digest, but with the food, it\u2019s a mark of success. The one comment they won\u2019t accept is that these horrendous creations are wasteful: impressively, worryingly omnivorous, Betchik finishes almost everything. In addition, \u201cI try to use foods that are close to going bad or things that have been donated to me. And if I can\u2019t eat it, I compost all the scraps.\u201d It\u2019s not clear if this level of diligence is common practice among the creators, but it feels doubtful.</p> <p>Mean commenters on the <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@myjanebrain?lang=en\">@myjanebrain</a> TikTok account include a certain Gordon Ramsay, who angrily described a chicken stuffed in a pumpkin, garnished with cinnamon sticks and many onions as \u201c<a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@gordonramsayofficial/video/7159989070607748357?lang=en\">Halloween salmonella right there</a>.\u201d \u201cIt was pretty awesome,\u201d says Jane, a preternaturally cheery 27-year-old Canadian and full-time content creator who prefers not to give her surname, perhaps for fear of reprisals from Italians angered by her ramen \u201cpizza\u201d. \u201cBut I know the chicken was fully cooked. It was moist, it had great flavour.\u201d</p> <p>Jane ended up in the realm of what is sometimes called \u201crage-bait\u201d cooking accidentally. Her early videos, she says, were straight instructional content, but she pivoted when her fried chicken recipe went viral. \u201cIt got 31m views, 3,000 comments,\u201d says Jane \u2013 this is, of course, highly populated TikTok territory, the hashtag #FoodTikTok had accumulated 112bn views by the end of 2022, for example. \u201cI thought it would be positive but it was more like: \u2018You\u2019re the worst chef I\u2019ve ever seen.\u2019 So I realised that I would have no idea what people were going to think of my videos.\u201d</p> <p>She started focusing on finding the \u201ccraziest combinations\u201d, including one titled \u201cI learned this hotdog trick in England\u201d, in which she makes jelly from pickle juice, adds frankfurters and eats it in a bread bun. \u201cThat is absolutely not English,\u201d I challenge her hotly, TikTok commenter style. \u201cI can\u2019t remember; it was from some sort of British something,\u201d she says. \u201cI was going to ask you why you make pickle juice jelly!\u201d What makes people angriest, though, she says, is her cooking techniques. \u201cAs soon as you cook for the internet you open yourself up to all the critics who are so specific in the way they cook.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"c681fee56db350006914e45c1dfc969e70f6ff71\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/c681fee56db350006914e45c1dfc969e70f6ff71/0_0_2006_1658/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Ramsay baiting \u2026 @myjanebrain makes chicken in a pumpkin.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"827\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Ramsay baiting \u2026 @myjanebrain makes chicken in a pumpkin.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Amyjanebrain, @gordonramsayofficial/Tik Tok</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Both Jane and Eli are clear that their content is knowingly provocative rather than instructional, whether viewers understand that or not. \u201cA lot of people take this content at face value when you have to remember we\u2019re through the looking-glass on social media, where these things are being deliberately gamed for the benefit of those that create it,\u201d says Stokel-Walker. All attention is good attention, since views and shares \u2013 including the genre of angry or incredulous \u201cduet\u201d videos where other creators (including Ramsay) comment on their depravity \u2013 are the point. That\u2019s how you make money after all: successful TikTokers can become part of the app\u2019s creator fund and get paid \u2013 admittedly pennies \u2013 per view. Stokel-Walker says that success can allow creators to pivot to the kind of genuinely lucrative mainstream <a href=\"https://retailtimes.co.uk/twisted-announces-a-new-frozen-food-collaboration-with-iceland-designed-to-make-eating-as-fun-and-social-as-possible/\">collaborations that Twisted has managed</a>.</p> <p>There is another possibly upsetting angle: fetish. \u201cVideos where they point a lot and touch things and make super-repulsive stuff are apparently fetish,\u201d a baker friend tells me airily, when I inquire if she uses TikTok recipes. It turns out there\u2019s a fairly widespread suspicion this is a thing. The messier foods could fulfil a \u201csploshing\u201d fetish: <a href=\"https://www.insidehook.com/article/internet/gross-viral-food-hacks-rick-lax-facebook-sploshing-fetish\">getting sexual gratification from food mess</a>. \u201cI\u2019ve seen this aired,\u201d says Stokel-Walker. \u201cCertainly, it appeals to your senses. It\u2019s like a slow-motion car crash in food form, where you\u2019re like, how more disgusting can this get?\u201d TikTok user <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@lenarae.lh?lang=en\">@lenarae.lh</a> analyses food videos and pronounces them fetish or non-fetish on the basis of how the women \u2013 it is almost always women \u2013 use their hands, splash or squirt stuff suggestively or massage phallic things. A friend also directs me to the work of a creator called <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@cedriklorenzen?lang=en\">@cedriklorenzen</a> who specialises in whacking pieces of raw meat, dribbling, drizzling and taking his top off. It\u2019s a better appetite suppressant than Ozempic: after watching, I never want to eat, have sex, or indeed see anything again.</p> <p>There is actually plenty of good, normal food on TikTok. Asking around, people mention recipes for homemade crispy chilli sauce, broccoli pasta, sesame dip and various noodle dishes they\u2019ve tried, then added to their repertoire. Seema Pankhania, a 25-year-old former chef de partie at Gordon Ramsay\u2019s Lucky Cat who posts as <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@seemagetsbaked?lang=en\">@seemagetsbaked</a>, has 1.3 million followers for her eminently achievable, delicious-looking recipes. They are pleasingly lo-fi, especially her pyjama recipes for hungover, no bones days and ultra simple versions of Indian classics \u2013 her butter chicken has 1.7m likes (she also recommends her \u201c<a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@seemagetsbaked/video/7165524963041086725\">super simple creamy chicken curry</a>\u201d. But even Pankhania, a proper cook, is aware it is all grist to the gnat\u2019s attention span TikTok mill. She aims to keep videos under a minute long (\u201cthe shorter the better; people are going to get bored\u201d) and has no illusions that much of the food content is only meant to be consumed with the eyes. \u201cThere\u2019s a whole other field of cooking on TikTok which is indulgent,\u201d she says, giving the example of elaborate lasagnes. \u201cNobody is going to make it, but it\u2019s very nice and satisfying to watch.\u201d Clearly that goes for the bizarre and the gross-out stuff too in some more depraved way. \u201cAt the end of the day, social media is entertainment, right?\u201d says Pankhania. \u201cMost of it is just for entertainment and people aren\u2019t actually going to be cooking a lot of it.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"867333ec298a8553dfc53cd7020d4c76450aa647\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/867333ec298a8553dfc53cd7020d4c76450aa647/0_273_8192_4918/1000.jpg\" alt=\"\u2018Not terrible, but not good either\u2019 \u2026 dried \u2018fresh\u2019 pasta.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018Not terrible, but not good either\u2019 \u2026 dried \u2018fresh\u2019 pasta.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Christopher Thomond/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Given much of food TikTok isn\u2019t meant to be cooked, or is intentionally tongue in cheek, I\u2019m sure I\u2019m missing the point entirely as I cram half a packet of spaghetti into my blender. A flimsy thing, it protests loudly with an ominous smell of burning rubber. I whiz up vermicelli instead, dump the \u201cflour\u201d on the worktop and add an egg, making a claggy mess. I have to add normal flour \u2013 surely invalidating the whole madness \u2013 to form a dough ball capable of being rolled out. The resultant approximate noodles are dumped in boiling water. I take them out based on vibes alone \u2013 TikTok recipes are wildly unspecific \u2013 then my family gather to taste and criticise. My husband \u2013 whose former student staple of peas and camembert prepared in a kettle would be a runaway TikTok hit \u2013 declares it raw. \u201cIt\u2019s not terrible,\u201d one son ventures. \u201cIt\u2019s not good either,\u201d says the other, correctly.</p> <p>I dare not attempt anything of Betchik\u2019s, and Jane recommends her own recipe for cinnamon buns baked in cream and coffee, topped with sugar, butter and flattened toffees \u2013 but I am 48 and my organs will explode if I eat that. My wimp\u2019s version \u2013 a vegan bun sliced and covered in oat cream, sugar and cinnamon \u2013 comes out of the oven ominously black; my just deserts for messing with the recipe, I suppose. I eat it all anyway \u2013 it\u2019s a cinnamon bun and cream, what\u2019s not to like? \u2013 then, exhausted and hyperglycaemic, I close TikTok, hopefully for good. Everybody\u2019s so creative! I wish they weren\u2019t.</p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "6", "wordcount": "2116", "commentCloseDate": "2023-04-21T05:00:35Z", "commentable": "true", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T05:00:35Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T07:31:06Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-18T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmg77", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/71119af54dd780c4ff7542279f2e1d6665234bfc/31_0_2064_1240/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "I have just ironed my husband a toasted sandwich like some kind of tradwife and to be honest, I\u2019m disappointed with his reaction. Admittedly, there were a few issues. The steam didn\u2019t help, plus I wrapped it in too much tinfoil, so the heat couldn\u2019t penetrate. The main problem, though, was that holding an iron meant I automatically started ironing the package, pressing hard and going to and fro industriously. The result is flat, very flat. \u201cWe have a sandwich toaster,\u201d my husband points out, holding the crepe-thin delicacy between finger and thumb. He should be thrilled: this is the closest I\u2019ve come to cooking for him in months. He tries it, reluctantly. \u201cIt\u2019s very soft. Did you put mustard in it?\u201d \u201cI thought it would help,\u201d I say. \u201cIt doesn\u2019t.\u201d Unless you are a particularly online person, you are probably asking why, at this point. It\u2019s a question I have asked myself repeatedly, in a rising pitch of incredulity and distress as I dived deep into TikTok food \u2013 or FoodTok, if you will. Because that is where the ironed toastie comes from: it\u2019s part of a new generation of TikTok recipe hacks that embody a provocative, frankly deranged \u201cwhy not?\u201d philosophy. We\u2019ve come a long, wrong way since 2021\u2019s viral feta pasta. Now, in addition to ironed toasties, you can enjoy a beatifically smiling blonde putting dried pasta in a blender to create an approximation of flour, then adding an egg to create a sort of dough. She then fashions lumpy, fat noodles, which she boils, tops with tomato sauce and declares \u201cexactly like fresh pasta\u201d. Comments include the likes of \u201cYOU VIOLATED THE PASTA\u201d, \u201cMa\u2019am, blink twice if someone is holding you hostage\u201d and many irate Italians. But that is not even as bad as the unholy tacos made by boiling beef, eggs and cheese in a bag of Doritos. There\u2019s a whole genre of sponsored-by-diabetes content, where beautiful, young, slim women combine terrifying quantities of marshmallows, sweets, chocolate, butter, cereal, preprepared cookie dough and the like into \u201cincredible\u201d desserts that should be illegal. Many videos are titled: \u201cWhy am I just finding out about \u2026\u201d to which the answer is surely: \u201cBecause it should be on trial at The Hague.\u201d You can watch people boil up crisps to make mashed potato, or dump uncooked dried pasta in the oven covered in a house-brick sized portion of cream cheese and a jar of sauce. Dry packet ramen oven-baked in tomato sauce and cheese is called \u201cpizza\u201d (I worry for Italy\u2019s collective blood pressure). How about marinading chicken in the sink, or massaging mountains of mac and cheese on a worktop? \u201cEverybody\u2019s so creative!\u201d TikToker @Tanaradoublechocolate, who seeks out culinary atrocities to comment upon, says. At the risk of sounding like Grampa Simpson yelling at clouds \u2013 which is exactly how I feel exploring FoodTok \u2013 what is going on? \u201cThere\u2019s a long and storied history of gross-out food on social media,\u201d says Chris Stokel-Walker, social media expert and the author of TikTok Boom. Twisted, the social media food brand that just announced a collaboration with Iceland, started out in 2016 and dared us to make the likes of deep-fried barbecue chicken-stuffed pizzadilla. Now, says Stokel-Walker, \u201cIt\u2019s been supercharged by the arrival of TikTok.\u201d The app is designed and engineered to \u201ccapture people\u2019s attention as they are scrolling through that endless feed of content\u201d and one good way to do it is precisely \u201cthe outlandish, the gross-out\u201d. It is a notion echoed by Jonah Berger, professor at the Wharton school in Pennsylvania and bestselling author of Contagious, a study of social transmission and virality, who notes that these videos combine surprise and often disgust. \u201cThe more surprising something is, the more likely we are to share it with others. And disgust is a high arousal emotion that also causes us to pass things on.\u201d So is this content engineered to provoke? Some of it, definitely. \u201cI never work to appear genuine,\u201d says Eli Betchik of @elis_kitchen, the self-proclaimed \u201cmost evil chef on TikTok\u201d. \u201cIf anyone asks, I say: \u2018Yeah, I do this for attention.\u2019 I think it\u2019s pretty obvious I do.\u201d It is a mark of Betchik\u2019s evil genius that every video of theirs makes me shout \u201cNo!\u201d in genuine anger at some point. Betchik was behind the much-reviled potato crisp mash, and a horrifying sandwich made of blended peas, pineapple, cheese and nuts, with the bread coated with mayo, then fried, among other outrages. Betchik is a fine art jeweller, who started their channel after discovering TikTok at jewellery school. \u201cI thought, I already love experimenting with food and trying new things \u2013 I could probably take that a few steps further and use it for some good old-fashioned shock-value entertainment.\u201d Their first video was fried mayonnaise. I make a strangled noise hearing this. \u201cYeah, it was horrible,\u201d confirms Betchik. Another early favourite was meatballs boiled in lime juice \u201cuntil the juice was a thick syrup. I\u2019m salivating because I can still taste the sourness. It was the most violent flavour I\u2019ve ever had.\u201d Outrage is the point, and, Betchik says, people enjoy feeling it. \u201cObviously, what I\u2019m doing is to gross people out, but people keep coming back \u2013 they wouldn\u2019t keep coming back if they didn\u2019t get something out of it. I find that sometimes people get happy when they\u2019re upset in the right way.\u201d On their jewellery TikTok account @eli_metal, Betchik says, a mean comment would take days to digest, but with the food, it\u2019s a mark of success. The one comment they won\u2019t accept is that these horrendous creations are wasteful: impressively, worryingly omnivorous, Betchik finishes almost everything. In addition, \u201cI try to use foods that are close to going bad or things that have been donated to me. And if I can\u2019t eat it, I compost all the scraps.\u201d It\u2019s not clear if this level of diligence is common practice among the creators, but it feels doubtful. Mean commenters on the @myjanebrain TikTok account include a certain Gordon Ramsay, who angrily described a chicken stuffed in a pumpkin, garnished with cinnamon sticks and many onions as \u201cHalloween salmonella right there.\u201d \u201cIt was pretty awesome,\u201d says Jane, a preternaturally cheery 27-year-old Canadian and full-time content creator who prefers not to give her surname, perhaps for fear of reprisals from Italians angered by her ramen \u201cpizza\u201d. \u201cBut I know the chicken was fully cooked. It was moist, it had great flavour.\u201d Jane ended up in the realm of what is sometimes called \u201crage-bait\u201d cooking accidentally. Her early videos, she says, were straight instructional content, but she pivoted when her fried chicken recipe went viral. \u201cIt got 31m views, 3,000 comments,\u201d says Jane \u2013 this is, of course, highly populated TikTok territory, the hashtag #FoodTikTok had accumulated 112bn views by the end of 2022, for example. \u201cI thought it would be positive but it was more like: \u2018You\u2019re the worst chef I\u2019ve ever seen.\u2019 So I realised that I would have no idea what people were going to think of my videos.\u201d She started focusing on finding the \u201ccraziest combinations\u201d, including one titled \u201cI learned this hotdog trick in England\u201d, in which she makes jelly from pickle juice, adds frankfurters and eats it in a bread bun. \u201cThat is absolutely not English,\u201d I challenge her hotly, TikTok commenter style. \u201cI can\u2019t remember; it was from some sort of British something,\u201d she says. \u201cI was going to ask you why you make pickle juice jelly!\u201d What makes people angriest, though, she says, is her cooking techniques. \u201cAs soon as you cook for the internet you open yourself up to all the critics who are so specific in the way they cook.\u201d Both Jane and Eli are clear that their content is knowingly provocative rather than instructional, whether viewers understand that or not. \u201cA lot of people take this content at face value when you have to remember we\u2019re through the looking-glass on social media, where these things are being deliberately gamed for the benefit of those that create it,\u201d says Stokel-Walker. All attention is good attention, since views and shares \u2013 including the genre of angry or incredulous \u201cduet\u201d videos where other creators (including Ramsay) comment on their depravity \u2013 are the point. That\u2019s how you make money after all: successful TikTokers can become part of the app\u2019s creator fund and get paid \u2013 admittedly pennies \u2013 per view. Stokel-Walker says that success can allow creators to pivot to the kind of genuinely lucrative mainstream collaborations that Twisted has managed. "bodyHtml": "<p>I have just ironed my husband a toasted sandwich like some kind of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2020/jan/27/tradwives-new-trend-submissive-women-dark-heart-history\">tradwife</a> and to be honest, I\u2019m disappointed with his reaction. Admittedly, there were a few issues. The steam didn\u2019t help, plus I wrapped it in too much tinfoil, so the heat couldn\u2019t penetrate. The main problem, though, was that holding an iron meant I automatically started ironing the package, pressing hard and going to and fro industriously. The result is flat, very flat. \u201cWe have a sandwich toaster,\u201d my husband points out, holding the crepe-thin delicacy between finger and thumb. He should be thrilled: this is the closest I\u2019ve come to cooking for him in months. He tries it, reluctantly. \u201cIt\u2019s very soft. Did you put mustard in it?\u201d</p> <p>\u201cI thought it would help,\u201d I say.</p> <p>\u201cIt doesn\u2019t.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"5aed856f9a8245373927c3fb0c839b72846e5f97\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5aed856f9a8245373927c3fb0c839b72846e5f97/0_268_8021_4815/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Deranged \u2026 Emma irons her toastie.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Deranged \u2026 Emma irons her toastie.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Christopher Thomond/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Unless you are a particularly online person, you are probably asking why, at this point. It\u2019s a question I have asked myself repeatedly, in a rising pitch of incredulity and distress as I dived deep into TikTok food \u2013 or FoodTok, if you will. Because that is where the ironed toastie comes from: it\u2019s part of a new generation of TikTok recipe hacks that embody a provocative, frankly deranged \u201cwhy not?\u201d philosophy. We\u2019ve come a long, wrong way since <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@feelgoodfoodie/video/6922938178559069446?lang=en\">2021\u2019s viral feta pasta</a>. Now, in addition to ironed toasties, you can enjoy a beatifically smiling blonde <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@foodsfuns3/video/7209089125515939114\">putting dried pasta in a blender</a> to create an approximation of flour, then adding an egg to create a sort of dough. She then fashions lumpy, fat noodles, which she boils, tops with tomato sauce and declares \u201cexactly like fresh pasta\u201d. Comments include the likes of \u201cYOU VIOLATED THE PASTA\u201d, \u201cMa\u2019am, blink twice if someone is holding you hostage\u201d and many irate Italians.</p> <p>But that is not even as bad as the unholy tacos made by <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@myjanebrain/video/7180875279290649861\">boiling beef, eggs and cheese in a bag of Doritos</a>. There\u2019s a whole genre of sponsored-by-diabetes content, where beautiful, young, slim women combine terrifying quantities of marshmallows, sweets, chocolate, butter, cereal, preprepared cookie dough and the like into \u201cincredible\u201d desserts that should be illegal. Many videos are titled: \u201cWhy am I just finding out about \u2026\u201d to which the answer is surely: \u201cBecause it should be on trial at The Hague.\u201d You can watch people <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@elis_kitchen/video/6919198339904949509?lang=fr\">boil up crisps to make mashed potato</a>, or dump uncooked dried pasta in the oven covered in a house-brick sized portion of cream cheese and a jar of sauce. <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@myjanebrain/video/7120382043669810438\">Dry packet ramen oven-baked in tomato sauce and cheese</a> is called \u201cpizza\u201d (I worry for Italy\u2019s collective blood pressure). How about marinading chicken in the sink, or massaging mountains of mac and cheese on a worktop? \u201cEverybody\u2019s so creative!\u201d TikToker @Tanaradoublechocolate, who seeks out culinary atrocities to comment upon, says.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"560c02348970336518d17b04b7acfccb87306b03\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/560c02348970336518d17b04b7acfccb87306b03/52_23_667_631/500.jpg\" alt=\"Unholy \u2026 Doritos tacos.\" width=\"500\" height=\"473\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Unholy \u2026 Doritos tacos.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: @myjanebrain</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>At the risk of sounding like Grampa Simpson yelling at clouds \u2013 which is exactly how I feel exploring FoodTok \u2013 what is going on? \u201cThere\u2019s a long and storied history of gross-out food on social media,\u201d says <a href=\"https://www.stokel-walker.com/\">Chris Stokel-Walker</a>, social media expert and the author of TikTok Boom. Twisted, the social media food brand that just announced a collaboration with Iceland, started out in 2016 and dared us to make the likes of <a href=\"https://ffwd.medium.com/the-company-behind-that-crazy-bbq-chicken-recipe-video-would-like-to-clarify-a-few-things-32bd11dcba24\">deep-fried barbecue chicken-stuffed pizzadilla</a>. Now, says Stokel-Walker, \u201cIt\u2019s been supercharged by the arrival of TikTok.\u201d The app is designed and engineered to \u201ccapture people\u2019s attention as they are scrolling through that endless feed of content\u201d and one good way to do it is precisely \u201cthe outlandish, the gross-out\u201d. It is a notion echoed by <a href=\"https://jonahberger.com/\">Jonah Berger</a>, professor at the Wharton school in Pennsylvania and bestselling author of Contagious, a study of social transmission and virality, who notes that these videos combine surprise and often disgust. \u201cThe more surprising something is, the more likely we are to share it with others. And disgust is a high arousal emotion that also causes us to pass things on.\u201d</p> <p>So is this content engineered to provoke? Some of it, definitely. \u201cI never work to appear genuine,\u201d says Eli Betchik of <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@elis_kitchen?lang=fr\">@elis_kitchen</a>, the self-proclaimed \u201cmost evil chef on TikTok\u201d. \u201cIf anyone asks, I say: \u2018Yeah, I do this for attention.\u2019 I think it\u2019s pretty obvious I do.\u201d It is a mark of Betchik\u2019s evil genius that every video of theirs makes me shout \u201cNo!\u201d in genuine anger at some point. Betchik was behind the much-reviled potato crisp mash, and a horrifying sandwich made of blended peas, pineapple, cheese and nuts, with the bread coated with mayo, then fried, among other outrages.</p> <p>Betchik is a <a href=\"https://www.betchik.com/\">fine art jeweller</a>, who started their channel after discovering TikTok at jewellery school. \u201cI thought, I already love experimenting with food and trying new things \u2013 I could probably take that a few steps further and use it for some good old-fashioned shock-value entertainment.\u201d Their first video was fried mayonnaise. I make a strangled noise hearing this. \u201cYeah, it was horrible,\u201d confirms Betchik. Another early favourite was meatballs boiled in lime juice \u201cuntil the juice was a thick syrup. I\u2019m salivating because I can still taste the sourness. It was the most violent flavour I\u2019ve ever had.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image element--supporting\" data-media-id=\"7b83a7936e8ebf4bcc6df3fe2a34933eb8e1b240\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7b83a7936e8ebf4bcc6df3fe2a34933eb8e1b240/23_156_722_940/384.jpg\" alt=\"Evil \u2026 @elis_kitchen\u2019s pea, pineapple, nuts and cheese sandwich fried in mayonnaise.\" width=\"384\" height=\"500\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Evil \u2026 @elis_kitchen\u2019s pea, pineapple, nuts and cheese sandwich fried in mayonnaise.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: @elis_kitchen/Tik Tok</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Outrage is the point, and, Betchik says, people enjoy feeling it. \u201cObviously, what I\u2019m doing is to gross people out, but people keep coming back \u2013 they wouldn\u2019t keep coming back if they didn\u2019t get something out of it. I find that sometimes people get happy when they\u2019re upset in the right way.\u201d On their jewellery TikTok account <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@eli_metal?lang=en\">@eli_metal</a>, Betchik says, a mean comment would take days to digest, but with the food, it\u2019s a mark of success. The one comment they won\u2019t accept is that these horrendous creations are wasteful: impressively, worryingly omnivorous, Betchik finishes almost everything. In addition, \u201cI try to use foods that are close to going bad or things that have been donated to me. And if I can\u2019t eat it, I compost all the scraps.\u201d It\u2019s not clear if this level of diligence is common practice among the creators, but it feels doubtful.</p> <p>Mean commenters on the <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@myjanebrain?lang=en\">@myjanebrain</a> TikTok account include a certain Gordon Ramsay, who angrily described a chicken stuffed in a pumpkin, garnished with cinnamon sticks and many onions as \u201c<a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@gordonramsayofficial/video/7159989070607748357?lang=en\">Halloween salmonella right there</a>.\u201d \u201cIt was pretty awesome,\u201d says Jane, a preternaturally cheery 27-year-old Canadian and full-time content creator who prefers not to give her surname, perhaps for fear of reprisals from Italians angered by her ramen \u201cpizza\u201d. \u201cBut I know the chicken was fully cooked. It was moist, it had great flavour.\u201d</p> <p>Jane ended up in the realm of what is sometimes called \u201crage-bait\u201d cooking accidentally. Her early videos, she says, were straight instructional content, but she pivoted when her fried chicken recipe went viral. \u201cIt got 31m views, 3,000 comments,\u201d says Jane \u2013 this is, of course, highly populated TikTok territory, the hashtag #FoodTikTok had accumulated 112bn views by the end of 2022, for example. \u201cI thought it would be positive but it was more like: \u2018You\u2019re the worst chef I\u2019ve ever seen.\u2019 So I realised that I would have no idea what people were going to think of my videos.\u201d</p> <p>She started focusing on finding the \u201ccraziest combinations\u201d, including one titled \u201cI learned this hotdog trick in England\u201d, in which she makes jelly from pickle juice, adds frankfurters and eats it in a bread bun. \u201cThat is absolutely not English,\u201d I challenge her hotly, TikTok commenter style. \u201cI can\u2019t remember; it was from some sort of British something,\u201d she says. \u201cI was going to ask you why you make pickle juice jelly!\u201d What makes people angriest, though, she says, is her cooking techniques. \u201cAs soon as you cook for the internet you open yourself up to all the critics who are so specific in the way they cook.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"c681fee56db350006914e45c1dfc969e70f6ff71\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/c681fee56db350006914e45c1dfc969e70f6ff71/0_0_2006_1658/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Ramsay baiting \u2026 @myjanebrain makes chicken in a pumpkin.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"827\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Ramsay baiting \u2026 @myjanebrain makes chicken in a pumpkin.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Amyjanebrain, @gordonramsayofficial/Tik Tok</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Both Jane and Eli are clear that their content is knowingly provocative rather than instructional, whether viewers understand that or not. \u201cA lot of people take this content at face value when you have to remember we\u2019re through the looking-glass on social media, where these things are being deliberately gamed for the benefit of those that create it,\u201d says Stokel-Walker. All attention is good attention, since views and shares \u2013 including the genre of angry or incredulous \u201cduet\u201d videos where other creators (including Ramsay) comment on their depravity \u2013 are the point. That\u2019s how you make money after all: successful TikTokers can become part of the app\u2019s creator fund and get paid \u2013 admittedly pennies \u2013 per view. Stokel-Walker says that success can allow creators to pivot to the kind of genuinely lucrative mainstream <a href=\"https://retailtimes.co.uk/twisted-announces-a-new-frozen-food-collaboration-with-iceland-designed-to-make-eating-as-fun-and-social-as-possible/\">collaborations that Twisted has managed</a>.</p> <p>There is another possibly upsetting angle: fetish. \u201cVideos where they point a lot and touch things and make super-repulsive stuff are apparently fetish,\u201d a baker friend tells me airily, when I inquire if she uses TikTok recipes. It turns out there\u2019s a fairly widespread suspicion this is a thing. The messier foods could fulfil a \u201csploshing\u201d fetish: <a href=\"https://www.insidehook.com/article/internet/gross-viral-food-hacks-rick-lax-facebook-sploshing-fetish\">getting sexual gratification from food mess</a>. \u201cI\u2019ve seen this aired,\u201d says Stokel-Walker. \u201cCertainly, it appeals to your senses. It\u2019s like a slow-motion car crash in food form, where you\u2019re like, how more disgusting can this get?\u201d TikTok user <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@lenarae.lh?lang=en\">@lenarae.lh</a> analyses food videos and pronounces them fetish or non-fetish on the basis of how the women \u2013 it is almost always women \u2013 use their hands, splash or squirt stuff suggestively or massage phallic things. A friend also directs me to the work of a creator called <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@cedriklorenzen?lang=en\">@cedriklorenzen</a> who specialises in whacking pieces of raw meat, dribbling, drizzling and taking his top off. It\u2019s a better appetite suppressant than Ozempic: after watching, I never want to eat, have sex, or indeed see anything again.</p> <p>There is actually plenty of good, normal food on TikTok. Asking around, people mention recipes for homemade crispy chilli sauce, broccoli pasta, sesame dip and various noodle dishes they\u2019ve tried, then added to their repertoire. Seema Pankhania, a 25-year-old former chef de partie at Gordon Ramsay\u2019s Lucky Cat who posts as <a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@seemagetsbaked?lang=en\">@seemagetsbaked</a>, has 1.3 million followers for her eminently achievable, delicious-looking recipes. They are pleasingly lo-fi, especially her pyjama recipes for hungover, no bones days and ultra simple versions of Indian classics \u2013 her butter chicken has 1.7m likes (she also recommends her \u201c<a href=\"https://www.tiktok.com/@seemagetsbaked/video/7165524963041086725\">super simple creamy chicken curry</a>\u201d. But even Pankhania, a proper cook, is aware it is all grist to the gnat\u2019s attention span TikTok mill. She aims to keep videos under a minute long (\u201cthe shorter the better; people are going to get bored\u201d) and has no illusions that much of the food content is only meant to be consumed with the eyes. \u201cThere\u2019s a whole other field of cooking on TikTok which is indulgent,\u201d she says, giving the example of elaborate lasagnes. \u201cNobody is going to make it, but it\u2019s very nice and satisfying to watch.\u201d Clearly that goes for the bizarre and the gross-out stuff too in some more depraved way. \u201cAt the end of the day, social media is entertainment, right?\u201d says Pankhania. \u201cMost of it is just for entertainment and people aren\u2019t actually going to be cooking a lot of it.\u201d</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"867333ec298a8553dfc53cd7020d4c76450aa647\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/867333ec298a8553dfc53cd7020d4c76450aa647/0_273_8192_4918/1000.jpg\" alt=\"\u2018Not terrible, but not good either\u2019 \u2026 dried \u2018fresh\u2019 pasta.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">\u2018Not terrible, but not good either\u2019 \u2026 dried \u2018fresh\u2019 pasta.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Christopher Thomond/The Guardian</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Given much of food TikTok isn\u2019t meant to be cooked, or is intentionally tongue in cheek, I\u2019m sure I\u2019m missing the point entirely as I cram half a packet of spaghetti into my blender. A flimsy thing, it protests loudly with an ominous smell of burning rubber. I whiz up vermicelli instead, dump the \u201cflour\u201d on the worktop and add an egg, making a claggy mess. I have to add normal flour \u2013 surely invalidating the whole madness \u2013 to form a dough ball capable of being rolled out. The resultant approximate noodles are dumped in boiling water. I take them out based on vibes alone \u2013 TikTok recipes are wildly unspecific \u2013 then my family gather to taste and criticise. My husband \u2013 whose former student staple of peas and camembert prepared in a kettle would be a runaway TikTok hit \u2013 declares it raw. \u201cIt\u2019s not terrible,\u201d one son ventures. \u201cIt\u2019s not good either,\u201d says the other, correctly.</p> <p>I dare not attempt anything of Betchik\u2019s, and Jane recommends her own recipe for cinnamon buns baked in cream and coffee, topped with sugar, butter and flattened toffees \u2013 but I am 48 and my organs will explode if I eat that. My wimp\u2019s version \u2013 a vegan bun sliced and covered in oat cream, sugar and cinnamon \u2013 comes out of the oven ominously black; my just deserts for messing with the recipe, I suppose. I eat it all anyway \u2013 it\u2019s a cinnamon bun and cream, what\u2019s not to like? \u2013 then, exhausted and hyperglycaemic, I close TikTok, hopefully for good. Everybody\u2019s so creative! I wish they weren\u2019t.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "I have just ironed my husband a toasted sandwich like some kind of tradwife and to be honest, I\u2019m disappointed with his reaction. The messier foods could fulfil a \u201csploshing\u201d fetish: getting sexual gratification from food mess. \u201cI\u2019ve seen this aired,\u201d says Stokel-Walker. \u201cCertainly, it appeals to your senses. It\u2019s like a slow-motion car crash in food form, where you\u2019re like, how more disgusting can this get?\u201d TikTok user @lenarae.lh analyses food videos and pronounces them fetish or non-fetish on the basis of how the women \u2013 it is almost always women \u2013 use their hands, splash or squirt stuff suggestively or massage phallic things. A friend also directs me to the work of a creator called @cedriklorenzen who specialises in whacking pieces of raw meat, dribbling, drizzling and taking his top off. It\u2019s a better appetite suppressant than Ozempic: after watching, I never want to eat, have sex, or indeed see anything again. There is actually plenty of good, normal food on TikTok. Asking around, people mention recipes for homemade crispy chilli sauce, broccoli pasta, sesame dip and various noodle dishes they\u2019ve tried, then added to their repertoire. Seema Pankhania, a 25-year-old former chef de partie at Gordon Ramsay\u2019s Lucky Cat who posts as @seemagetsbaked, has 1.3 million followers for her eminently achievable, delicious-looking recipes. They are pleasingly lo-fi, especially her pyjama recipes for hungover, no bones days and ultra simple versions of Indian classics \u2013 her butter chicken has 1.7m likes (she also recommends her \u201csuper simple creamy chicken curry\u201d. But even Pankhania, a proper cook, is aware it is all grist to the gnat\u2019s attention span TikTok mill. She aims to keep videos under a minute long (\u201cthe shorter the better; people are going to get bored\u201d) and has no illusions that much of the food content is only meant to be consumed with the eyes. \u201cThere\u2019s a whole other field of cooking on TikTok which is indulgent,\u201d she says, giving the example of elaborate lasagnes. \u201cNobody is going to make it, but it\u2019s very nice and satisfying to watch.\u201d Clearly that goes for the bizarre and the gross-out stuff too in some more depraved way. \u201cAt the end of the day, social media is entertainment, right?\u201d says Pankhania. \u201cMost of it is just for entertainment and people aren\u2019t actually going to be cooking a lot of it.\u201d\nGiven much of food TikTok isn\u2019t meant to be cooked, or is intentionally tongue in cheek, I\u2019m sure I\u2019m missing the point entirely as I cram half a packet of spaghetti into my blender. A flimsy thing, it protests loudly with an ominous smell of burning rubber. I whiz up vermicelli instead, dump the \u201cflour\u201d on the worktop and add an egg, making a claggy mess. I have to add normal flour \u2013 surely invalidating the whole madness \u2013 to form a dough ball capable of being rolled out. The resultant approximate noodles are dumped in boiling water. I take them out based on vibes alone \u2013 TikTok recipes are wildly unspecific \u2013 then my family gather to taste and criticise. My husband \u2013 whose former student staple of peas and camembert prepared in a kettle would be a runaway TikTok hit \u2013 declares it raw. \u201cIt\u2019s not terrible,\u201d one son ventures. \u201cIt\u2019s not good either,\u201d says the other, correctly. I dare not attempt anything of Betchik\u2019s, and Jane recommends her own recipe for cinnamon buns baked in cream and coffee, topped with sugar, butter and flattened toffees \u2013 but I am 48 and my organs will explode if I eat that. My wimp\u2019s version \u2013 a vegan bun sliced and covered in oat cream, sugar and cinnamon \u2013 comes out of the oven ominously black; my just deserts for messing with the recipe, I suppose. I eat it all anyway \u2013 it\u2019s a cinnamon bun and cream, what\u2019s not to like? \u2013 then, exhausted and hyperglycaemic, I close TikTok, hopefully for good. Everybody\u2019s so creative! Twisted, the social media food brand that just announced a collaboration with Iceland, started out in 2016 and dared us to make the likes of <a href=\"https://ffwd.medium.com/the-company-behind-that-crazy-bbq-chicken-recipe-video-would-like-to-clarify-a-few-things-32bd11dcba24\">deep-fried barbecue chicken-stuffed pizzadilla</a>. It is a notion echoed by <a href=\"https://jonahberger.com/\">Jonah Berger</a>, professor at the Wharton school in Pennsylvania and bestselling author of Contagious, a study of social transmission and virality, who notes that these videos combine surprise and often disgust. \u201cThe more surprising something is, the more likely we are to share it with others. The UN envoy to Sudan says at least 185 people have been killed and more than 1,800 wounded. Many more bodies lay uncollected in the streets.</p> \n<p>A US state department official said Blinken had expressed \u201cgrave concern\u201d over civilian deaths in his calls with the rival leaders, and urged them to agree to a ceasefire. Both had a responsibility to \u201censure the safety and wellbeing of civilians, diplomatic personnel, and humanitarian workers\u201d, the official said.</p> \n<aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> \n <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/16/sudan-conflict-why-is-there-fighting-and-what-is-at-stake-in-the-region\">Sudan conflict: why is there fighting and what is at stake in the region?</a> </p> \n</aside> \n<p>Hemedti said he had discussed \u201cpressing issues\u201d with Blinken during their call and further talks were planned. \u201cWe will have another call to continuing dialogue and working hand-in-hand to forge a brighter future for our nations,\u201d tweeted Hemedti, whose whereabouts have not been disclosed since the fighting began.</p> \n<p>Sudan\u2019s rival factions both claimed to have made gains on Monday as violence cut power and water in the capital. Volker Perthes, the UN envoy to Sudan, said the two sides showed no signs of being willing to negotiate.</p> \n<p>The power struggle has derailed a shift to civilian rule and raised fears of a wider conflict.</p> \n<p>Clashes in Khartoum have centred on key sites such as the international airport, presidential palace and the army headquarters. In comments to Sky News, Burhan said he was secure in a presidential guesthouse within the defence ministry compound.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425tN8PSIE2s0l6/\" data-alt=\"map of khartoum\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425tN8PSIE2s0l6/\">Interactive</a> \n</figure> \n<p>Josep Borrell, the EU foreign policy chief, said the EU ambassador in Khartoum had been assaulted at his residency. Borrell did not say if the ambassador, the Irish diplomat Aidan O\u2019Hara, had been badly injured, but called the attack \u201ca gross violation of the Vienna convention\u201d, which is supposed to guarantee the protection of diplomatic premises.</p> \n<p>The US national security council spokesperson, John Kirby, said the US was not, for the time being, planning an evacuation from the country.</p> \n<p>Burhan raised the stakes in the violence still further on Monday, ordering the dissolution of the RSF, which he called a \u201crebellious group\u201d. For his part, Hemedti called Burhan \u201ca radical Islamist who is bombing civilians from the air\u201d.</p> \n<p>Military jets flew low over the capital through much of Monday as repeated bouts of firing and shelling continued there and in Omdurman, Khartoum\u2019s sister city across the Nile. Witnesses have reported dozens of bodies in one central neighbourhood of the capital, and hundreds of students remain trapped in schools by the fighting.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"5a161cf69acfda274bfc10c28857bfefb2a5b33d\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5a161cf69acfda274bfc10c28857bfefb2a5b33d/0_322_5500_3301/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Smoke rises from burning aircraft in Khartoum airport during clashes between the paramilitary RSF and the army.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Smoke rises from burning aircraft in Khartoum airport during clashes between the paramilitary RSF and the army.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Reuters</span> \n </figcaption> \n</figure> \n<p>Hospitals have been particularly affected, with essential supplies badly disrupted by the fighting. Hundreds of patients have been evacuated, while medical staff attempt to move others from intensive care or dialysis units to places of safety.</p> \n<p>\u201cWe had to move them to the isolation centres along with 70 doctors and nurses, all have been trapped here with no oxygen for the chest patients and that\u2019s really dangerous \u2026 The oxygen we have is from the time of the pandemic and it\u2019s limited,\u201d one nurse said.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"4d92144a-a982-401c-ba17-9158cc5756a3\" data-atom-type=\"media\"> \n  <div>\n   <iframe frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" src=\"https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/WVlQ91l9Ciw?showinfo=0&amp;rel=0\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>Aid workers in remote parts of Sudan also reported tensions or violence. One based in on the eastern border with Ethiopia described the regular army overwhelming a small RSF contingent and seizing their base amid sporadic shooting. Officials also reported fighting in the east, including the provinces of Kassala and El Gadaref.</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/16/sudan-conflict-why-is-there-fighting-and-what-is-at-stake-in-the-region\">conflict threatens to plunge</a> one of Africa\u2019s biggest and most strategically important countries into chaos. Analysts say only pressure from \u201cheavyweight\u201d intermediaries will have a chance of ending the fighting.</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425qo5Kq3COxrLU/\" data-alt=\"Map of fighting across Sudan\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425qo5Kq3COxrLU/\">Interactive</a> \n</figure> \n<p>In a speech broadcast by Egyptian state television late on Monday, President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi said he was in regular contact with the army and RSF to \u201cencourage them to accept a ceasefire and spare the blood of the Sudanese people\u201d.</p> \n<p>The African Union\u2019s top council has called for an immediate ceasefire without conditions, while other Arab states with stakes in Sudan \u2013 Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates \u2013 made similar appeals. </p> \n<p><em>Reuters contributed to this report</em></p>", "wordcount": "790", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T04:49:32Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-19T09:50:13Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnk8j", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/11602ac96a16956c4b04f53e229155a5a739164d/0_224_6720_4032/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "A US diplomatic convoy came under fire in Sudan in an apparent attack by fighters associated with Sudan\u2019s paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, the US secretary of state, Antony Blinken, has said, in an incident he described as \u201creckless\u201d and \u201cirresponsible\u201d. The incident on Monday prompted a direct warning from Blinken, who separately telephoned the RSF leader Gen Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, known as Hemedti, and Sudan\u2019s army chief, Gen Abdel Fatah al-Burhan, to tell them any danger posed to American diplomats was unacceptable. Blinken said the convoy that came under fire was flying US. flags and all in the convoy were safe. \u201cWe have deep concerns about the overall security environment,\u201d he said at a press conference in Japan where he attended a G7 meeting of foreign ministers. Fighting erupted on Saturday between army units loyal to Burhan, the head of Sudan\u2019s transitional governing Sovereign Council, and Hemedti, the deputy head of the council. The UN envoy to Sudan says at least 185 people have been killed and more than 1,800 wounded. Many more bodies lay uncollected in the streets. A US state department official said Blinken had expressed \u201cgrave concern\u201d over civilian deaths in his calls with the rival leaders, and urged them to agree to a ceasefire. Both had a responsibility to \u201censure the safety and wellbeing of civilians, diplomatic personnel, and humanitarian workers\u201d, the official said. Hemedti said he had discussed \u201cpressing issues\u201d with Blinken during their call and further talks were planned. \u201cWe will have another call to continuing dialogue and working hand-in-hand to forge a brighter future for our nations,\u201d tweeted Hemedti, whose whereabouts have not been disclosed since the fighting began. Sudan\u2019s rival factions both claimed to have made gains on Monday as violence cut power and water in the capital. Volker Perthes, the UN envoy to Sudan, said the two sides showed no signs of being willing to negotiate. The power struggle has derailed a shift to civilian rule and raised fears of a wider conflict. Clashes in Khartoum have centred on key sites such as the international airport, presidential palace and the army headquarters. In comments to Sky News, Burhan said he was secure in a presidential guesthouse within the defence ministry compound. Josep Borrell, the EU foreign policy chief, said the EU ambassador in Khartoum had been assaulted at his residency. Borrell did not say if the ambassador, the Irish diplomat Aidan O\u2019Hara, had been badly injured, but called the attack \u201ca gross violation of the Vienna convention\u201d, which is supposed to guarantee the protection of diplomatic premises. The US national security council spokesperson, John Kirby, said the US was not, for the time being, planning an evacuation from the country. Burhan raised the stakes in the violence still further on Monday, ordering the dissolution of the RSF, which he called a \u201crebellious group\u201d. For his part, Hemedti called Burhan \u201ca radical Islamist who is bombing civilians from the air\u201d. Military jets flew low over the capital through much of Monday as repeated bouts of firing and shelling continued there and in Omdurman, Khartoum\u2019s sister city across the Nile. Witnesses have reported dozens of bodies in one central neighbourhood of the capital, and hundreds of students remain trapped in schools by the fighting. Hospitals have been particularly affected, with essential supplies badly disrupted by the fighting. Hundreds of patients have been evacuated, while medical staff attempt to move others from intensive care or dialysis units to places of safety. \u201cWe had to move them to the isolation centres along with 70 doctors and nurses, all have been trapped here with no oxygen for the chest patients and that\u2019s really dangerous \u2026 The oxygen we have is from the time of the pandemic and it\u2019s limited,\u201d one nurse said. Aid workers in remote parts of Sudan also reported tensions or violence. One based in on the eastern border with Ethiopia described the regular army overwhelming a small RSF contingent and seizing their base amid sporadic shooting. Officials also reported fighting in the east, including the provinces of Kassala and El Gadaref. The conflict threatens to plunge one of Africa\u2019s biggest and most strategically important countries into chaos. Analysts say only pressure from \u201cheavyweight\u201d intermediaries will have a chance of ending the fighting. In a speech broadcast by Egyptian state television late on Monday, President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi said he was in regular contact with the army and RSF to \u201cencourage them to accept a ceasefire and spare the blood of the Sudanese people\u201d. The African Union\u2019s top council has called for an immediate ceasefire without conditions, while other Arab states with stakes in Sudan \u2013 Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates \u2013 made similar appeals. The UN envoy to Sudan says at least 185 people have been killed and more than 1,800 wounded. Many more bodies lay uncollected in the streets.</p> <p>A US state department official said Blinken had expressed \u201cgrave concern\u201d over civilian deaths in his calls with the rival leaders, and urged them to agree to a ceasefire. Both had a responsibility to \u201censure the safety and wellbeing of civilians, diplomatic personnel, and humanitarian workers\u201d, the official said.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/16/sudan-conflict-why-is-there-fighting-and-what-is-at-stake-in-the-region\">Sudan conflict: why is there fighting and what is at stake in the region?</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Hemedti said he had discussed \u201cpressing issues\u201d with Blinken during their call and further talks were planned. \u201cWe will have another call to continuing dialogue and working hand-in-hand to forge a brighter future for our nations,\u201d tweeted Hemedti, whose whereabouts have not been disclosed since the fighting began.</p> <p>Sudan\u2019s rival factions both claimed to have made gains on Monday as violence cut power and water in the capital. Volker Perthes, the UN envoy to Sudan, said the two sides showed no signs of being willing to negotiate.</p> <p>The power struggle has derailed a shift to civilian rule and raised fears of a wider conflict.</p> <p>Clashes in Khartoum have centred on key sites such as the international airport, presidential palace and the army headquarters. In comments to Sky News, Burhan said he was secure in a presidential guesthouse within the defence ministry compound.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425tN8PSIE2s0l6/\" data-alt=\"map of khartoum\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425tN8PSIE2s0l6/\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>Josep Borrell, the EU foreign policy chief, said the EU ambassador in Khartoum had been assaulted at his residency. Borrell did not say if the ambassador, the Irish diplomat Aidan O\u2019Hara, had been badly injured, but called the attack \u201ca gross violation of the Vienna convention\u201d, which is supposed to guarantee the protection of diplomatic premises.</p> <p>The US national security council spokesperson, John Kirby, said the US was not, for the time being, planning an evacuation from the country.</p> <p>Burhan raised the stakes in the violence still further on Monday, ordering the dissolution of the RSF, which he called a \u201crebellious group\u201d. For his part, Hemedti called Burhan \u201ca radical Islamist who is bombing civilians from the air\u201d.</p> <p>Military jets flew low over the capital through much of Monday as repeated bouts of firing and shelling continued there and in Omdurman, Khartoum\u2019s sister city across the Nile. Witnesses have reported dozens of bodies in one central neighbourhood of the capital, and hundreds of students remain trapped in schools by the fighting.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"5a161cf69acfda274bfc10c28857bfefb2a5b33d\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/5a161cf69acfda274bfc10c28857bfefb2a5b33d/0_322_5500_3301/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Smoke rises from burning aircraft in Khartoum airport during clashes between the paramilitary RSF and the army.\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Smoke rises from burning aircraft in Khartoum airport during clashes between the paramilitary RSF and the army.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Hospitals have been particularly affected, with essential supplies badly disrupted by the fighting. Hundreds of patients have been evacuated, while medical staff attempt to move others from intensive care or dialysis units to places of safety.</p> <p>\u201cWe had to move them to the isolation centres along with 70 doctors and nurses, all have been trapped here with no oxygen for the chest patients and that\u2019s really dangerous \u2026 The oxygen we have is from the time of the pandemic and it\u2019s limited,\u201d one nurse said.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"4d92144a-a982-401c-ba17-9158cc5756a3\"         data-atom-type=\"media\"    > </gu-atom> </figure>   <p>Aid workers in remote parts of Sudan also reported tensions or violence. One based in on the eastern border with Ethiopia described the regular army overwhelming a small RSF contingent and seizing their base amid sporadic shooting. Officials also reported fighting in the east, including the provinces of Kassala and El Gadaref.</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/16/sudan-conflict-why-is-there-fighting-and-what-is-at-stake-in-the-region\">conflict threatens to plunge</a> one of Africa\u2019s biggest and most strategically important countries into chaos. Analysts say only pressure from \u201cheavyweight\u201d intermediaries will have a chance of ending the fighting.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425qo5Kq3COxrLU/\" data-alt=\"Map of fighting across Sudan\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425qo5Kq3COxrLU/\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>In a speech broadcast by Egyptian state television late on Monday, President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi said he was in regular contact with the army and RSF to \u201cencourage them to accept a ceasefire and spare the blood of the Sudanese people\u201d.</p> <p>The African Union\u2019s top council has called for an immediate ceasefire without conditions, while other Arab states with stakes in Sudan \u2013 Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates \u2013 made similar appeals. </p> <p><em>Reuters contributed to this report</em></p>", "bodyTextSummary": "A US diplomatic convoy came under fire in Sudan in an apparent attack by fighters associated with Sudan\u2019s paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, the US secretary of state, Antony Blinken, has said, in an incident he described as \u201creckless\u201d and \u201cirresponsible\u201d. The incident on Monday prompted a direct warning from Blinken, who separately telephoned the RSF leader Gen Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, known as Hemedti, and Sudan\u2019s army chief, Gen Abdel Fatah al-Burhan, to tell them any danger posed to American diplomats was unacceptable. Blinken said the convoy that came under fire was flying US. flags and all in the convoy were safe. \u201cWe have deep concerns about the overall security environment,\u201d he said at a press conference in Japan where he attended a G7 meeting of foreign ministers. Fighting erupted on Saturday between army units loyal to Burhan, the head of Sudan\u2019s transitional governing Sovereign Council, and Hemedti, the deputy head of the council. The UN envoy to Sudan says at least 185 people have been killed and more than 1,800 wounded. Many more bodies lay uncollected in the streets. A US state department official said Blinken had expressed \u201cgrave concern\u201d over civilian deaths in his calls with the rival leaders, and urged them to agree to a ceasefire. Both had a responsibility to \u201censure the safety and wellbeing of civilians, diplomatic personnel, and humanitarian workers\u201d, the official said.\nHemedti said he had discussed \u201cpressing issues\u201d with Blinken during their call and further talks were planned. \u201cWe will have another call to continuing dialogue and working hand-in-hand to forge a brighter future for our nations,\u201d tweeted Hemedti, whose whereabouts have not been disclosed since the fighting began. Sudan\u2019s rival factions both claimed to have made gains on Monday as violence cut power and water in the capital. Volker Perthes, the UN envoy to Sudan, said the two sides showed no signs of being willing to negotiate. The power struggle has derailed a shift to civilian rule and raised fears of a wider conflict. Clashes in Khartoum have centred on key sites such as the international airport, presidential palace and the army headquarters. In comments to Sky News, Burhan said he was secure in a presidential guesthouse within the defence ministry compound.\nJosep Borrell, the EU foreign policy chief, said the EU ambassador in Khartoum had been assaulted at his residency. Borrell did not say if the ambassador, the Irish diplomat Aidan O\u2019Hara, had been badly injured, but called the attack \u201ca gross violation of the Vienna convention\u201d, which is supposed to guarantee the protection of diplomatic premises. The US national security council spokesperson, John Kirby, said the US was not, for the time being, planning an evacuation from the country. Burhan raised the stakes in the violence still further on Monday, ordering the dissolution of the RSF, which he called a \u201crebellious group\u201d. For his part, Hemedti called Burhan \u201ca radical Islamist who is bombing civilians from the air\u201d. Military jets flew low over the capital through much of Monday as repeated bouts of firing and shelling continued there and in Omdurman, Khartoum\u2019s sister city across the Nile. Witnesses have reported dozens of bodies in one central neighbourhood of the capital, and hundreds of students remain trapped in schools by the fighting.\nHospitals have been particularly affected, with essential supplies badly disrupted by the fighting. Hundreds of patients have been evacuated, while medical staff attempt to move others from intensive care or dialysis units to places of safety. \u201cWe had to move them to the isolation centres along with 70 doctors and nurses, all have been trapped here with no oxygen for the chest patients and that\u2019s really dangerous \u2026 The oxygen we have is from the time of the pandemic and it\u2019s limited,\u201d one nurse said.\nAid workers in remote parts of Sudan also reported tensions or violence. One based in on the eastern border with Ethiopia described the regular army overwhelming a small RSF contingent and seizing their base amid sporadic shooting. Officials also reported fighting in the east, including the provinces of Kassala and El Gadaref. The conflict threatens to plunge one of Africa\u2019s biggest and most strategically important countries into chaos. Analysts say only pressure from \u201cheavyweight\u201d intermediaries will have a chance of ending the fighting.\nIn a speech broadcast by Egyptian state television late on Monday, President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi said he was in regular contact with the army and RSF to \u201cencourage them to accept a ceasefire and spare the blood of the Sudanese people\u201d. The African Union\u2019s top council has called for an immediate ceasefire without conditions, while other Arab states with stakes in Sudan \u2013 Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates \u2013 made similar appeals. "<strong>Lightwood, Derbyshire:\u200b</strong> Mosses are a wonderfully rich and underappreciated subject \u2013 often living right under our noses \u200b", "byline": "Mark Cocker", "main": "<figure alt=\"Springy turf-moss (Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus).\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Springy turf-moss (<em>Rhytidiadelphus them? If you Google the words \u201cmoss treatment\u201d, it gets 200 million hits, but \u201cbryology\u201d \u2013 the study of mosses and bryophytes (including liverworts and hornworts) \u2013 returns a figure of just 490,000.</p> <p>Even botanists acknowledge, however, that mosses are hard to identify. The excellent starter guide by the Species Recovery Trust, which has been my trusty lantern into this previously shadowed realm, describes mosses as the botanist\u2019s \u201cfinal frontier\u201d.</p> <p>The stark, leaf-free conditions of spring make mosses easier to notice, but I must confess that the season has involved more darkness than light. My default office scenario involves a screen of five website pages, simultaneous with four of my images, a scatter of opened books, all hand annotated now, mostly with crossed-out names. Yet I\u2019ve already enriched my life \u2013 and vocabulary \u2013 with new acquaintances such as <a href=\"https://www.britishbryologicalsociety.org.uk/learning/species-finder/tortula-muralis/\" title=\"\">wall screw\u2011moss</a> or <a href=\"https://www.britishbryologicalsociety.org.uk/learning/species-finder/grimmia-pulvinata/\" title=\"\">grey-cushioned grimmia</a> and <a href=\"https://www.britishbryologicalsociety.org.uk/learning/species-finder/rhytidiadelphus-squarrosus/\" title=\"\">springy turf-moss</a>.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"16b3ef26b5bfee3fc7534f76e138ab8bdcc9d687\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/16b3ef26b5bfee3fc7534f76e138ab8bdcc9d687/0_182_4000_2399/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A close-up of water earwort (Scapania undulata).\" width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">A close-up of water earwort (<em>Scapania undulata).</em></span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Mark Cocker</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>The last, incidentally, is probably the species that inspires most of those online hits for \u201cmoss treatment\u201d. It\u2019s a common lawn visitor. If only people looked closer they would see what bryologists love about <em>Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus</em>: the way that the pointed leaves bend back at right angles from a gloriously red stem so that each spike ends in a tiny, soft, glittering star. It is both exquisite and awesome because to study mosses is to ponder deep time: their ancestors first evolved in the Ordovician, 470m years ago.</p> <p>If mosses are wonderful, then liverworts are bizarre. As the name may indicate, many are primitive, flattened, fleshy layers of aqueous green, usually in conditions of permanent wetness. Riverbanks are a common haunt. Many require a hand lens for true appreciation, and an old wet gritstone quarry has become a favourite personal site. Most of the time I\u2019ve no idea what I\u2019m looking at, but to peer into the liverwort\u2019s realm, albeit magnified 10 times by my lens, is to look into the glistening oesophageal depths of some unknown, previously unimagined life.</p> <p>This, I suppose, has been the bryophytes\u2019 gift this year: a recognition that beyond the \u201chomolith\u201d \u2013 the superabundant detritus smothered by our species across the landscape \u2013 is another wild world still untouched and probably unassailable.</p> <p>\u2022 Country diary is on Twitter at <a href=\"https://twitter.com/gdncountrydiary?lang=en\" title=\"\">@gdncountrydiary</a></p>", "newspaperPageNumber": "9", "wordcount": "380", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T04:30:34Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "true", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-19T10:32:34Z", "newspaperEditionDate": "2023-04-18T00:00:00Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "The Guardian", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmbdt", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/83e647916c319165b0093037ed35b6bfaf808046/0_121_3594_2157/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Why is it that we care so little for mosses, except perhaps to kill them? Even botanists acknowledge, however, that mosses are hard to identify.
