If only people looked closer they would see what bryologists love about <em>Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus</em>: the way that the pointed leaves bend back at right angles from a gloriously red stem so that each spike ends in a tiny, soft, glittering star. It is both exquisite and awesome because to study mosses is to ponder deep time: their ancestors first evolved in the Ordovician, 470m years ago.</p> \n<p>If mosses are wonderful, then liverworts are bizarre. As the name may indicate, many are primitive, flattened, fleshy layers of aqueous green, usually in conditions of permanent wetness. Riverbanks are a common haunt. Many require a hand lens for true appreciation, and an old wet gritstone quarry has become a favourite personal site. Most of the time I\u2019ve no idea what I\u2019m looking at, but to peer into the liverwort\u2019s realm, albeit magnified 10 times by my lens, is to look into the glistening oesophageal depths of some unknown, previously unimagined life.</p> \n<p>This, I suppose, has been the bryophytes\u2019 gift this year: a recognition that beyond the \u201chomolith\u201d \u2013 the superabundant detritus smothered by our species across the landscape \u2013 is another wild world still untouched and probably unassailable.</p> \n<p>\u2022 Country diary is on Twitter at <a href=\"https://twitter.com/gdncountrydiary?lang=en\" title=\"\">@gdncountrydiary</a></p>"}}]}], "totalBodyBlocks": 1}, "rights": {"syndicatable": "true", "subscriptionDatabases": "true", <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/jan/18/freshwater-fish-contaminated-forever-chemicals\">Freshwater fish more contaminated with \u2018forever chemicals\u2019 than in oceans</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The unique ecosystem and cultural heritage of the Grand Canyon is on the brink of collapse due to prolonged drought, rising temperatures and outdated river management, according to American Rivers, the conservation group that compiles <a href=\"https://www.americanrivers.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/AR_2023-Most-Endangered-Rivers_lowres-3.pdf\">the annual endangered list.</a></p> <p>Its future hangs in the balance, as the Biden administration is poised to change the way the Colorado River\u2019s dwindling water is divided. Further restrictions to the river flow risks turning the Grand Canyon into an ecological sacrifice zone, causing irreparable damage to wildlife, fish stocks and sacred sites, the report warns.</p> <p>\u201cThe Colorado River is on the brink of collapse and the Grand Canyon is in the crosshairs ... trying to solve the basin\u2019s water challenges by sacrificing the health of the Grand Canyon would be an utter tragedy,\u201d said Sinjin Eberle from American Rivers. \u201cThis is an all-hands-on-deck emergency.\u201d</p> <p>The annual snapshot of the country\u2019s most endangered rivers ranks the 10 US waterways at a crucial crossroads, where key decisions in the coming months will determine their long-term fate.</p> <p>Now in its 38th year, the annual ranking has helped spur the removal of outdated dams, clean-ups and protective designations, and the prevention of destructive development.</p> <p>The 2023 list includes rivers that traverse 17 states and scores of sovereign tribal nations, and supply drinking water, food, recreation and spiritual nourishment to millions of people. The waterways are under threat from mining, the climate breakdown, dams, industrial pollution and outdated river management practices that for too long have rebuffed traditional knowledge and sustainable techniques tried and tested by Indigenous Americans.</p> <p>Two-thirds of the country\u2019s water supply comes from its 3m miles of rivers, but almost half (44%) of waterways are too polluted for fishing and swimming, according to the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425LQJSzTs13k9k/\" data-alt=\"Map of the 10 most endangered US rivers\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425LQJSzTs13k9k/\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>Stretching from the Rocky Mountains to the sea in Mexico, the 1,500-mile Colorado watershed provides drinking water to 40 million people \u2013 including some of America\u2019s most populous cities, such as Los Angeles and Phoenix, as well as 30 tribal nations \u2013 and irrigation water for almost 6m acres of ranch and farmland.</p> <p>The Grand Canyon in northern Arizona boasts one of the region\u2019s most biodiverse ecosystems and is considered one of the seven natural wonders of the world. The canyon connects the upper and lower basins of the Colorado River, and is bookended by two massive dams that form the largest reservoirs in the US, Lake Mead and Lake Powell.</p> <p>More than a dozen tribes and pueblos consider the Grand Canyon sacred, and have long acted as stewards in spite of the dams, development and pollution by US governments dating back to the first settlers.</p> <p>The climate crisis has led to prolonged <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/sep/12/us-west-megadrought-climate-disaster\">drought across the entire river basin</a> and reduced snowfall on the Rockies, which, along with chronic overuse, has left the reservoirs with historically low water levels.</p> <p>As a result, river managers have overseen changes to the quantity and flow of water supplies along the course of the river to protect the dams and other infrastructure. Restricting water flows has contributed to severe erosion of beaches within the canyon, impacting essential habitat for native fish and wildlife that play an important role in food security, Indigenous cultures and the recreation industry, according to the report.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"a26c259290fd89fb53f65a58793d80c6cfc3ec10\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/a26c259290fd89fb53f65a58793d80c6cfc3ec10/0_0_5472_3648/1000.jpg\" alt=\"aerial picture of river running through valley with trees\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">New mines threaten the future of the Chilkat and Klehini rivers in Alaska, relied upon by  Indigenous villagers for food security and tribal culture.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Katy Neusteter/Courtesy of American Rivers</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Despite some much needed respite after above-average rainfall and winter snowpack, the Biden administration is on the cusp of announcing major cuts to Colorado River water allocation which could further impact the supply and flow to the ecologically fragile canyon landscape.</p> <p>\u201cThe Colorado River is in poor health. We hope that agencies will listen and work with tribes on tackling these challenges of how to manage and protect the Colorado River and Grand Canyon,\u201d said Jakob Maase from the Hopi Tribe.</p> <p>Last year, the entire Colorado River was ranked as America\u2019s most endangered waterway, and this marks its 12th appearance on the list since 1991. The river has been so over-tapped since the mid 1900s that it runs dry in Mexico, leaving the Indigenous Cucap\u00e1 \u2013 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/oct/22/mexico-colorado-river-people-left-without-river\">or river people \u2013 without water</a>.</p> <p>In the midwest, the Norfolk Southern train derailment and chemical burn in East Palestine led to a major leak of hazardous butyl acrylate into the Ohio River, an already overly polluted watershed relied on by 5m people for drinking. The report calls on Congress to designate the Ohio River as a federally protected system and provide funds to upgrade monitoring equipment and cleanup the degraded waterway which is contaminated with legacy industrial chemicals including mercury and dioxin, as well as newer toxins like PFAS, Gen-X chemicals and acid mine drainage.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--inline\"> <blockquote> <p>We hope that agencies will work with tribes on tackling these challenges of how to manage and protect the Colorado River and Grand Canyon</p> <footer> <cite>Jakob Maase, Hopi Tribe</cite> </footer> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>\u201cThe economic future of communities along the Ohio River depends in large part on the protection and restoration of the water system,\u201d said Ben Hunkler from the Ohio River Valley Institute.</p> <p>Meanwhile, new mines threaten the future of the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/jun/22/alaska-haines-village-salmon-fishing-gold-mine\">Chilkat </a>and Klehini rivers in Alaska, relied upon by Indigenous villagers for food security and tribal culture, and the pristine <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/apr/01/georgia-okefenokee-swamp-twin-pines-mining\">Okefenokee swamp</a> that borders Georgia and Florida. In both cases, fish and wildlife habitat, water quality and climate buffering wetlands face imminent and irreversible dangers, if mining operations are given the go-ahead.</p> <p>\u201cThe natural riches of these lands and waters have allowed our people not only to survive, but to thrive, for untold generations. Endangering the Chilkat River ecosystem with a hard rock mine will have devastating effects on our tribal people that rely on the Chilkat River and Chilkat Valley as our sustainable food source,\u201d said Kimberley Strong, president of Chilkat Indian Village.</p> <p>\u201cThis report sounds the alarm. It is a national call to action to defend these rivers and all of the life they support,\u201d said Tom Kiernan, president of American Rivers. \u201cWhen rivers are sick, people suffer.\u201d</p>", "wordcount": "971", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T04:01:34Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T14:33:41Z", "productionOffice": "US", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnx98", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/1eb20ea9a587bbab849abad30c208e75a03d9f2c/0_305_4928_2959/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "A 277-mile stretch of the Colorado River that snakes through the iconic Grand Canyon is America\u2019s most endangered waterway, a new report has found. The unique ecosystem and cultural heritage of the Grand Canyon is on the brink of collapse due to prolonged drought, rising temperatures and outdated river management, according to American Rivers, the conservation group that compiles the annual endangered list. Its future hangs in the balance, as the Biden administration is poised to change the way the Colorado River\u2019s dwindling water is divided. Further restrictions to the river flow risks turning the Grand Canyon into an ecological sacrifice zone, causing irreparable damage to wildlife, fish stocks and sacred sites, the report warns. \u201cThe Colorado River is on the brink of collapse and the Grand Canyon is in the crosshairs ... trying to solve the basin\u2019s water challenges by sacrificing the health of the Grand Canyon would be an utter tragedy,\u201d said Sinjin Eberle from American Rivers. \u201cThis is an all-hands-on-deck emergency.\u201d The annual snapshot of the country\u2019s most endangered rivers ranks the 10 US waterways at a crucial crossroads, where key decisions in the coming months will determine their long-term fate. Now in its 38th year, the annual ranking has helped spur the removal of outdated dams, clean-ups and protective designations, and the prevention of destructive development. The 2023 list includes rivers that traverse 17 states and scores of sovereign tribal nations, and supply drinking water, food, recreation and spiritual nourishment to millions of people. The waterways are under threat from mining, the climate breakdown, dams, industrial pollution and outdated river management practices that for too long have rebuffed traditional knowledge and sustainable techniques tried and tested by Indigenous Americans. Two-thirds of the country\u2019s water supply comes from its 3m miles of rivers, but almost half (44%) of waterways are too polluted for fishing and swimming, according to the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Stretching from the Rocky Mountains to the sea in Mexico, the 1,500-mile Colorado watershed provides drinking water to 40 million people \u2013 including some of America\u2019s most populous cities, such as Los Angeles and Phoenix, as well as 30 tribal nations \u2013 and irrigation water for almost 6m acres of ranch and farmland. The Grand Canyon in northern Arizona boasts one of the region\u2019s most biodiverse ecosystems and is considered one of the seven natural wonders of the world. The canyon connects the upper and lower basins of the Colorado River, and is bookended by two massive dams that form the largest reservoirs in the US, Lake Mead and Lake Powell. More than a dozen tribes and pueblos consider the Grand Canyon sacred, and have long acted as stewards in spite of the dams, development and pollution by US governments dating back to the first settlers. The climate crisis has led to prolonged drought across the entire river basin and reduced snowfall on the Rockies, which, along with chronic overuse, has left the reservoirs with historically low water levels. As a result, river managers have overseen changes to the quantity and flow of water supplies along the course of the river to protect the dams and other infrastructure. Restricting water flows has contributed to severe erosion of beaches within the canyon, impacting essential habitat for native fish and wildlife that play an important role in food security, Indigenous cultures and the recreation industry, according to the report. Despite some much needed respite after above-average rainfall and winter snowpack, the Biden administration is on the cusp of announcing major cuts to Colorado River water allocation which could further impact the supply and flow to the ecologically fragile canyon landscape. \u201cThe Colorado River is in poor health. We hope that agencies will listen and work with tribes on tackling these challenges of how to manage and protect the Colorado River and Grand Canyon,\u201d said Jakob Maase from the Hopi Tribe. Last year, the entire Colorado River was ranked as America\u2019s most endangered waterway, and this marks its 12th appearance on the list since 1991. The river has been so over-tapped since the mid 1900s that it runs dry in Mexico, leaving the Indigenous Cucap\u00e1 \u2013 or river people \u2013 without water. In the midwest, the Norfolk Southern train derailment and chemical burn in East Palestine led to a major leak of hazardous butyl acrylate into the Ohio River, an already overly polluted watershed relied on by 5m people for drinking. The report calls on Congress to designate the Ohio River as a federally protected system and provide funds to upgrade monitoring equipment and cleanup the degraded waterway which is contaminated with legacy industrial chemicals including mercury and dioxin, as well as newer toxins like PFAS, Gen-X chemicals and acid mine drainage. \u201cThe economic future of communities along the Ohio River depends in large part on the protection and restoration of the water system,\u201d said Ben Hunkler from the Ohio River Valley Institute. Meanwhile, new mines threaten the future of the Chilkat and Klehini rivers in Alaska, relied upon by Indigenous villagers for food security and tribal culture, and the pristine Okefenokee swamp that borders Georgia and Florida. In both cases, fish and wildlife habitat, water quality and climate buffering wetlands face imminent and irreversible dangers, if mining operations are given the go-ahead. \u201cThe natural riches of these lands and waters have allowed our people not only to survive, but to thrive, for untold generations. Endangering the Chilkat River ecosystem with a hard rock mine will have devastating effects on our tribal people that rely on the Chilkat River and Chilkat Valley as our sustainable food source,\u201d said Kimberley Strong, president of Chilkat Indian Village. \u201cThis report sounds the alarm. It is a national call to action to defend these rivers and all of the life they support,\u201d said Tom Kiernan, president of American Rivers. \u201cWhen rivers are sick, people suffer.\u201d", The waterways are under threat from mining, the climate breakdown, dams, industrial pollution and outdated river management practices that for too long have rebuffed traditional knowledge and sustainable techniques tried and tested by Indigenous Americans.</p> <p>Two-thirds of the country\u2019s water supply comes from its 3m miles of rivers, but almost half (44%) of waterways are too polluted for fishing and swimming, according to the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425LQJSzTs13k9k/\" data-alt=\"Map of the 10 most endangered US rivers\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/uploader/embed/2023/04/archive-zip/giv-13425LQJSzTs13k9k/\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>Stretching from the Rocky Mountains to the sea in Mexico, the 1,500-mile Colorado watershed provides drinking water to 40 million people \u2013 including some of America\u2019s most populous cities, such as Los Angeles and Phoenix, as well as 30 tribal nations \u2013 and irrigation water for almost 6m acres of ranch and farmland.</p> <p>The Grand Canyon in northern Arizona boasts one of the region\u2019s most biodiverse ecosystems and is considered one of the seven natural wonders of the world. The canyon connects the upper and lower basins of the Colorado River, and is bookended by two massive dams that form the largest reservoirs in the US, Lake Mead and Lake Powell.</p> <p>More than a dozen tribes and pueblos consider the Grand Canyon sacred, and have long acted as stewards in spite of the dams, development and pollution by US governments dating back to the first settlers.</p> <p>The climate crisis has led to prolonged <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2022/sep/12/us-west-megadrought-climate-disaster\">drought across the entire river basin</a> and reduced snowfall on the Rockies, which, along with chronic overuse, has left the reservoirs with historically low water levels.</p> <p>As a result, river managers have overseen changes to the quantity and flow of water supplies along the course of the river to protect the dams and other infrastructure. Restricting water flows has contributed to severe erosion of beaches within the canyon, impacting essential habitat for native fish and wildlife that play an important role in food security, Indigenous cultures and the recreation industry, according to the report.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"a26c259290fd89fb53f65a58793d80c6cfc3ec10\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/a26c259290fd89fb53f65a58793d80c6cfc3ec10/0_0_5472_3648/1000.jpg\" alt=\"aerial picture of river running through valley with trees\" width=\"1000\" height=\"667\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">New mines threaten the future of the Chilkat and Klehini rivers in Alaska, relied upon by  Indigenous villagers for food security and tribal culture.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Katy Neusteter/Courtesy of American Rivers</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Despite some much needed respite after above-average rainfall and winter snowpack, the Biden administration is on the cusp of announcing major cuts to Colorado River water allocation which could further impact the supply and flow to the ecologically fragile canyon landscape.</p> <p>\u201cThe Colorado River is in poor health. We hope that agencies will listen and work with tribes on tackling these challenges of how to manage and protect the Colorado River and Grand Canyon,\u201d said Jakob Maase from the Hopi Tribe.</p> <p>Last year, the entire Colorado River was ranked as America\u2019s most endangered waterway, and this marks its 12th appearance on the list since 1991. The river has been so over-tapped since the mid 1900s that it runs dry in Mexico, leaving the Indigenous Cucap\u00e1 \u2013 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2019/oct/22/mexico-colorado-river-people-left-without-river\">or river people \u2013 without water</a>.</p> <p>In the midwest, the Norfolk Southern train derailment and chemical burn in East Palestine led to a major leak of hazardous butyl acrylate into the Ohio River, an already overly polluted watershed relied on by 5m people for drinking. The report calls on Congress to designate the Ohio River as a federally protected system and provide funds to upgrade monitoring equipment and cleanup the degraded waterway which is contaminated with legacy industrial chemicals including mercury and dioxin, as well as newer toxins like PFAS, Gen-X chemicals and acid mine drainage.</p>  <aside class=\"element element-pullquote element--inline\"> <blockquote> <p>We hope that agencies will work with tribes on tackling these challenges of how to manage and protect the Colorado River and Grand Canyon</p> <footer> <cite>Jakob Maase, Hopi Tribe</cite> </footer> </blockquote> </aside>  <p>\u201cThe economic future of communities along the Ohio River depends in large part on the protection and restoration of the water system,\u201d said Ben Hunkler from the Ohio River Valley Institute.</p> <p>Meanwhile, new mines threaten the future of the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/jun/22/alaska-haines-village-salmon-fishing-gold-mine\">Chilkat </a>and Klehini rivers in Alaska, relied upon by Indigenous villagers for food security and tribal culture, and the pristine <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/apr/01/georgia-okefenokee-swamp-twin-pines-mining\">Okefenokee swamp</a> that borders Georgia and Florida. In both cases, fish and wildlife habitat, water quality and climate buffering wetlands face imminent and irreversible dangers, if mining operations are given the go-ahead.</p> <p>\u201cThe natural riches of these lands and waters have allowed our people not only to survive, but to thrive, for untold generations. Endangering the Chilkat River ecosystem with a hard rock mine will have devastating effects on our tribal people that rely on the Chilkat River and Chilkat Valley as our sustainable food source,\u201d said Kimberley Strong, president of Chilkat Indian Village.</p> <p>\u201cThis report sounds the alarm. It is a national call to action to defend these rivers and all of the life they support,\u201d said Tom Kiernan, president of American Rivers. \u201cWhen rivers are sick, people suffer.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "A 277-mile stretch of the Colorado River that snakes through the iconic Grand Canyon is America\u2019s most endangered waterway, a new report has found.\nThe unique ecosystem and cultural heritage of the Grand Canyon is on the brink of collapse due to prolonged drought, rising temperatures and outdated river management, according to American Rivers, the conservation group that compiles the annual endangered list. Its future hangs in the balance, as the Biden administration is poised to change the way the Colorado River\u2019s dwindling water is divided. Further restrictions to the river flow risks turning the Grand Canyon into an ecological sacrifice zone, causing irreparable damage to wildlife, fish stocks and sacred sites, the report warns. \u201cThe Colorado River is on the brink of collapse and the Grand Canyon is in the crosshairs ... trying to solve the basin\u2019s water challenges by sacrificing the health of the Grand Canyon would be an utter tragedy,\u201d said Sinjin Eberle from American Rivers. \u201cThis is an all-hands-on-deck emergency.\u201d The annual snapshot of the country\u2019s most endangered rivers ranks the 10 US waterways at a crucial crossroads, where key decisions in the coming months will determine their long-term fate. Now in its 38th year, the annual ranking has helped spur the removal of outdated dams, clean-ups and protective designations, and the prevention of destructive development. The 2023 list includes rivers that traverse 17 states and scores of sovereign tribal nations, and supply drinking water, food, recreation and spiritual nourishment to millions of people. The waterways are under threat from mining, the climate breakdown, dams, industrial pollution and outdated river management practices that for too long have rebuffed traditional knowledge and sustainable techniques tried and tested by Indigenous Americans. Two-thirds of the country\u2019s water supply comes from its 3m miles of rivers, but almost half (44%) of waterways are too polluted for fishing and swimming, according to the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).\nStretching from the Rocky Mountains to the sea in Mexico, the 1,500-mile Colorado watershed provides drinking water to 40 million people \u2013 including some of America\u2019s most populous cities, such as Los Angeles and Phoenix, as well as 30 tribal nations \u2013 and irrigation water for almost 6m acres of ranch and farmland. The Grand Canyon in northern Arizona boasts one of the region\u2019s most biodiverse ecosystems and is considered one of the seven natural wonders of the world. The canyon connects the upper and lower basins of the Colorado River, and is bookended by two massive dams that form the largest reservoirs in the US, Lake Mead and Lake Powell. More than a dozen tribes and pueblos consider the Grand Canyon sacred, and have long acted as stewards in spite of the dams, development and pollution by US governments dating back to the first settlers. The climate crisis has led to prolonged drought across the entire river basin and reduced snowfall on the Rockies, which, along with chronic overuse, has left the reservoirs with historically low water levels. As a result, river managers have overseen changes to the quantity and flow of water supplies along the course of the river to protect the dams and other infrastructure. Restricting water flows has contributed to severe erosion of beaches within the canyon, impacting essential habitat for native fish and wildlife that play an important role in food security, Indigenous cultures and the recreation industry, according to the report.\nDespite some much needed respite after above-average rainfall and winter snowpack, the Biden administration is on the cusp of announcing major cuts to Colorado River water allocation which could further impact the supply and flow to the ecologically fragile canyon landscape. \u201cThe Colorado River is in poor health. We hope that agencies will listen and work with tribes on tackling these challenges of how to manage and protect the Colorado River and Grand Canyon,\u201d said Jakob Maase from the Hopi Tribe. Last year, the entire Colorado River was ranked as America\u2019s most endangered waterway, and this marks its 12th appearance on the list since 1991. The river has been so over-tapped since the mid 1900s that it runs dry in Mexico, leaving the Indigenous Cucap\u00e1 \u2013 or river people \u2013 without water. In the midwest, the Norfolk Southern train derailment and chemical burn in East Palestine led to a major leak of hazardous butyl acrylate into the Ohio River, an already overly polluted watershed relied on by 5m people for drinking. The report calls on Congress to designate the Ohio River as a federally protected system and provide funds to upgrade monitoring equipment and cleanup the degraded waterway which is contaminated with legacy industrial chemicals including mercury and dioxin, as well as newer toxins like PFAS, Gen-X chemicals and acid mine drainage.\n\u201cThe economic future of communities along the Ohio River depends in large part on the protection and restoration of the water system,\u201d said Ben Hunkler from the Ohio River Valley Institute. Meanwhile, new mines threaten the future of the Chilkat and Klehini rivers in Alaska, relied upon by Indigenous villagers for food security and tribal culture, and the pristine Okefenokee swamp that borders Georgia and Florida. In both cases, fish and wildlife habitat, water quality and climate buffering wetlands face imminent and irreversible dangers, if mining operations are given the go-ahead. \u201cThe natural riches of these lands and waters have allowed our people not only to survive, but to thrive, for untold generations. Endangering the Chilkat River ecosystem with a hard rock mine will have devastating effects on our tribal people that rely on the Chilkat River and Chilkat Valley as our sustainable food source,\u201d said Kimberley Strong, president of Chilkat Indian Village. \u201cThis report sounds the alarm. It is a national call to action to defend these rivers and all of the life they support,\u201d said Tom Kiernan, president of American Rivers. \u201cWhen rivers are sick, people suffer.\u201d", "attributes": {}, "published": true, "createdDate": "2023-04-18T04:01:34Z", "firstPublishedDate": "2023-04-18T11:33:16Z", "publishedDate": "2023-04-18T14:33:39Z", "lastModifiedDate": "2023-04-18T14:33:39Z", "contributors": [], "elements": [{"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>A 277-mile stretch of the Colorado River that snakes through the iconic Grand Canyon is America\u2019s most endangered waterway, a new report has found.</p>"}}, {"type": "rich-link", "assets": [], "richLinkTypeData": {"url": "https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/jan/18/freshwater-fish-contaminated-forever-chemicals", "originalUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/jan/18/freshwater-fish-contaminated-forever-chemicals", "linkText": "Freshwater fish more contaminated with \u2018forever chemicals\u2019 than in oceans", "linkPrefix": "Related: ", "role": "thumbnail"}}, {"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>The unique ecosystem and cultural heritage of the Grand Canyon is on the brink of collapse due to prolonged drought, rising temperatures and outdated river management, according to American Rivers, the conservation group that compiles <a href=\"https://www.americanrivers.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/04/AR_2023-Most-Endangered-Rivers_lowres-3.pdf\">the annual endangered list.</a></p> \n<p>Its future hangs in the balance, as the Biden administration is poised to change the way the Colorado River\u2019s dwindling water is divided. "world/2023/apr/18/our-country-is-sick-survivors-in-shock-after-deadly-myanmar-airstrike", "type": "article", "sectionId": "world", "sectionName": "World news", "webPublicationDate": "https://content.guardianapis.com/world/2023/apr/18/our-country-is-sick-survivors-in-shock-after-deadly-myanmar-airstrike", "fields": {"headline": "\u2018Our country is sick\u2019: survivors in shock after deadly Myanmar airstrike ", "standfirst": "<p>On 11 April 168 people were killed in deadliest attack since coup as locals were celebrating opening of village hall</p>", "trailText": "On 11 April 168 people were killed in deadliest attack since coup as locals were celebrating opening of village hall", "byline": "Min Ye Kyaw and Rebecca Ratcliffe", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"7494fbb4c662ec81f270ea25d7d05305a082d7b0\"> \n <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/7494fbb4c662ec81f270ea25d7d05305a082d7b0/213_59_807_484/500.jpg\" alt=\"Members of the people defense forces after an airstrike on Pa Zi Gyi village.\" width=\"500\" height=\"300\" class=\"gu-image\"> \n <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Members of the "body": "<p>It was supposed to be an opportunity for local people to gather and share food. After more than two years of turmoil following the 2021 military coup, hundreds of locals from neighbouring villages had been invited to Pa Zi Gyi to celebrate the opening of a new village hall, which had been set up by the junta\u2019s domestic opponents. Families \u2013 from young toddlers and pregnant women to grandparents \u2013 had set off early to attend.</p> \n<p>The gathering on 11 April quickly became the scene of the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/apr/12/myanmar-airstrike-on-civilians-sparks-global-outcry-as-witnesses-describe-attack\">deadliest airstrike by the Myanmar military since it seized power</a>; 168 people, including 40 children and 24 pregnant women, were killed, according to the national unity government (NUG), which was set up by elected politicians and activists to oppose the military. </p> \n<p>The attack began at 7.30am, when a military jet fighter bombed the area. Shortly afterwards, a helicopter gunship opened fire, according to the NUG. At 5.45pm, the junta\u2019s air force returned again and attacked rescuers as they tried to search for survivors and recover the dead. </p> \n<p>While the death toll was higher than previous strikes, such attacks are not uncommon. The military, which has struggled to suppress a determined armed resistance to its rule, has <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/jan/31/monster-from-the-sky-two-years-on-from-coup-myanmar-junta-increases-airstrikes-on-civilians\">increasingly launched airstrikes</a>, including against hospitals and schools.</p> \n<p>\u201cIt\u2019s not an isolated incident,\u201d said Aung Myo Min, the NUG\u2019s human rights minister.</p> \n<p>The NUG has recorded more than 600 airstrikes between October 2021 and March 2023, he said. \u201cWe have recorded that the military targeted civilians, with knowledge that these are civilians, because they targeted the religious buildings; in some cases the attack was on the temporary medical centres that are providing humanitarian assistance.\u201d</p> \n<figure class=\"element element-atom\"> <gu-atom data-atom-id=\"829bd860-4d93-4a36-86fc-14813893dd0d\" data-atom-type=\"media\"> \n  <div>\n   <iframe frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"true\" src=\"https://www.youtube-nocookie.com/embed/DFgNNQpm7uo?showinfo=0&amp;rel=0\"></iframe>\n  </div>\n </gu-atom> \n</figure> \n<p>A day before Pa Zi Gyi, the military bombed a high school in Webula, Chin state, according to the <a href=\"https://myanmar-now.org/en/news/airstrike-kills-at-least-nine-at-a-school-in-northern-chin-state/\">independent outlet Myanmar Now</a>. The school was closed at the time, but the headteacher and his wife, as well as seven others, were reportedly killed.</p> \n<p>The military says it is acting to restore peace and stability, and that its attack on Pa Zi Gyi was part of counter-terrorism operations.</p> \n<p>Last week\u2019s violence has prompted renewed calls for stronger measures to stop the flow of aviation fuel and funding to the military. The weakness of the international response was empowering the military to continue its attacks, said Thinzar Shunlei Yi, a prominent anti-coup activist. \u201cI think this is giving them impunity and a sense of confidence that the international community will always be paper tigers,\u201d she said. \u201cThis must end.\u201d</p> \n<p>Soe Naing*, a 31-year-old goat herder who survived the attack on Pa Zi Gyi, remembers sitting inside the new village hall, looking at his phone last Tuesday morning. The hall had been set up by the local People\u2019s Defence Force, the name given to volunteer armed groups that formed in response to military violence after the coup. Virtually everyone present was a civilian, Soe Naing said.</p> \n<p>He said his mother had come into the building and taken his three-year-old daughter outside to eat. Then he heard a loud bang; everything was covered in smoke. Outside, where tents had been set up for families to eat, bodies were scattered.</p> \n<p>\u201cI came running out of smoke and started looking for my daughter desperately,\u201d he said, adding that another military helicopter appeared and began shooting. He hid under a bridge. By the time he was able to emerge, the scene was one of devastation.</p> \n<p>\u201cI told myself to be strong. There was nothing much left, instead just piles of bodies on the ground, most dismembered, burnt and charred,\u201d he said. \u201cI then saw the tiny legs of an unborn child coming outside from a pregnant woman who was dead,.\u201d</p> \n<p>Soe Naing lost seven relatives in the attack, including his parents and his daughter, who he describes as a chatty girl who loved to sing. \u201cI still can\u2019t get her smiles out of my head yet,\u201d he said. She was loved by everyone, he said.</p> \n<p>Military-controlled Myawaddy TV said last week\u2019s attack had occurred outside Pa Zi Gyi village, on a building that the NUG planned to use. The military struck a weapons storage facility, it said, and explosions from such weapons had added to fatalities. Those who died were resistance fighters, the junta spokesperson Zaw Min Tun said, adding that \u201cpeople who were forced to support them probably died as well\u201d.</p> \n<p>The airstrike came just days ahead of Thingyan, the Burmese new year festival, normally a time of celebrations and splashing water in the streets. In Yangon, where the military held festive events in an apparent attempt to give an impression of normalcy, a sign was hung from a bridge that read: \u201cWhy are you dancing when the whole village is burning?\u201d</p> \n<p>Mass street protests are no longer possible in Yangon, which remains under military control.</p> \n<p>Thurein, a 29-year-old resident of Yangon\u2019s Mingalar Taungnyunt township, said the streets near to him were deserted. \u201cWe used to go to big pavilions and party with our friends. Now our country is sick, and there is nothing to celebrate,\u201d he said.</p> \n<p>The attack in Pa Zi Gyi was widely condemned, including by the US and the EU. However, activists say the international community has failed to take meaningful action.</p> \n<p>Montse Ferrer, Amnesty International\u2019s researcher and adviser on business and human rights, said that while some countries had imposed sanctions aimed at stopping jet fuel reaching the military, these generally targeted individual companies \u2013 something the military can easily evade. \u201cA company that today is called \u2018X\u2019, tomorrow is called \u2018Y\u2019 and the sanction in many ways is no longer effective,\u201d said Ferrer, who added that wider, sectoral sanctions were needed. Only Canada has taken this step.</p> \n<p>Days after the attack at Pa Zi Gyi, the village stands deserted. Funerals for the victims, including Soe Naing\u2019s relatives, have not yet been held because most of the residents worry about further military violence.</p> \n<p>\u201cTruthfully, no human being would engage in such a heinous act,\u201d said Soe Naing. \u201cThey were not born as human beings.\u201d</p> \n<p><em>*</em><em>Name has been changed for security reasons</em></p>", "wordcount": "1007", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T04:00:34Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T06:14:14Z", "productionOffice": "UK", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnfaq", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/7494fbb4c662ec81f270ea25d7d05305a082d7b0/213_59_807_484/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "It was supposed to be an opportunity for local people to gather and share food. After more than two years of turmoil following the 2021 military coup, hundreds of locals from neighbouring villages had been invited to Pa Zi Gyi to celebrate the opening of a new village hall, which had been set up by the junta\u2019s domestic opponents. Families \u2013 from young toddlers and pregnant women to grandparents \u2013 had set off early to attend. The gathering on 11 April quickly became the scene of the deadliest airstrike by the Myanmar military since it seized power; 168 people, including 40 children and 24 pregnant women, were killed, according to the national unity government (NUG), which was set up by elected politicians and activists to oppose the military. The attack began at 7.30am, when a military jet fighter bombed the area. Shortly afterwards, a helicopter gunship opened fire, according to the NUG. At 5.45pm, the junta\u2019s air force returned again and attacked rescuers as they tried to search for survivors and recover the dead. While the death toll was higher than previous strikes, such attacks are not uncommon. The military, which has struggled to suppress a determined armed resistance to its rule, has increasingly launched airstrikes, including against hospitals and schools. \u201cIt\u2019s not an isolated incident,\u201d said Aung Myo Min, the NUG\u2019s human rights minister. The NUG has recorded more than 600 airstrikes between October 2021 and March 2023, he said. \u201cWe have recorded that the military targeted civilians, with knowledge that these are civilians, because they targeted the religious buildings; in some cases the attack was on the temporary medical centres that are providing humanitarian assistance.\u201d A day before Pa Zi Gyi, the military bombed a high school in Webula, Chin state, according to the independent outlet Myanmar Now. The school was closed at the time, but the headteacher and his wife, as well as seven others, were reportedly killed. The military says it is acting to restore peace and stability, and that its attack on Pa Zi Gyi was part of counter-terrorism operations. Last week\u2019s violence has prompted renewed calls for stronger measures to stop the flow of aviation fuel and funding to the military. The weakness of the international response was empowering the military to continue its attacks, said Thinzar Shunlei Yi, a prominent anti-coup activist. \u201cI think this is giving them impunity and a sense of confidence that the international community will always be paper tigers,\u201d she said. \u201cThis must end.\u201d Soe Naing*, a 31-year-old goat herder who survived the attack on Pa Zi Gyi, remembers sitting inside the new village hall, looking at his phone last Tuesday morning. The hall had been set up by the local People\u2019s Defence Force, the name given to volunteer armed groups that formed in response to military violence after the coup. Virtually everyone present was a civilian, Soe Naing said. He said his mother had come into the building and taken his three-year-old daughter outside to eat. Then he heard a loud bang; everything was covered in smoke. Outside, where tents had been set up for families to eat, bodies were scattered. \u201cI came running out of smoke and started looking for my daughter desperately,\u201d he said, adding that another military helicopter appeared and began shooting. He hid under a bridge. By the time he was able to emerge, the scene was one of devastation. \u201cI told myself to be strong. There was nothing much left, instead just piles of bodies on the ground, most dismembered, burnt and charred,\u201d he said. \u201cI then saw the tiny legs of an unborn child coming outside from a pregnant woman who was dead,.\u201d Soe Naing lost seven relatives in the attack, including his parents and his daughter, who he describes as a chatty girl who loved to sing. \u201cI still can\u2019t get her smiles out of my head yet,\u201d he said. She was loved by everyone, he said. Military-controlled Myawaddy TV said last week\u2019s attack had occurred outside Pa Zi Gyi village, on a building that the NUG planned to use. The military struck a weapons storage facility, it said, and explosions from such weapons had added to fatalities. Those who died were resistance fighters, the junta spokesperson Zaw Min Tun said, adding that \u201cpeople who were forced to support them probably died as well\u201d. The airstrike came just days ahead of Thingyan, the Burmese new year festival, normally a time of celebrations and splashing water in the streets. In Yangon, where the military held festive events in an apparent attempt to give an impression of normalcy, a sign was hung from a bridge that read: \u201cWhy are you dancing when the whole village is burning?\u201d Mass street protests are no longer possible in Yangon, which remains under military control. Thurein, a 29-year-old resident of Yangon\u2019s Mingalar Taungnyunt township, said the streets near to him were deserted. \u201cWe used to go to big pavilions and party with our friends. Now our country is sick, and there is nothing to celebrate,\u201d he said. The attack in Pa Zi Gyi was widely condemned, including by the US and the EU. However, activists say the international community has failed to take meaningful action. Montse Ferrer, Amnesty International\u2019s researcher and adviser on business and human rights, said that while some countries had imposed sanctions aimed at stopping jet fuel reaching the military, these generally targeted individual companies \u2013 something the military can easily evade. \u201cA company that today is called \u2018X\u2019, tomorrow is called \u2018Y\u2019 and the sanction in many ways is no longer effective,\u201d said Ferrer, who added that wider, sectoral sanctions were needed. Only Canada has taken this step. Days after the attack at Pa Zi Gyi, the village stands deserted. Funerals for the victims, including Soe Naing\u2019s relatives, have not yet been held because most of the residents worry about further military violence. \u201cTruthfully, no human being would The military, which has struggled to suppress a determined armed resistance to its rule, has <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/jan/31/monster-from-the-sky-two-years-on-from-coup-myanmar-junta-increases-airstrikes-on-civilians\">increasingly launched airstrikes</a>, including against hospitals and schools.</p> \n<p>\u201cIt\u2019s not an isolated incident,\u201d said Aung Myo Min, the NUG\u2019s human rights minister.</p> \n<p>The NUG has recorded more than 600 airstrikes between October 2021 and March 2023, he said. \u201cWe have recorded that the military targeted civilians, with knowledge that these are civilians, because they targeted the religious buildings; in some cases the attack was on the temporary medical centres that are providing humanitarian assistance.\u201d</p>"}}, {"type": "contentatom", "assets": [], "contentAtomTypeData": {"atomId": "829bd860-4d93-4a36-86fc-14813893dd0d", "atomType": "media", "isMandatory": true}}, {"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>A day before Pa Zi Gyi, the military bombed a high school in Webula, Chin state, according to the <a href=\"https://myanmar-now.org/en/news/airstrike-kills-at-least-nine-at-a-school-in-northern-chin-state/\">independent outlet Myanmar Now</a>. The school was closed at the time, but the headteacher and his wife, as well as seven others, were reportedly killed.</p> \n<p>The military says it is acting to restore peace and stability, and that its attack on Pa Zi Gyi was part of counter-terrorism operations.</p> \n<p>Last week\u2019s violence has prompted renewed calls for stronger measures to stop the flow of aviation fuel and funding to the military. The weakness of the international response was empowering the military to continue its attacks, said Thinzar Shunlei Yi, a prominent anti-coup activist. \u201cI think this is giving them impunity and a sense of confidence that the international community will always be paper tigers,\u201d she said. \u201cThis must end.\u201d</p> \n<p>Soe Naing*, a 31-year-old goat herder who survived the attack on Pa Zi Gyi, remembers sitting inside the new village hall, looking at his phone last Tuesday morning. The hall had been set up by the local People\u2019s Defence Force, the name given to volunteer armed groups that formed in response to military violence after the coup. Virtually everyone present was a civilian, Soe Naing said.</p> \n<p>He said his mother had come into the building and taken his three-year-old daughter outside to eat. Then he heard a loud bang; everything was covered in smoke. Outside, where tents had been set up for families to eat, bodies were scattered.</p> \n<p>\u201cI came running out of smoke and started looking for my daughter desperately,\u201d he said, adding that another military helicopter appeared and began shooting. He hid under a bridge. By the time he was able to emerge, the scene was one of devastation.</p> \n<p>\u201cI told myself to be strong. There was nothing much left, instead just piles of bodies on the ground, most dismembered, burnt and charred,\u201d he said. \u201cI then saw the tiny legs of an unborn child coming outside from a pregnant woman who was dead,.\u201d</p> \n<p>Soe Naing lost seven relatives in the attack, including his parents and his daughter, who he describes as a chatty girl who loved to sing. \u201cI still can\u2019t get her smiles out of my head yet,\u201d he said. She was loved by everyone, he said.</p> \n<p>Military-controlled Myawaddy TV said last week\u2019s attack had occurred outside Pa Zi Gyi village, on a building that the NUG planned to use. The military struck a weapons storage facility, it said, and explosions from such weapons had added to fatalities. Those who died were resistance fighters, the junta spokesperson Zaw Min Tun said, adding that \u201cpeople who were forced to support them probably died as well\u201d.</p> \n<p>The airstrike came just days ahead of Thingyan, the Burmese new year festival, normally a time of celebrations and splashing water in the streets. In Yangon, where the military held festive events in an apparent attempt to give an impression of normalcy, a sign was hung from a bridge that read: \u201cWhy are you dancing when the whole village is burning?\u201d</p> \n<p>Mass street protests are no longer possible in Yangon, which remains under military control.</p> \n<p>Thurein, a 29-year-old resident of Yangon\u2019s Mingalar Taungnyunt township, said the streets near to him were deserted. \u201cWe used to go to big pavilions and party with our friends. Now our country is sick, and there is nothing to celebrate,\u201d he said.</p> \n<p>The attack in Pa Zi Gyi was widely condemned, including by the US and the EU. However, activists say the international community has failed to take meaningful action.</p> \n<p>Montse Ferrer, Amnesty International\u2019s researcher and adviser on business and human rights, said that while some countries had imposed sanctions aimed at stopping jet fuel reaching the military, these generally targeted individual companies \u2013 something the military can easily evade. \u201cA company that today is called \u2018X\u2019, tomorrow is called \u2018Y\u2019 and the sanction in many ways is no longer effective,\u201d said Ferrer, who added that wider, sectoral sanctions were needed. Only Canada has taken this step.</p> \n<p>Days after the attack at Pa Zi Gyi, the village stands deserted. Funerals for the victims, including Soe Naing\u2019s relatives, have not yet been held because most of the residents worry about further military violence.</p> \n<p>\u201cTruthfully, no human being would engage in such a heinous act,\u201d said Soe Naing. \u201cThey were not born as human beings.\u201d</p> \n<p><em>*</em><em>Name has been changed for security reasons</em></p>"}}]}], "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnjpc", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/7ddcc0301e15c8971e2b7b859330e36ea8f79542/0_0_7156_4294/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "The unexpected departure of Karen Andrews from shadow cabinet necessitated a wider reshuffle, but Peter Dutton has taken to the task with all the subtlety of the proverbial sledgehammer to a walnut. When Julian Leeser announced his departure from the frontbench last week to campaign in favour of the Indigenous voice, it immediately put the Coalition\u2019s two Indigenous senators \u2013 Jacinta Price and Kerrynne Liddle \u2013 in the frame for promotion. Although both are first-term senators, the Coalition could benefit from their experience throughout the voice referendum debate, in which both are happy to argue the case for no. But there was a more cautious approach considered: to promote one to shadow assistant minister for Indigenous Australians, while transferring the shadow minister\u2019s responsibility to an existing cabinet member, such as Anne Ruston. In elevating Price to the shadow minister role, parachuting her straight into cabinet, Dutton has opted for a high-risk strategy of maximising the Coalition\u2019s brand differentiation with Labor and locking in hard against the voice. Perhaps it should be unsurprising that in a reshuffle sparked by taking the middle-of-the-road option of a free vote off the table, Dutton has doubled down by promoting a strident opponent of the voice all the way into shadow cabinet. Price got to work early, attacking the referendum proposal which she said some Indigenous communities felt was being pushed by \u201cthose who have long-held positions within the Aboriginal industry\u201d. Price declared it was \u201cutterly ridiculous\u201d that in South Australia people \u201ccan write a statutory declaration and claim to be Indigenous\u201d and have input into that state\u2019s voice, adding this was \u201cdeeply concerning\u201d. The other remarkable aspect of Price\u2019s promotion is that she is the seventh National in cabinet \u2013 one more than the quota guarantees the junior member of the Coalition. With 21 Nationals in parliament, one-third are now in the shadow cabinet. That is a win for the Nationals leader, David Littleproud. He was quick to declare it a \u201cproud day\u201d and credited his party with having \u201cled the debate\u201d on the voice by opposing it in November. Sign up for a weekly email featuring our best reads The Nationals\u2019 influence is expanding not because their numbers in the Coalition party room require it \u2013 in fact, they lost an MP, Andrew Gee, over the voice in December. Rather, it is because Dutton\u2019s conservatism puts him naturally closer on social issues to their regions-first ideology than to Liberal moderates within his own party. After the Aston byelection defeat, Dutton declared that the Coalition is \u201cthe party of regional and rural Australia\u201d and that too much of Labor\u2019s effort is \u201cconcentrated on capital cities\u201d. On Tuesday Dutton said he wants his \u201cbest people on the paddock\u201d and it would be \u201csilly to overlook [Price\u2019s] obvious talent\u201d because of a quota. Reasonable minds can differ about the merit of a candidate for any job \u2013 and in the context of a reshuffle \u201cobvious talent\u201d can just mean whoever suits the leader most. Littleproud said Price\u2019s promotion means that women hold 60% of the party\u2019s shadow cabinet positions. He praised the \u201cdiversity\u201d, experience and \u201ccommonsense\u201d the party brings to Canberra. There\u2019s nothing wrong with the Nationals representing a particular constituency, but the non-Labor side of politics in Australia has succeeded over many decades because it combines the strength of the conservative and liberal political tendencies. But liberals are increasingly finding a home elsewhere: with the teal independents in the seven inner-city seats they now hold; or with Labor, which won blue-ribbon seats such as Higgins, Bennelong and now Aston; or the Greens, who won Ryan and Brisbane from the Liberals. Who is left to represent the experience of the parts of the country the Coalition needs to win to get back in government? A rump of moderates who spoke in favour of a free vote on the voice in shadow cabinet and a few more committed advocates including MP Bridget Archer and Senator Andrew Bragg. Price may speak for some Indigenous people who feel the voice will make little practical difference, but public opinion polling and the consensus in the Uluru statement from the heart would suggest this is a minority view. By deriding those who disagree with her as the \u201cAboriginal industry\u201d, Price is hardly the model of good faith that opponents of the voice, including Dutton, say must be a feature of the debate. He praised the \u201cdiversity\u201d, experience and \u201ccommonsense\u201d the party brings to Canberra.</p> \n<p>There\u2019s nothing wrong with the Nationals representing a particular constituency, but the non-Labor side of politics in Australia has succeeded over many decades because it combines the strength of the conservative and liberal political tendencies.</p> \n<p>But liberals are increasingly finding a home elsewhere: with the teal independents in the seven inner-city seats they now hold; or with Labor, which won blue-ribbon seats such as Higgins, Bennelong and now Aston; or the Greens, who won Ryan and Brisbane from the Liberals.</p> \n<p>Who is left to represent the experience of the parts of the country the Coalition needs to win to get back in government?</p> \n<p>A rump of <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/07/at-least-three-senior-liberals-pushed-back-against-indigenous-voice-opposition-in-shadow-cabinet-meeting\">moderates who spoke in favour of a free vote on the voice in shadow cabinet</a> and a few more committed advocates including MP Bridget Archer and Senator Andrew Bragg.</p> \n<p>Price may speak for some Indigenous people who feel the voice will make little practical difference, but public opinion polling and the consensus in the Uluru statement from the heart would suggest this is a minority view.</p> \n<p>By deriding those who disagree with her as the \u201cAboriginal industry\u201d, Price is hardly the model of good faith that opponents of the voice, including Dutton, say must be a feature of the debate.</p> "australia-news", "webTitle": "Australia news", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/australia-news", "code": "default"}]}, "isHosted": "sectionId": "australia-news", "sectionName": "Australia news", "webPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T03:09:50Z", "webTitle": "This is not Utopia: how will the inland rail project stand up to real-life scrutiny? | Gabrielle Chan", "webUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/18/this-is-not-utopia-how-will-the-inland-rail-project-stand-up-to-real-life-scrutiny", "apiUrl": "https://content.guardianapis.com/australia-news/2023/apr/18/this-is-not-utopia-how-will-the-inland-rail-project-stand-up-to-real-life-scrutiny", "fields": {"headline": "This is not Utopia: how will the inland rail project stand up to real-life scrutiny?", "standfirst": "<p>The 1,700km railway is being touted as a nation-building project, so we need to get the planning right</p><ul><li><a 1700km railway is being touted as a nation-building project, so we need to get the planning right", "byline": "Gabrielle Chan", "main": "<figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"4e8430d204d0647642f4e4256a8d77326ad72cb0\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/4e8430d204d0647642f4e4256a8d77326ad72cb0/0_276_3992_2395/1000.jpg\" alt=\"A freight train sits at </figure>", "body": "<p>The public service comedy Utopia has a lot to answer for when it comes to sullying the name of \u201cnation-building\u201d rail projects, after it devoted an <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8av3knflbQo\">episode</a> to the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/mar/07/nsw-plan-for-population-growth-outside-sydney-to-fail-without-high-speed-rail-says-expert-behind-strategy\">perennial political story of high-speed rail</a>.</p> <p>That may be why the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2019/aug/05/too-good-to-be-true-australias-high-speed-rail-dream-leaves-a-bitter-taste\">high-speed rail passenger concept</a> is often mixed up with the inland rail freight line, a less exciting but much more real plan to build a 1,727km line connecting Melbourne to Brisbane.</p> <p>But there are plenty of reasons to get your head around it, given it is likely to take at least the next decade to complete and will cost more than the current $31bn blowout in the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/astonishing-cost-of-inland-rail-doubles-to-30bn-as-review-savages-coalition-over-project\">recent review by Kerry Schott</a>.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/16/inland-rail-review-supports-concerns-raised-by-regional-communities\">Inland rail review supports concerns raised by regional communities</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Last year, when <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/ng-interactive/2022/jan/25/trouble-on-the-tracks-is-australias-40bn-inland-rail-project-going-off-the-rails\">the Rural Network took a deep dive</a> into the project, it was enlightening to understand <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/25/australias-inland-rail-a-long-held-dream-but-for-whom-and-at-what-cost\">how common the themes were among disparate communities along the track</a>.</p> <p>Cameron Simpkins, a former project director for the Albury to Parkes section, backed in those communities when he <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/26/if-australias-inland-rail-is-a-game-changer-why-are-we-shortchanging-it\">wrote last year in Guardian Australia</a> that if inland rail is indeed going to be nation-building, then it should be done properly. He predicted a more realistic price tag than the then $14bn budget was $40bn. It was eerily prescient.</p> <p>This week, Simpkins told me while it was great to feel vindicated, it should not have taken so long.</p> <p>\u201cI\u2019m disappointed that it\u2019s taken an external party, following on from me going public, for these people to suddenly wake up and realise that their work is not as good as they think it was,\u201d he said.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/sep/14/sign-up-for-rural-network-guardian-australia-email-newsletter-about-regional-affairs?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up to receive Guardian Australia\u2019s fortnightly Rural Network email newsletter</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>Yet many critics, even ones supportive of the rail, were dismissed by National party ministers keen to promote the project without question. They were also dismissed by the commonwealth-owned Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC), the body responsible for the governance and delivery of the inland rail.</p> <p>Here are some of the key questions addressed by the Schott review.</p> <h2>What is the price tag?</h2> <p>Schott compares the distance to be traversed by the inland rail to a journey between London and the Ukraine border. It crosses three states and the lands of at least 11 First Nations groups and 36 local government areas. </p> <p>The scope of the project makes it hard to cost. \u201cThere is insufficient certainty about the completion date and the final cost to have confidence in the current estimates,\u201d Schott wrote.</p> <h2>How well was it planned?</h2> <p>Not very well. Schott said the challenges of delivering the project \u201cdo not seem to have been fully appreciated by either ARTC or its shareholder [the federal government] when it was first given the go-ahead\u201d.</p> <p>Many communities along the route say they engaged with ARTC but their misgivings about noise or the proposed route cleaving towns in two were ignored in the rush to get the project started.</p> <p>The Narrabri civil engineer and water irrigation specialist <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/16/inland-rail-review-supports-concerns-raised-by-regional-communities\">Jim Purcell\u2019s sentiment was typical of communities along the tracks</a>: if it\u2019s such an important project, why not do it right the first time? Purcell and other Narrabri residents were concerned the rail would exacerbate the risk from flooding. When their concerns were put to the then infrastructure minister Barnaby Joyce, he said <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/feb/10/what-the-hell-were-you-thinking-fighting-flares-in-narrabri-over-inland-rail\">consideration of alternative routes would take too long</a>.</p> <h2>What will it carry?</h2> <p>According to Schott, by 2050, 70% of the freight to be carried on Inland Rail will be for domestic use, including household goods and groceries produced in Australia and consumed in our major cities.</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://apo.org.au/sites/default/files/resource-files/2015-08/apo-nid220986_1.pdf\">2015 business case</a> prepared by the former Nationals leader John Anderson estimated that \u201cover half of the total demand for Inland Rail by volume\u201d would come from coal. </p> <p>There is not a lot of other information in the public realm about who the freight customers will be and how the goods will move, except that they have to make the journey in 24 hours to compete against the trucking industry. </p> <h2>Is it economically and environmentally sound?</h2> <p>One of the selling points of the project is to ease traffic congestion around east coast cities and lower transport emissions. <a href=\"https://www.inlandrail.gov.au/understanding-inland-rail/why-inland-rail/environment\">Government</a> forecasts say that by 2050 the inland rail will cut carbon emissions by 750,000 tonnes a year and reduce the number of trucks on the road by 200,000. </p> <p>But Schott notes both the inland rail project and the operating business of ARTC are facing more pressing challenges. ARTC currently relies heavily on transporting coal \u2013 according to <a href=\"https://www.artc.com.au/uploads/ARTC-Annual-Report-2021-2022.pdf\">its 2021-22 annual report</a>, 63% of its revenue related to the coal industry.</p> <p>In that same report, ARTC is hoping markets developed around the inland rail will \u201calso reduce the risks associated with declining coal production\u201d.</p> <p>So the business case for the inland rail relied on the transport of coal but ARTC is relying on it to generate revenue to make up for the decline of the coal industry. The project may be as much a lifeline for the ARTC economically as it was for the National party politically.</p> <h2>Can we do big infrastructure projects as a country?</h2> <p>Anyone who has completed the smallest building task in the last few years knows building costs have blown out. The inland rail is just the latest in a long list of blowouts, the latest being the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/13/nsw-government-launches-sydney-metro-review-amid-21bn-cost-blowout\">Sydney Metro program</a>.</p> <p>Big infrastructure projects, many of them related to transport, are <a href=\"https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/warning-that-more-mega-projects-will-run-late-over-budget-20221213-p5c5x1.html\">increasingly crimped</a> by a mix of labour shortages, rising construction material costs and a concentration of projects in the eastern states, <a href=\"https://www.infrastructureaustralia.gov.au/listing/media-release/Infrastructure-market-capacity-2022-risks-to-project-delivery-increase-as-5-year-investment-climbs-by-%2415b\">according to Infrastructure Australia</a>.</p> <h2>Do regional communities support it?</h2> <p>Regional people seem to like the theory, if not the reality, of the project.</p> <p>Community confidence in the management of the ARTC, following Schott\u2019s damning report, is going to be just one of the challenges ahead.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/albanese-government-commits-to-half-of-inland-rail-project-after-blowouts-delay-and-mismanagement\">Albanese government commits to half of Inland Rail project after blowouts, delay and mismanagement</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Inland rail staff are apparently gutted by the review and there is talk of internal restructures, following a recommendation to <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/albanese-government-commits-to-half-of-inland-rail-project-after-blowouts-delay-and-mismanagement\">focus on the southern end of the project from Melbourne to Parkes.</a></p> <p>For all their concerns, regional communities are generally supportive of the concept.</p> <p>They get the freight requirements across such a big country and they assume <em>someone</em> has done their homework on the business case, which may be a triumph of optimism over experience.</p> <p>That latent support may be why both sides of politics support the inland rail. Anthony Albanese <a href=\"https://anthonyalbanese.com.au/opinion-inland-rail-is-a-train-wreck-this-is-the-only-way-to-get-it-back-on-track-10-daily-monday-29-april-2019\">supported it right through opposition</a>, though he was critical of the planning. It now falls to his government to get it moving.</p> <ul> <li><p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/sep/14/sign-up-for-rural-network-guardian-australia-email-newsletter-about-regional-affairs?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for the Rural Network email newsletter</a></p></li> <li><p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/groups/guardianaustraliaruralnetwork\">Join the Rural Network group on Facebook to be part of the community</a></p></li> </ul>", "wordcount": "1081", "commentCloseDate": "2023-04-18T07:00:00Z", "commentable": "true", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T03:09:50Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T12:32:51Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnf7q", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/4e8430d204d0647642f4e4256a8d77326ad72cb0/0_276_3992_2395/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "The public service comedy Utopia has a lot to answer for when it comes to sullying the name of \u201cnation-building\u201d rail projects, after it devoted an episode to the perennial political story of high-speed rail.
