{"aspectRatio": "5:3", "width": 3992, "height": 2395, "isMaster": true}}], "imageTypeData": {"caption": "The Inland Rail project will likely take at least the next decade to complete and cost more than the $31bn blowout in the recent review by Kerry Schott.", "displayCredit": true, "credit": "Photograph: Mike Bowers/The Guardian", "source": "The Guardian", "photographer": "Mike Bowers", "alt": "A freight train sits at signals outside Parkes, Australia", "mediaId": "4e8430d204d0647642f4e4256a8d77326ad72cb0", "mediaApiUri": "https://api.media.gutools.co.uk/images/4e8430d204d0647642f4e4256a8d77326ad72cb0", "imageType": "Photograph"}}]}, "body": [{"id": "643ccf2a8f0885230b2dc4d1", "bodyHtml": "<p>The public service comedy Utopia has a lot to answer for when it comes to sullying the name of \u201cnation-building\u201d rail projects, after it devoted an <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8av3knflbQo\">episode</a> to the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/mar/07/nsw-plan-for-population-growth-outside-sydney-to-fail-without-high-speed-rail-says-expert-behind-strategy\">perennial political story of high-speed rail</a>.</p> <p>That may be why the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2019/aug/05/too-good-to-be-true-australias-high-speed-rail-dream-leaves-a-bitter-taste\">high-speed rail passenger concept</a> is often mixed up with the inland rail freight line, a less exciting but much more real plan to build a 1,727km line connecting Melbourne to Brisbane.</p> <p>But there are plenty of reasons to get your head around it, given it is likely to take at least the next decade to complete and will cost more than the current $31bn blowout in the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/astonishing-cost-of-inland-rail-doubles-to-30bn-as-review-savages-coalition-over-project\">recent review by Kerry Schott</a>.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/16/inland-rail-review-supports-concerns-raised-by-regional-communities\">Inland rail review supports concerns raised by regional communities</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Last year, when <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/ng-interactive/2022/jan/25/trouble-on-the-tracks-is-australias-40bn-inland-rail-project-going-off-the-rails\">the Rural Network took a deep dive</a> into the project, it was enlightening to understand <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/25/australias-inland-rail-a-long-held-dream-but-for-whom-and-at-what-cost\">how common the themes were among disparate communities along the track</a>.</p> <p>Cameron Simpkins, a former project director for the Albury to Parkes section, backed in those communities when he <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/jan/26/if-australias-inland-rail-is-a-game-changer-why-are-we-shortchanging-it\">wrote last year in Guardian Australia</a> that if inland rail is indeed going to be nation-building, then it should be done properly. He predicted a more realistic price tag than the then $14bn budget was $40bn. It was eerily prescient.</p> <p>This week, Simpkins told me while it was great to feel vindicated, it should not have taken so long.</p> <p>\u201cI\u2019m disappointed that it\u2019s taken an external party, following on from me going public, for these people to suddenly wake up and realise that their work is not as good as they think it was,\u201d he said.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/sep/14/sign-up-for-rural-network-guardian-australia-email-newsletter-about-regional-affairs?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up to receive Guardian Australia\u2019s fortnightly Rural Network email newsletter</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>Yet many critics, even ones supportive of the rail, were dismissed by National party ministers keen to promote the project without question. They were also dismissed by the commonwealth-owned Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC), the body responsible for the governance and delivery of the inland rail.</p> <p>Here are some of the key questions addressed by the Schott review.</p> <h2>What is the price tag?</h2> <p>Schott compares the distance to be traversed by the inland rail to a journey between London and the Ukraine border. It crosses three states and the lands of at least 11 First Nations groups and 36 local government areas. </p> <p>The scope of the project makes it hard to cost. \u201cThere is insufficient certainty about the completion date and the final cost to have confidence in the current estimates,\u201d Schott wrote.</p> <h2>How well was it planned?</h2> <p>Not very well. Schott said the challenges of delivering the project \u201cdo not seem to have been fully appreciated by either ARTC or its shareholder [the federal government] when it was first given the go-ahead\u201d.</p> <p>Many communities along the route say they engaged with ARTC but their misgivings about noise or the proposed route cleaving towns in two were ignored in the rush to get the project started.</p> <p>The Narrabri civil engineer and water irrigation specialist <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/16/inland-rail-review-supports-concerns-raised-by-regional-communities\">Jim Purcell\u2019s sentiment was typical of communities along the tracks</a>: if it\u2019s such an important project, why not do it right the first time? Purcell and other Narrabri residents were concerned the rail would exacerbate the risk from flooding. When their concerns were put to the then infrastructure minister Barnaby Joyce, he said <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/feb/10/what-the-hell-were-you-thinking-fighting-flares-in-narrabri-over-inland-rail\">consideration of alternative routes would take too long</a>.</p> <h2>What will it carry?</h2> <p>According to Schott, by 2050, 70% of the freight to be carried on Inland Rail will be for domestic use, including household goods and groceries produced in Australia and consumed in our major cities.</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://apo.org.au/sites/default/files/resource-files/2015-08/apo-nid220986_1.pdf\">2015 business case</a> prepared by the former Nationals leader John Anderson estimated that \u201cover half of the total demand for Inland Rail by volume\u201d would come from coal. </p> <p>There is not a lot of other information in the public realm about who the freight customers will be and how the goods will move, except that they have to make the journey in 24 hours to compete against the trucking industry. </p> <h2>Is it economically and environmentally sound?</h2> <p>One of the selling points of the project is to ease traffic congestion around east coast cities and lower transport emissions. <a href=\"https://www.inlandrail.gov.au/understanding-inland-rail/why-inland-rail/environment\">Government</a> forecasts say that by 2050 the inland rail will cut carbon emissions by 750,000 tonnes a year and reduce the number of trucks on the road by 200,000. </p> <p>But Schott notes both the inland rail project and the operating business of ARTC are facing more pressing challenges. ARTC currently relies heavily on transporting coal \u2013 according to <a href=\"https://www.artc.com.au/uploads/ARTC-Annual-Report-2021-2022.pdf\">its 2021-22 annual report</a>, 63% of its revenue related to the coal industry.</p> <p>In that same report, ARTC is hoping markets developed around the inland rail will \u201calso reduce the risks associated with declining coal production\u201d.</p> <p>So the business case for the inland rail relied on the transport of coal but ARTC is relying on it to generate revenue to make up for the decline of the coal industry. The project may be as much a lifeline for the ARTC economically as it was for the National party politically.</p> <h2>Can we do big infrastructure projects as a country?</h2> <p>Anyone who has completed the smallest building task in the last few years knows building costs have blown out. The inland rail is just the latest in a long list of blowouts, the latest being the <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/13/nsw-government-launches-sydney-metro-review-amid-21bn-cost-blowout\">Sydney Metro program</a>.</p> <p>Big infrastructure projects, many of them related to transport, are <a href=\"https://www.smh.com.au/national/nsw/warning-that-more-mega-projects-will-run-late-over-budget-20221213-p5c5x1.html\">increasingly crimped</a> by a mix of labour shortages, rising construction material costs and a concentration of projects in the eastern states, <a href=\"https://www.infrastructureaustralia.gov.au/listing/media-release/Infrastructure-market-capacity-2022-risks-to-project-delivery-increase-as-5-year-investment-climbs-by-%2415b\">according to Infrastructure Australia</a>.</p> <h2>Do regional communities support it?</h2> <p>Regional people seem to like the theory, if not the reality, of the project.</p> <p>Community confidence in the management of the ARTC, following Schott\u2019s damning report, is going to be just one of the challenges ahead.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/albanese-government-commits-to-half-of-inland-rail-project-after-blowouts-delay-and-mismanagement\">Albanese government commits to half of Inland Rail project after blowouts, delay and mismanagement</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Inland rail staff are apparently gutted by the review and there is talk of internal restructures, following a recommendation to <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/albanese-government-commits-to-half-of-inland-rail-project-after-blowouts-delay-and-mismanagement\">focus on the southern end of the project from Melbourne to Parkes.</a></p> <p>For all their concerns, regional communities are generally supportive of the concept.</p> <p>They get the freight requirements across such a big country and they assume <em>someone</em> has done their homework on the business case, which may be a triumph of optimism over experience.</p> <p>That latent support may be why both sides of politics support the inland rail. Anthony Albanese <a href=\"https://anthonyalbanese.com.au/opinion-inland-rail-is-a-train-wreck-this-is-the-only-way-to-get-it-back-on-track-10-daily-monday-29-april-2019\">supported it right through opposition</a>, though he was critical of the planning. It now falls to his government to get it moving.</p> <ul> <li><p><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/sep/14/sign-up-for-rural-network-guardian-australia-email-newsletter-about-regional-affairs?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for the Rural Network email newsletter</a></p></li> <li><p><a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/groups/guardianaustraliaruralnetwork\">Join the Rural Network group on Facebook to be part of the community</a></p></li> </ul>", "bodyTextSummary": "The public service comedy Utopia has a lot to answer for when it comes to sullying the name of \u201cnation-building\u201d rail projects, after it devoted an episode to the perennial political story of high-speed rail. think third-party rental application platforms require too much private information from them but many still feel pressured to use them to find a home, a new report has found.</p> <p>In a national survey of 1,020 renters on their use of rental technology, consumer advocacy organisation Choice found 60% of renters were uncomfortable with the amount and type of information they were asked for when applying for a rental using rent-tech platforms. Almost one-third (29%) said they had at least once chosen not to apply for a rental because they did not trust the tech company taking their application with their data, and 41% said they felt pressured to use it anyway.</p> <p>The report, released on Tuesday, said renters were very concerned about data insecurity and invasive, automated decision-making technologies used in the rental application process. Among renters between 18 and 34 years old, 29% reported that their rental application had been scored against other prospective tenants to determine whether they would get a property.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/feb/20/its-worrying-victorias-affordable-rental-housing-to-be-allocated-by-ballot-rather-than-need\">Advocates criticise Victoria\u2019s decision to allocate affordable housing by ballot rather than need</a> </p> </aside>  <p>\u201cA sore lack of regulation in this market means these automated decision-making systems could increase barriers and discrimination for renters, potentially excluding some people from housing,\u201d Kate Bower, a Choice consumer data advocate, said.</p> <p>The Choice report follows <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/nov/17/imperfect-match-australian-renters-in-the-dark-over-use-of-data-by-tech-company-snug\">a Guardian Australia investigation last year</a> that revealed the potentially discriminatory use of applicants\u2019 personal data by Australian rent-tech company Snug. The company\u2019s rental application platform uses opaque algorithms to \u201cscore\u201d renters against properties, which gave renters a higher score when they offered to pay more rent.</p> <p>Privacy experts, academics and renters\u2019 advocates expressed concern after analysis of Snug\u2019s patent application suggested the company\u2019s intention was to collect wide-ranging information from users, including friend lists, social media networks and ratings on third-party platforms such as Airbnb and Uber, and to develop a kind of rental credit system.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon</a></strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\"> </a><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">email newsletters for your daily news roundup</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>Snug denied that the \u201cmatch score\u201d function facilitated rental bidding and said its mission was to \u201cmake renting easier\u201d thanks to a platform designed \u201cto facilitate a better relationship between renters and agents\u201d.</p> <p>The company did not disclose which data points went into its match score, and its spokesperson said the company had \u201cno foreseeable plans to implement further permissible data attributes contained conceptually in the patent application\u201d. The company\u2019s match score appears to no longer be visibly influenced by the amount of rent offered for a property.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/mar/31/australian-renters-face-surging-costs-after-end-of-national-affordability-scheme\">Australian renters face surging costs after end of national affordability scheme</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Snug was also contracted late last year by the Victorian government\u2019s social housing agency, Homes Victoria, to create <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/feb/20/its-worrying-victorias-affordable-rental-housing-to-be-allocated-by-ballot-rather-than-need\">a purpose-built platform to take applications for the government\u2019s affordable housing program</a>, with homes to be allocated by ballot.</p> <p>The Choice survey found the most commonly used third-party platforms were 2Apply and Ignite (formerly 1Form), followed by rent.com.au and Snug.</p> <p>Renters said they felt pressured to pay for a background check by many of these platforms in the hope their application would stand out in an increasingly overheated rental market, with 25% reporting they had forked out the money.</p> <p>\u201cFinding a home as a renter is already an incredibly difficult and draining experience,\u2019 Bower said. \u201cOur research found RentTech platforms are taking advantage of people\u2019s basic need for a roof over their heads to collect excessive data and charge unfair fees.</p> <p>\u201cAs the risk of data misuse and data breaches continues to grow, so too does the risk to consumers. The government needs to act quickly and strengthen Australia\u2019s privacy laws to ensure they are fit-for-purpose and protect consumers effectively.\u201d</p> <p>Choice is calling for reforms to the Privacy Act that ensure renters are protected, a federal inquiry into automated decision-making technology, and state governments to modernise their tenancy laws to prevent harms related to emerging rental technologies.</p>", "wordcount": "622", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T02:19:03Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T02:20:41Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnkxx", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/161137bb3088233c3813f465b557b458ec798b54/0_0_8192_4918/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Nearly two-thirds of renters think third-party rental application platforms require too much private information from them but many still feel pressured to use them to find a home, a new report has found. In a national survey of 1,020 renters on their use of rental technology, consumer advocacy organisation Choice found 60% of renters were uncomfortable with the amount and type of information they were asked for when applying for a rental using rent-tech platforms. Almost one-third (29%) said they had at least once chosen not to apply for a rental because they did not trust the tech company taking their application with their data, and 41% said they felt pressured to use it anyway. The report, released on Tuesday, said renters were very concerned about data insecurity and invasive, automated decision-making technologies used in the rental application process. Among renters between 18 and 34 years old, 29% reported that their rental application had been scored against other prospective tenants to determine whether they would get a property. \u201cA sore lack of regulation in this market means these automated decision-making systems could increase barriers and discrimination for renters, potentially excluding some people from housing,\u201d Kate Bower, a Choice consumer data advocate, said. The Choice report follows a Guardian Australia investigation last year that revealed the potentially discriminatory use of applicants\u2019 personal data by Australian rent-tech company Snug. The company\u2019s rental application platform uses opaque algorithms to \u201cscore\u201d renters against properties, which gave renters a higher score when they offered to pay more rent. Privacy experts, academics and renters\u2019 advocates expressed concern after analysis of Snug\u2019s patent application suggested the company\u2019s intention was to collect wide-ranging information from users, including friend lists, social media networks and ratings on third-party platforms such as Airbnb and Uber, and to develop a kind of rental credit system. Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Snug denied that the \u201cmatch score\u201d function facilitated rental bidding and said its mission was to \u201cmake renting easier\u201d thanks to a platform designed \u201cto facilitate a better relationship between renters and agents\u201d. The company did not disclose which data points went into its match score, and its spokesperson said the company had \u201cno foreseeable plans to implement further permissible data attributes contained conceptually in the patent application\u201d. The company\u2019s match score appears to no longer be visibly influenced by the amount of rent offered for a property. Snug was also contracted late last year by the Victorian government\u2019s social housing agency, Homes Victoria, to create a purpose-built platform to take applications for the government\u2019s affordable housing program, with homes to be allocated by ballot. The Choice survey found the most commonly used third-party platforms were 2Apply and Ignite (formerly 1Form), followed by rent.com.au and Snug. Renters said they felt pressured to pay for a background check by many of these platforms in the hope their application would stand out in an increasingly overheated rental market, with 25% reporting they had forked out the money. \u201cFinding a home as a renter is already an incredibly difficult and draining experience,\u2019 Bower said. \u201cOur research found RentTech platforms are taking advantage of people\u2019s basic need for a roof over their heads to collect excessive data and charge unfair fees. \u201cAs the risk of data misuse and data breaches continues to grow, so too does the risk to consumers. The government needs to act quickly and strengthen Australia\u2019s privacy laws to ensure they are fit-for-purpose and protect consumers effectively.\u201d Choice is calling for reforms to the require too much private information from them but many still feel pressured to use them to find a home, a new report has found.</p> <p>In a national survey of 1,020 renters on their use of rental technology, consumer advocacy organisation Choice found 60% of renters were uncomfortable with the amount and type of information they were asked for when applying for a rental using rent-tech platforms. Almost one-third (29%) said they had at least once chosen not to apply for a rental because they did not trust the tech company taking their application with their data, and 41% said they felt pressured to use it anyway.</p> <p>The report, released on Tuesday, said renters were very concerned about data insecurity and invasive, automated decision-making technologies used in the rental application process. Among renters between 18 and 34 years old, 29% reported that their rental application had been scored against other prospective tenants to determine whether they would get a property.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/feb/20/its-worrying-victorias-affordable-rental-housing-to-be-allocated-by-ballot-rather-than-need\">Advocates criticise Victoria\u2019s decision to allocate affordable housing by ballot rather than need</a> </p> </aside>  <p>\u201cA sore lack of regulation in this market means these automated decision-making systems could increase barriers and discrimination for renters, potentially excluding some people from housing,\u201d Kate Bower, a Choice consumer data advocate, said.</p> <p>The Choice report follows <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/nov/17/imperfect-match-australian-renters-in-the-dark-over-use-of-data-by-tech-company-snug\">a Guardian Australia investigation last year</a> that revealed the potentially discriminatory use of applicants\u2019 personal data by Australian rent-tech company Snug. The company\u2019s rental application platform uses opaque algorithms to \u201cscore\u201d renters against properties, which gave renters a higher score when they offered to pay more rent.</p> <p>Privacy experts, academics and renters\u2019 advocates expressed concern after analysis of Snug\u2019s patent application suggested the company\u2019s intention was to collect wide-ranging information from users, including friend lists, social media networks and ratings on third-party platforms such as Airbnb and Uber, and to develop a kind of rental credit system.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon</a></strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\"> </a><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">email newsletters for your daily news roundup</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>Snug denied that the \u201cmatch score\u201d function facilitated rental bidding and said its mission was to \u201cmake renting easier\u201d thanks to a platform designed \u201cto facilitate a better relationship between renters and agents\u201d.</p> <p>The company did not disclose which data points went into its match score, and its spokesperson said the company had \u201cno foreseeable plans to implement further permissible data attributes contained conceptually in the patent application\u201d. The company\u2019s match score appears to no longer be visibly influenced by the amount of rent offered for a property.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/mar/31/australian-renters-face-surging-costs-after-end-of-national-affordability-scheme\">Australian renters face surging costs after end of national affordability scheme</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Snug was also contracted late last year by the Victorian government\u2019s social housing agency, Homes Victoria, to create <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/feb/20/its-worrying-victorias-affordable-rental-housing-to-be-allocated-by-ballot-rather-than-need\">a purpose-built platform to take applications for the government\u2019s affordable housing program</a>, with homes to be allocated by ballot.</p> <p>The Choice survey found the most commonly used third-party platforms were 2Apply and Ignite (formerly 1Form), followed by rent.com.au and Snug.</p> <p>Renters said they felt pressured to pay for a background check by many of these platforms in the hope their application would stand out in an increasingly overheated rental market, with 25% reporting they had forked out the money.</p> <p>\u201cFinding a home as a renter is already an incredibly difficult and draining experience,\u2019 Bower said. \u201cOur research found RentTech platforms are taking advantage of people\u2019s basic need for a roof over their heads to collect excessive data and charge unfair fees.</p> <p>\u201cAs the risk of data misuse and data breaches continues to grow, so too does the risk to consumers. The government needs to act quickly and strengthen Australia\u2019s privacy laws to ensure they are fit-for-purpose and protect consumers effectively.\u201d</p> <p>Choice is calling for reforms to the Privacy Act that ensure renters are protected, a federal inquiry into automated decision-making technology, and state governments to modernise their tenancy laws to prevent harms related to emerging rental technologies.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Nearly two-thirds of renters think third-party rental application platforms require too much private information from them but many still feel pressured to use them to find a home, a new report has found. In a national survey of 1,020 renters on their use of rental technology, consumer advocacy organisation Choice found 60% of renters were uncomfortable with the amount and type of information they were asked for when applying for a rental using rent-tech platforms. Almost one-third (29%) said they had at least once chosen not to apply for a rental because they did not trust the tech company taking their application with their data, and 41% said they felt pressured to use it anyway. The report, released on Tuesday, said renters were very concerned about data insecurity and invasive, automated decision-making technologies used in the rental application process. Among renters between 18 and 34 years old, 29% reported that their rental application had been scored against other prospective tenants to determine whether they would get a property.\n\u201cA sore lack of regulation in this market means these automated decision-making systems could increase barriers and discrimination for renters, potentially excluding some people from housing,\u201d Kate Bower, a Choice consumer data advocate, said. The Choice report follows a Guardian Australia investigation last year that revealed the potentially discriminatory use of applicants\u2019 personal data by Australian rent-tech company Snug. The company\u2019s rental application platform uses opaque algorithms to \u201cscore\u201d renters against properties, which gave renters a higher score when they offered to pay more rent. Privacy experts, academics and renters\u2019 advocates expressed concern after analysis of Snug\u2019s patent application suggested the company\u2019s intention was to collect wide-ranging information from users, including friend lists, social media networks and ratings on third-party platforms such as Airbnb and Uber, and to develop a kind of rental credit system. The company\u2019s match score appears to no longer be visibly influenced by the amount of rent offered for a property.\nSnug was also contracted late last year by the Victorian government\u2019s social housing agency, Homes Victoria, to create a purpose-built platform to take applications for the government\u2019s affordable housing program, with homes to be allocated by ballot. width=\"1000\" height=\"600\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">RBA board members were close to agreeing to an 11th consecutive rate rise in April.</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Steven Saphore/Reuters</span> </figcaption> </figure>", "body": "<p>The Reserve Bank\u2019s decision to pause its record run of interest rate rises earlier this month was lineball, with the central bank board deciding it needed more information to determine \u201cwhen and how much more\u201d they would be lifted.</p> <p>Minutes from the 4 April rates meeting,<a href=\"https://www.rba.gov.au/monetary-policy/rba-board-minutes/2023/2023-04-04.html\"> released on Tuesday,</a> show the nine board members examined at length the case for another 25 basis-point increase. That would have made it 11 consecutive rate hikes and lifted the cash rate to 3.85%.</p> <p>The case for another rate rise included the usual comments that inflation \u2013 running at an annual pace of 6.8% in February \u2013 \u201cremained too high and the labour market was very tight\u201d, the minutes show.</p> <p>In addition, the board weighed up two other factors that \u201cwere relevant to the case\u201d for more interest rate increases. These were the faster than expected pickup in population growth as immigration levels rose, and the \u201cincreased risk of larger wage increases in parts of the economy\u201d.</p> <p>However, the board ended up opting to halt the rate hikes in order to gather more information on the economic impacts of the 10 increases so far, given their full effects would take time to be felt. \u201cMembers judged that monetary policy was already restrictive,\u201d the minutes showed.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/audio/2023/feb/13/these-five-things-will-determine-your-interest-rates\">The five drivers of interest rates you need to watch</a> </p> </aside>  <p>By the 2 May meeting, board members will have access to the March quarter consumer prices index figures that are scheduled for a 26 April release. RBA staff are also due to \u201cpresent a full set of updated forecasts\u201d at that May meeting.</p> <p>In the end, there was \u201ca stronger case to pause\u201d at the April gathering than to lift the cash rate.</p> <p>Still, \u201cit was important to be clear that monetary policy may need to be tightened at subsequent meetings\u201d, implying that the RBA may still have more than one rate rise to come.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>Indeed, the RBA\u2019s projections of inflation returning to its target band of 2-3% by mid-2025 \u201cwere conditioned on monetary policy being tightened a little further\u201d, it said.</p> <p>Prior to today\u2019s minutes, investors viewed the chance of another pause in May as about a 90% chance. They were also predicting the next move would be a rate cut, a stance at odds with many economists who forecast at least one more interest rate increase.</p> <p>Some economists, such as Deloitte\u2019s Stephen Smith, have identified the prospect of a consumer recession for 2023, with household spending expected to finish the year below where it started.</p> <p>The RBA, though, has only identified \u201ca material slowing in the growth of consumer spending\u201d so far.</p> <p>\u201c[M]ost households were well-placed to navigate the financial challenges associated with higher prices and interest rates, especially if employment remained resilient,\u201d the minutes show. </p> <p>\u201cHowever, there were parts of the household sector that are under financial stress and, as a result, would have to scale back their spending to minimise the need to draw upon savings.\u201d</p> <p>Since the April board meeting, the Australian Bureau of Statistics has released labour market figures that were more robust than economists had forecast.<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/13/australia-unemployment-rate-holds-australian-employers-add-72000-full-time-jobs\"> The jobless rate remained at 3.5% in March</a> with a net increase of more than 50,000 jobs including about 72,000 additional full-time positions.</p> <p>House prices, too, had started to tick higher in some markets partly because of the increased population growth. Board members \u201cobserved that there were already signs that the recent fall in housing prices might be smaller and more short-lived than expected\u201d, the bank said.</p> <p>For now, the RBA expects wage increases to remain well below the headline inflation rate even with the unemployment rate hovering at half-century lows and an expected increase in the pace of public sector wage rises.</p> <p>\u201cFirms in the [RBA\u2019s] liaison program expected annual wages growth in the private sector to level out at a little below 4%,\u201d the minutes showed. \u201cWages growth in the public sector was likely to increase in coming quarters as recently announced state government wages policies take effect.\u201d</p> <p>The RBA did not name NSW, but the election of the Minns Labor government is expected to result in higher wage increases in the country\u2019s most populous state.</p> <p>NSW\u2019s rail workers, though, did feature in the minutes, with the RBA noting the Fair Work Commission had awarded wage increases to them above the state wage cap.</p> <p>The incoming treasurer, Daniel Mookhey, said on Monday the government had an election mandate to lift the current public sector wage caps of 3% for 2023-24 and 2.5% for subsequent years.</p> <p>While Australia\u2019s domestic considerations dominated, international issues, particularly financial stability, also feature in the minutes.</p> <p>The RBA noted that economic activity in China, Australia\u2019s largest trading partner, \u201chad begun to recover rapidly in the early part of the year from earlier Covid-19-related disruptions\u201d.</p> <p>China provided more evidence of that pickup on Tuesday. The country\u2019s GDP in the first quarter of 2023 accelerated to 4.5%, compared with a year ago, <a href=\"http://www.stats.gov.cn/english/PressRelease/202304/t20230418_1938715.html\">China\u2019s national bureau of statistics said</a>. That pace was faster than the 4% forecast by economists, and put the country on track towards meeting that nation\u2019s target of 5% growth for this year.</p>", "wordcount": "857", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T01:59:55Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T04:31:58Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnk3p", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/8a73141faf861221f05ef1bf553787fa7bbe981c/0_83_3235_1941/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "The Reserve Bank\u2019s decision to pause its record run of interest rate rises earlier this month was lineball, with the central bank board deciding it needed more information to determine \u201cwhen and how much more\u201d they would be lifted. Minutes from the 4 April rates meeting, released on Tuesday, show the nine board members examined at length the case for another 25 basis-point increase. That would have made it 11 consecutive rate hikes and lifted the cash rate to 3.85%. The case for another rate rise included the usual comments that inflation \u2013 running at an annual pace of 6.8% in February \u2013 \u201cremained too high and the labour market was very tight\u201d, the minutes show. In addition, the board weighed up two other factors that \u201cwere relevant to the case\u201d for more interest rate increases. These were the faster than expected pickup in population growth as immigration levels rose, and the \u201cincreased risk of larger wage increases in parts of the economy\u201d. However, the board ended up opting to halt the rate hikes in order to gather more information on the economic impacts of the 10 increases so far, given their full effects would take time to be felt. \u201cMembers judged that monetary policy was already restrictive,\u201d the minutes showed. By the 2 May meeting, board members will have access to the March quarter consumer prices index figures that are scheduled for a 26 April release. RBA staff are also due to \u201cpresent a full set of updated forecasts\u201d at that May meeting. In the end, there was \u201ca stronger case to pause\u201d at the April gathering than to lift the cash rate. Still, \u201cit was important to be clear that monetary policy may need to be tightened at subsequent meetings\u201d, implying that the RBA may still have more than one rate rise to come. They were also predicting the next move would be a rate cut, a stance at odds with many economists who forecast at least one more interest rate increase. The RBA, though, has only identified \u201ca material slowing in the growth of consumer spending\u201d so far. \u201c[M]ost households were well-placed to navigate the financial challenges associated with higher prices and interest rates, especially if employment remained resilient,\u201d the minutes show. \u201cHowever, there were parts of the household sector that are under financial stress and, as a result, would have to scale back their spending to minimise the need to draw upon savings.\u201d Since the April board meeting, the Australian Bureau of Statistics has released labour market figures that were more robust than economists had forecast. The jobless rate remained at 3.5% in March with a net increase of more than 50,000 jobs including about 72,000 additional full-time positions. House prices, too, had started to tick higher in some markets partly because of the increased population growth. NSW\u2019s rail workers, though, did feature in the minutes, with the RBA noting the Fair Work Commission had awarded wage increases to them above the state wage cap. While Australia\u2019s domestic considerations dominated, international issues, particularly financial stability, also feature in the minutes. These were the faster than expected pickup in population growth as immigration levels rose, and the \u201cincreased risk of larger wage increases in parts of the economy\u201d.</p> \n<p>However, the board ended up opting to halt the rate hikes in order to gather more information on the economic impacts of the 10 increases so far, given their full effects would take time to be felt. \u201cMembers judged that monetary policy was already restrictive,\u201d the minutes showed.</p>"}}, {"type": "rich-link", "assets": [], "richLinkTypeData": {"url": "https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/audio/2023/feb/13/these-five-things-will-determine-your-interest-rates", "originalUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/audio/2023/feb/13/these-five-things-will-determine-your-interest-rates", "linkText": "The five drivers of interest rates you need to watch", "linkPrefix": "Related: ", "role": "thumbnail"}}, {"type": "text", "assets": [], "textTypeData": {"html": "<p>By the 2 May meeting, board members will have access to the March quarter consumer prices index figures that are scheduled for a 26 April release. RBA staff are also due to \u201cpresent a full set of updated forecasts\u201d at that May meeting.</p> \n<p>In the end, there was \u201ca stronger case to pause\u201d at the April gathering than to lift the cash rate.</p> \n<p>Still, \u201cit was important to be clear that monetary policy may need to be tightened at subsequent meetings\u201d, implying that the RBA may still have more than one rate rise to come.</p> \n<ul> \n <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup</a></strong></p></li> \n</ul> \n<p>Indeed, the RBA\u2019s projections of inflation returning to its target band of 2-3% by mid-2025 \u201cwere conditioned on monetary policy being tightened a little further\u201d, it said.</p> \n<p>Prior to today\u2019s minutes, investors viewed the chance of another pause in May as about a 90% chance. They were also predicting the next move would be a rate cut, a stance at odds with many economists who forecast at least one more interest rate increase.</p> \n<p>Some economists, such as Deloitte\u2019s Stephen Smith, have identified the prospect of a consumer recession for 2023, with household spending expected to finish the year below where it started.</p> \n<p>The RBA, though, has only identified \u201ca material slowing in the growth of consumer spending\u201d so far.</p> \n<p>\u201c[M]ost households were well-placed to navigate the financial challenges associated with higher prices and interest rates, especially if employment remained resilient,\u201d the minutes show. </p> \n<p>\u201cHowever, there were parts of the household sector that are under financial stress and, as a result, would have to scale back their spending to minimise the need to draw upon savings.\u201d</p> \n<p>Since the April board meeting, the Australian Bureau of Statistics has released labour market figures that were more robust than economists had forecast.<a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/business/2023/apr/13/australia-unemployment-rate-holds-australian-employers-add-72000-full-time-jobs\"> The jobless rate remained at 3.5% in March</a> with a net increase of more than 50,000 jobs including about 72,000 additional full-time positions.</p> \n<p>House prices, too, had started to tick higher in some markets partly because of the increased population growth. Board members \u201cobserved that there were already signs that the recent fall in housing prices might be smaller and more short-lived than expected\u201d, the bank said.</p> \n<p>For now, the RBA expects wage increases to remain well below the headline inflation rate even with the unemployment rate hovering at half-century lows and an expected increase in the pace of public sector wage rises.</p> \n<p>\u201cFirms in the [RBA\u2019s] liaison program expected annual wages growth in the private sector to level out at a little below 4%,\u201d the minutes showed. \u201cWages growth in the public sector was likely to increase in coming quarters as recently announced state government wages policies take effect.\u201d</p> \n<p>The RBA did not name NSW, but the election of the Minns Labor government is expected to result in higher wage increases in the country\u2019s most populous state.</p> \n<p>NSW\u2019s rail workers, though, did feature in the minutes, with the RBA noting the Fair Work Commission had awarded wage increases to them above the state wage cap.</p> \n<p>The incoming treasurer, Daniel Mookhey, said on Monday the government had an election mandate to lift the current public sector wage caps of 3% for 2023-24 and 2.5% for subsequent years.</p> \n<p>While Australia\u2019s domestic considerations dominated, international issues, particularly financial stability, also feature in the minutes.</p> \n<p>The RBA noted that economic activity in China, Australia\u2019s largest trading partner, \u201chad begun to recover rapidly in the early part of the year from earlier Covid-19-related disruptions\u201d.</p> \n<p>China provided more evidence of that pickup on Tuesday. The country\u2019s GDP in the first quarter of 2023 accelerated to 4.5%, compared with a year ago, <a href=\"http://www.stats.gov.cn/english/PressRelease/202304/t20230418_1938715.html\">China\u2019s national bureau of statistics said</a>. That pace was faster than the 4% forecast by economists, and put the country on track towards meeting that nation\u2019s target of 5% growth for this year.</p>"}}]}], "totalBodyBlocks": 1}, "rights": choosing to campaign against the Indigenous voice, opposition leader Peter Dutton has not only done existential damage to the party he purports to lead, he has likely given the yes case its best chance of success.</p> <p>Over recent months the momentum for constitutional change has stalled, the strong and instinctive public goodwill dissipated by internal negotiations in pursuit of a bipartisanship that is beyond the current federal Coalition.</p> <p>The messaging around the yes vote has softened from a hard \u201cvoice\u201d to a greater emphasis on \u201cconstitutional recognition\u201d, a position previously rejected by First Nations leaders concerned that symbolism isn\u2019t enough to address the consequences of their historical injustice.</p> <p>In this period of conspicuous moderation, support among Liberal voters had marginally increased, but the younger progressive vote had started to slide in echoes of the 1999 republic debacle where milquetoast reform was rejected not for its ambition but for its lack thereof.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/18/weaponising-indigenous-children-for-the-voices-no-campaign-is-a-distraction-from-the-solutions-we-need\">Weaponising Indigenous children for the voice\u2019s no campaign is a distraction from the solutions we need | Catherine Liddle</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Dutton\u2019s rejection of bipartisanship liberates the yes campaign from this tepid incrementalism, allowing the campaign to reconnect with the roadmap originally laid out in the <a href=\"https://ulurustatement.org/\">Uluru statement from the heart</a>.</p> <p>This week\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/18/guardian-essential-poll-indigenous-voice-retains-majority-support-but-sees-opposition-harden\">Guardian Essential report</a> shows that in the week since Dutton rejected this generous invitation to walk forward, this slide in support has been arrested and progressive support is again rising.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=1-v1MMViJZFYIkDAJ4Q2h9KDqfLcBOWxzgsW3-9ItK4U\" data-alt=\"Do you approve the proposed alteration to the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander voice?\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=1-v1MMViJZFYIkDAJ4Q2h9KDqfLcBOWxzgsW3-9ItK4U\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>Now Dutton provides the campaign with a ready-made villain: not simply the charmless champion for an unacceptable status quo, but the entitled white guy who wants to control every detail of a process designed for and by people with less power and privilege than him.</p> <p>As the putative leader of the no campaign, Dutton becomes an apologist for every libertarian lapdog and racist fringe dweller who will be drawn to the no banner, rightly required to answer for every one of their rhetorical excesses.</p> <p>Dutton will continue to campaign on the tyranny of detail, a wilfully deceptive misrepresentation of the question on the referendum ballot, trying to spread both fear and panic around the status quo while pretending that nothing really needs to change.</p> <p>He will attempt to wish away the inherent contradictions in his position while spreading disdain for the very idea of nationhood, with his derisive and disingenuous \u201cCanberra Voice\u201d straw man.</p> <p>But he will do so with established credentials of a bad faith actor who walked out of the apology to the stolen generations and was part of a government that cut half a billion dollars from health and education programs in remote communities while sending in the Australian federal police to \u201cintervene\u201d in them. Less Canberra Voice, more Canberra Vice.</p> <p>Dutton has never been popular, but this decision forces him into a premature showdown with a first-term leader who will garner a vocal constituency across business and civil society. The raw figures show the extent of this mismatch.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=1OG_DlZM-D1keZIZ9cBg7KFibc87CZ_v-f7djknfkEus\" data-alt=\"Do you approve or disapprove of the job &lt;insert name&gt; is doing?\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=1OG_DlZM-D1keZIZ9cBg7KFibc87CZ_v-f7djknfkEus\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>That Dutton lacks the smarts to see the opportunity to work side by side with a popular prime minister, rising above politics, as Albanese did when the pandemic first hit, probably renders him ineligible for higher office at the get-go.</p> <p>What does the Liberal party do with these numbers? It would be easy to say that the hardheads should step in and see the folly of this strategy.</p> <p>The problem for the Liberals is that the hardheads are no longer running the party. Indeed, the hardheads like \u201cturn back the boats\u201d and Brexit mastermind Mark Textor and Howard-era campaign director <a href=\"https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-02-01/high-profile-australians-yes-campaign-voice-to-parliament/101917752\">Tony Nutt are actually on the yes campaign oversight board.</a></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/18/guardian-essential-poll-indigenous-voice-retains-majority-support-but-sees-opposition-harden\">Guardian Essential poll: Indigenous voice retains majority support but sees opposition harden</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The tragedy for anyone who likes the idea of a two-party democratic system is that the softheads now in charge are the group fixated on playing to their base rather than building genuine, er, coalitions.</p> <p>As for the yes campaign, the opportunity now is to reinvigorate the journey to the voice by looking outwards rather than accommodating inwards, and reassuring the majority of soft voters whose primary concern is that a yes vote will not lead to meaningful change.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=137xR3NJr5ErmprKv-0yt4H75IJLi2xfOMLY3g9EH1sE\" data-alt=\"What is your biggest concern about voting &lt;\u2018Yes\u2019/\u2019No\u201d&gt; for the voice?\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=137xR3NJr5ErmprKv-0yt4H75IJLi2xfOMLY3g9EH1sE\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>This reassurance starts with the voice\u2019s remarkable source document. No Australian who spends the time to read or listen to the <a href=\"https://ulurustatement.org/the-statement/\">Uluru statement from the heart </a>could tolerate anything but a successful yes vote.</p> <p>Like all good manifestos, it persuasively and poetically answers the cynical and pernickety questions of detail while explaining how the status quo is no longer tenable.</p> <p>It elegantly lays out the problem from the specific: <em>\u201cWe are the most incarcerated people on the planet. But we are not an innately criminal people</em>\u201d, to the systemic: <em>\u201cThe torment of our powerlessness.\u201d</em></p> <p>But it also demands more than a narrow yes vote with a bare majority of states. The invitation is to start a journey that deploys a First Nations voice, not just to make better decisions now but to guide us towards treaty in order to confront the terrible, unspoken truths that lie at the heart of our nation\u2019s soul.</p> <p>At just over 400 words it is a bit too long for a meme, but it is hardly War and Peace. Each Australian who takes the four minutes\u2019 time to read it will find themselves not just informed about the \u201cdetail\u201d but inspired to join their brothers and sisters as they <em>\u201cleave base camp\u201d.</em></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/15/as-liberal-party-fractures-over-the-voice-peter-dutton-turns-to-alice-springs-and-a-dog-whistle\">As Liberal party fractures over the voice, Peter Dutton turns to Alice Springs \u2013 and a dog-whistle | Paul Karp</a> </p> </aside>  <p>I\u2019m proud to be working with the campaign and will, over the coming months, be rolling out a series of Town Hall meetings across the nation that will give every Australian the chance to listen to this eloquent and generous invitation.</p> <p>There is also a program of kitchen table conversations, inspired by the \u201cvoices of\u201d community independent movement, that will be convening from May under the banner <a href=\"https://togetheryes.com.au/\">Together Yes</a>.</p> <p>There will be space in the room for anyone who wants to ask questions and be reassured that this is a meaningful step forward that will make a difference.</p> <p>Sadly, there will no longer be a place for the opposition leader, although the voices of those including Bridget Archer, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/11/julian-leeser-resigns-from-shadow-cabinet-over-liberals-voice-stance\">Julian Lesser</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/former-indigenous-affairs-minister-ken-wyatt-quits-liberals-over-partys-voice-opposition\">Ken Wyatt </a>and Tasmanian premier Jeremy Rockliff will only serve to highlight a liberalism he has deliberately purged from his party.</p> <p>They realise what Dutton is wilfully blind to: that this is much more than a contest of legal models, it is an opportunity to create the consensus to finally build a nation on solid foundations.</p> <ul> <li><p>Peter Lewis is an executive director of Essential, a progressive strategic communications and research company. Over recent months the momentum for constitutional change has stalled, the strong and instinctive public goodwill dissipated by internal negotiations in pursuit of a bipartisanship that is beyond the current federal Coalition. The messaging around the yes vote has softened from a hard \u201cvoice\u201d to a greater emphasis on \u201cconstitutional recognition\u201d, a position previously rejected by First Nations leaders concerned that symbolism isn\u2019t enough to address the consequences of their historical injustice. In this period of conspicuous moderation, support among Liberal voters had marginally increased, but the younger progressive vote had started to slide in echoes of the 1999 republic debacle where milquetoast reform was rejected not for its ambition but for its lack thereof. Dutton\u2019s rejection of bipartisanship liberates the yes campaign from this tepid incrementalism, allowing the campaign to reconnect with the roadmap originally laid out in the Uluru statement from the heart. This week\u2019s Guardian Essential report shows that in the week since Dutton rejected this generous invitation to walk forward, this slide in support has been arrested and progressive support is again rising. Now Dutton provides the campaign with a ready-made villain: not simply the charmless champion for an unacceptable status quo, but the entitled white guy who wants to control every detail of a process designed for and by people with less power and privilege than him. As the putative leader of the no campaign, Dutton becomes an apologist for every libertarian lapdog and racist fringe dweller who will be drawn to the no banner, rightly required to answer for every one of their rhetorical excesses. Dutton will continue to campaign on the tyranny of detail, a wilfully deceptive misrepresentation of the question on the referendum ballot, trying to spread both fear and panic around the status quo while pretending that nothing really needs to change. He will attempt to wish away the inherent contradictions in his position while spreading disdain for the very idea of nationhood, with his derisive and disingenuous \u201cCanberra Voice\u201d straw man. But he will do so with established credentials of a bad faith actor who walked out of the apology to the stolen generations and was part of a government that cut half a billion dollars from health and education programs in remote communities while sending in the Australian federal police to \u201cintervene\u201d in them. Less Canberra Voice, more Canberra Vice. Dutton has never been popular, but this decision forces him into a premature showdown with a first-term leader who will garner a vocal constituency across business and civil society. The raw figures show the extent of this mismatch. That Dutton lacks the smarts to see the opportunity to work side by side with a popular prime minister, rising above politics, as Albanese did when the pandemic first hit, probably renders him ineligible for higher office at the get-go. What does the Liberal party do with these numbers? It would be easy to say that the hardheads should step in and see the folly of this strategy. The problem for the Liberals is that the hardheads are no longer running the party. Indeed, the hardheads like \u201cturn back the boats\u201d and Brexit mastermind Mark Textor and Howard-era campaign director Tony Nutt are actually on the yes campaign oversight board. The tragedy for anyone who likes the idea of a two-party democratic system is that the softheads now in charge are the group fixated on playing to their base rather than building genuine, er, coalitions. As for the yes campaign, the opportunity now is to reinvigorate the journey to the voice by looking outwards rather than accommodating inwards, and reassuring the majority of soft voters whose primary concern is that a yes vote will not lead to meaningful change. This reassurance starts with the voice\u2019s remarkable source document. No Australian who spends the time to read or listen to the Uluru statement from the heart could tolerate anything but a successful yes vote. Like all good manifestos, it persuasively and poetically answers the cynical and pernickety questions of detail while explaining how the status quo is no longer tenable. It elegantly lays out the problem from the specific: \u201cWe are the most incarcerated people on the planet. But we are not an innately criminal people\u201d, to the systemic: \u201cThe torment of our powerlessness.\u201d But it also demands more than a narrow yes vote with a bare majority of states. The invitation is to start a journey that deploys a First Nations voice, not just to make better decisions now but to guide us towards treaty in order to confront the terrible, unspoken truths that lie at the heart of our nation\u2019s soul. At just over 400 words it is a bit too long for a meme, but it is hardly War and Peace. Each Australian who takes the four minutes\u2019 time to read it will find themselves not just informed about the \u201cdetail\u201d but inspired to join their brothers and sisters as they \u201cleave base camp\u201d. I\u2019m proud to be working with the campaign and will, over the coming months, be rolling out a series of Town Hall meetings across the nation that will give every Australian the chance to listen to this eloquent and generous invitation. There is also a program of kitchen table conversations, inspired by the \u201cvoices of\u201d community independent movement, that will be convening from May under the banner Together Yes. There will be space in the room for anyone who wants to ask questions and be reassured that this is a meaningful step forward that will make a difference. Sadly, there will no longer be a place for the opposition leader, although the voices of those including Bridget Archer, Julian Lesser, Ken Wyatt and Tasmanian premier Jeremy Rockliff will only serve to highlight a liberalism he has deliberately purged from his party. They realise what Dutton is wilfully blind to: that this is much more than a contest of legal models, it is an opportunity to create the consensus to finally build a nation on solid foundations.
