"6434c43c0b19b6bfe7a702eb", "imageType": "Photograph"}}]}, "body": [{"id": "643dbd188f08bd874860d8f1", "bodyHtml": "<p>In choosing to campaign against the Indigenous voice, opposition leader Peter Dutton has not only done existential damage to the party he purports to lead, he has likely given the yes case its best chance of success.</p> <p>Over recent months the momentum for constitutional change has stalled, the strong and instinctive public goodwill dissipated by internal negotiations in pursuit of a bipartisanship that is beyond the current federal Coalition.</p> <p>The messaging around the yes vote has softened from a hard \u201cvoice\u201d to a greater emphasis on \u201cconstitutional recognition\u201d, a position previously rejected by First Nations leaders concerned that symbolism isn\u2019t enough to address the consequences of their historical injustice.</p> <p>In this period of conspicuous moderation, support among Liberal voters had marginally increased, but the younger progressive vote had started to slide in echoes of the 1999 republic debacle where milquetoast reform was rejected not for its ambition but for its lack thereof.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/18/weaponising-indigenous-children-for-the-voices-no-campaign-is-a-distraction-from-the-solutions-we-need\">Weaponising Indigenous children for the voice\u2019s no campaign is a distraction from the solutions we need | Catherine Liddle</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Dutton\u2019s rejection of bipartisanship liberates the yes campaign from this tepid incrementalism, allowing the campaign to reconnect with the roadmap originally laid out in the <a href=\"https://ulurustatement.org/\">Uluru statement from the heart</a>.</p> <p>This week\u2019s <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/18/guardian-essential-poll-indigenous-voice-retains-majority-support-but-sees-opposition-harden\">Guardian Essential report</a> shows that in the week since Dutton rejected this generous invitation to walk forward, this slide in support has been arrested and progressive support is again rising.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=1-v1MMViJZFYIkDAJ4Q2h9KDqfLcBOWxzgsW3-9ItK4U\" data-alt=\"Do you approve the proposed alteration to the Constitution to recognise the First Peoples of Australia by establishing an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander voice?\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=1-v1MMViJZFYIkDAJ4Q2h9KDqfLcBOWxzgsW3-9ItK4U\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>Now Dutton provides the campaign with a ready-made villain: not simply the charmless champion for an unacceptable status quo, but the entitled white guy who wants to control every detail of a process designed for and by people with less power and privilege than him.</p> <p>As the putative leader of the no campaign, Dutton becomes an apologist for every libertarian lapdog and racist fringe dweller who will be drawn to the no banner, rightly required to answer for every one of their rhetorical excesses.</p> <p>Dutton will continue to campaign on the tyranny of detail, a wilfully deceptive misrepresentation of the question on the referendum ballot, trying to spread both fear and panic around the status quo while pretending that nothing really needs to change.</p> <p>He will attempt to wish away the inherent contradictions in his position while spreading disdain for the very idea of nationhood, with his derisive and disingenuous \u201cCanberra Voice\u201d straw man.</p> <p>But he will do so with established credentials of a bad faith actor who walked out of the apology to the stolen generations and was part of a government that cut half a billion dollars from health and education programs in remote communities while sending in the Australian federal police to \u201cintervene\u201d in them. Less Canberra Voice, more Canberra Vice.</p> <p>Dutton has never been popular, but this decision forces him into a premature showdown with a first-term leader who will garner a vocal constituency across business and civil society. The raw figures show the extent of this mismatch.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=1OG_DlZM-D1keZIZ9cBg7KFibc87CZ_v-f7djknfkEus\" data-alt=\"Do you approve or disapprove of the job &lt;insert name&gt; is doing?\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=1OG_DlZM-D1keZIZ9cBg7KFibc87CZ_v-f7djknfkEus\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>That Dutton lacks the smarts to see the opportunity to work side by side with a popular prime minister, rising above politics, as Albanese did when the pandemic first hit, probably renders him ineligible for higher office at the get-go.</p> <p>What does the Liberal party do with these numbers? It would be easy to say that the hardheads should step in and see the folly of this strategy.</p> <p>The problem for the Liberals is that the hardheads are no longer running the party. Indeed, the hardheads like \u201cturn back the boats\u201d and Brexit mastermind Mark Textor and Howard-era campaign director <a href=\"https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-02-01/high-profile-australians-yes-campaign-voice-to-parliament/101917752\">Tony Nutt are actually on the yes campaign oversight board.</a></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/18/guardian-essential-poll-indigenous-voice-retains-majority-support-but-sees-opposition-harden\">Guardian Essential poll: Indigenous voice retains majority support but sees opposition harden</a> </p> </aside>  <p>The tragedy for anyone who likes the idea of a two-party democratic system is that the softheads now in charge are the group fixated on playing to their base rather than building genuine, er, coalitions.</p> <p>As for the yes campaign, the opportunity now is to reinvigorate the journey to the voice by looking outwards rather than accommodating inwards, and reassuring the majority of soft voters whose primary concern is that a yes vote will not lead to meaningful change.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-interactive interactive\" data-interactive=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/embed/iframe-wrapper/0.1/boot.js\" data-canonical-url=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=137xR3NJr5ErmprKv-0yt4H75IJLi2xfOMLY3g9EH1sE\" data-alt=\"What is your biggest concern about voting &lt;\u2018Yes\u2019/\u2019No\u201d&gt; for the voice?\"> <a href=\"https://interactive.guim.co.uk/atoms/2020/08/table-tool/embed/app/main.html?spreadsheet=137xR3NJr5ErmprKv-0yt4H75IJLi2xfOMLY3g9EH1sE\">Interactive</a> </figure>  <p>This reassurance starts with the voice\u2019s remarkable source document. No Australian who spends the time to read or listen to the <a href=\"https://ulurustatement.org/the-statement/\">Uluru statement from the heart </a>could tolerate anything but a successful yes vote.</p> <p>Like all good manifestos, it persuasively and poetically answers the cynical and pernickety questions of detail while explaining how the status quo is no longer tenable.</p> <p>It elegantly lays out the problem from the specific: <em>\u201cWe are the most incarcerated people on the planet. But we are not an innately criminal people</em>\u201d, to the systemic: <em>\u201cThe torment of our powerlessness.\u201d</em></p> <p>But it also demands more than a narrow yes vote with a bare majority of states. The invitation is to start a journey that deploys a First Nations voice, not just to make better decisions now but to guide us towards treaty in order to confront the terrible, unspoken truths that lie at the heart of our nation\u2019s soul.</p> <p>At just over 400 words it is a bit too long for a meme, but it is hardly War and Peace. Each Australian who takes the four minutes\u2019 time to read it will find themselves not just informed about the \u201cdetail\u201d but inspired to join their brothers and sisters as they <em>\u201cleave base camp\u201d.</em></p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/15/as-liberal-party-fractures-over-the-voice-peter-dutton-turns-to-alice-springs-and-a-dog-whistle\">As Liberal party fractures over the voice, Peter Dutton turns to Alice Springs \u2013 and a dog-whistle | Paul Karp</a> </p> </aside>  <p>I\u2019m proud to be working with the campaign and will, over the coming months, be rolling out a series of Town Hall meetings across the nation that will give every Australian the chance to listen to this eloquent and generous invitation.</p> <p>There is also a program of kitchen table conversations, inspired by the \u201cvoices of\u201d community independent movement, that will be convening from May under the banner <a href=\"https://togetheryes.com.au/\">Together Yes</a>.</p> <p>There will be space in the room for anyone who wants to ask questions and be reassured that this is a meaningful step forward that will make a difference.</p> <p>Sadly, there will no longer be a place for the opposition leader, although the voices of those including Bridget Archer, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/11/julian-leeser-resigns-from-shadow-cabinet-over-liberals-voice-stance\">Julian Lesser</a>, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/06/former-indigenous-affairs-minister-ken-wyatt-quits-liberals-over-partys-voice-opposition\">Ken Wyatt </a>and Tasmanian premier Jeremy Rockliff will only serve to highlight a liberalism he has deliberately purged from his party.</p> <p>They realise what Dutton is wilfully blind to: that this is much more than a contest of legal models, it is an opportunity to create the consensus to finally build a nation on solid foundations.</p> <ul> <li><p>Peter Lewis is an executive director of Essential, a progressive strategic communications and research company. Essential is a Yes23 campaign partner<br></p></li> </ul>", "bodyTextSummary": "In choosing to campaign against the Indigenous voice, opposition leader Peter Dutton has not only done existential damage to the party he purports to lead, he has likely given the yes case its best chance of success. Over recent months the momentum for constitutional change has stalled, the strong and instinctive public goodwill dissipated by internal negotiations in pursuit of a bipartisanship that is beyond the current federal Coalition. The messaging around the yes vote has softened from a hard \u201cvoice\u201d to a greater emphasis on \u201cconstitutional recognition\u201d, a position previously rejected by First Nations leaders concerned that symbolism isn\u2019t enough to address the consequences of their historical injustice. In this period of conspicuous moderation, support among Liberal voters had marginally increased, but the younger progressive vote had started to slide in echoes of the 1999 republic debacle where milquetoast reform was rejected not for its ambition but for its lack thereof.\nDutton\u2019s rejection of bipartisanship liberates the yes campaign from this tepid incrementalism, allowing the campaign to reconnect with the roadmap originally laid out in the Uluru statement from the heart. This week\u2019s Guardian Essential report shows that in the week since Dutton rejected this generous invitation to walk forward, this slide in support has been arrested and progressive support is again rising.\nNow Dutton provides the campaign with a ready-made villain: not simply the charmless champion for an unacceptable status quo, but the entitled white guy who wants to control every detail of a process designed for and by people with less power and privilege than him. As the putative leader of the no campaign, Dutton becomes an apologist for every libertarian lapdog and racist fringe dweller who will be drawn to the no banner, rightly required to answer for every one of their rhetorical excesses. Dutton will continue to campaign on the tyranny of detail, a wilfully deceptive misrepresentation of the question on the referendum ballot, trying to spread both fear and panic around the status quo while pretending that nothing really needs to change. He will attempt to wish away the inherent contradictions in his position while spreading disdain for the very idea of nationhood, with his derisive and disingenuous \u201cCanberra Voice\u201d straw man. But he will do so with established credentials of a bad faith actor who walked out of the apology to the stolen generations and was part of a government that cut half a billion dollars from health and education programs in remote communities while sending in the Australian federal police to \u201cintervene\u201d in them. Less Canberra Voice, more Canberra Vice. Dutton has never been popular, but this decision forces him into a premature showdown with a first-term leader who will garner a vocal constituency across business and civil society. The raw figures show the extent of this mismatch.\nThat Dutton lacks the smarts to see the opportunity to work side by side with a popular prime minister, rising above politics, as Albanese did when the pandemic first hit, probably renders him ineligible for higher office at the get-go. What does the Liberal party do with these numbers? It would be easy to say that the hardheads should step in and see the folly of this strategy. The problem for the Liberals is that the hardheads are no longer running the party. Indeed, the hardheads like \u201cturn back the boats\u201d and Brexit mastermind Mark Textor and Howard-era campaign director Tony Nutt are actually on the yes campaign oversight board.\nThe tragedy for anyone who likes the idea of a two-party democratic system is that the softheads now in charge are the group fixated on playing to their base rather than building genuine, er, coalitions. As for the yes campaign, the opportunity now is to reinvigorate the journey to the voice by looking outwards rather than accommodating inwards, and reassuring the majority of soft voters whose primary concern is that a yes vote will not lead to meaningful change.\nThis reassurance starts with the voice\u2019s remarkable source document. No Australian who spends the time to read or listen to the Uluru statement from the heart could tolerate anything but a successful yes vote. Like all good manifestos, it persuasively and poetically answers the cynical and pernickety questions of detail while explaining how the status quo is no longer tenable. It elegantly lays out the problem from the specific: \u201cWe are the most incarcerated people on the planet. But we are not an innately criminal people\u201d, to the systemic: \u201cThe torment of our powerlessness.\u201d But it also demands more than a narrow yes vote with a bare majority of states. The invitation is to start a journey that deploys a First Nations voice, not just to make better decisions now but to guide us towards treaty in order to confront the terrible, unspoken truths that lie at the heart of our nation\u2019s soul. At just over 400 words it is a bit too long for a meme, but it is hardly War and Peace. Each Australian who takes the four minutes\u2019 time to read it will find themselves not just informed about the \u201cdetail\u201d but inspired to join their brothers and sisters as they \u201cleave base camp\u201d.\nI\u2019m proud to be working with the campaign and will, over the coming months, be rolling out a series of Town Hall meetings across the nation that will give every Australian the chance to listen to this eloquent and generous invitation. There is also a program of kitchen table conversations, inspired by the \u201cvoices of\u201d community independent movement, that will be convening from May under the banner Together Yes. There will be space in the room for anyone who wants to ask questions and be reassured that this is a meaningful step forward that will make a difference. Sadly, there will no longer be a place for the opposition leader, although the voices of those including Bridget Archer, Julian Lesser, Ken Wyatt and Tasmanian premier Jeremy Rockliff will only serve to highlight a liberalism he has deliberately purged from his party. They realise what Dutton is wilfully blind to: that this is much more than a contest of legal models, it is an opportunity to create the consensus to finally build a nation on solid foundations. Peter Lewis is an executive director of Essential, a progressive strategic communications and research company. A second package of Risso\u2019s dolphin offal showed mercury levels 80 times higher than the safe limit.</p> <p>An AFD investigator based in Japan ordered Risso\u2019s dolphin offal from the Yahoo! Japan website on 13 October 2022. Two packages arrived on 15 October and were sent to a laboratory in Japan, where they were tested separately.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/mar/23/whale-meat-on-the-menu-as-japanese-suppliers-try-to-tempt-tourists\">Whale meat on the menu as Japanese suppliers enlist influencers</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Hannah Tait, AFD\u2019s chief executive, said she hoped the test results and police complaint would result in dolphin meat being removed from sale in supermarkets, restaurants and the online retailer Yahoo! Japan.</p> <p>\u201cThere are multiple test results dating back a decade showing potentially toxic levels of mercury in whale and dolphin meat sold via Yahoo! Japan\u2019s website,\u201d Tait told the Guardian. \u201cThere is a lack of information and labelling \u2026 anyone can buy the meat, including pregnant women, which is particularly troubling.</p> <p>\u201cWe hope that by launching this complaint the matter will be taken up with urgency and these products will be removed from Yahoo! Japan\u2019s website, as well as from supermarket shelves and restaurant menus.</p> <p>\u201cThis is a case of the Japanese government looking the other way, even though \u2013 as we say in our complaint \u2013 the continued sale of [toxic] dolphin meat is a violation of Japanese food sanitation laws.\u201d</p> <p>In an email to the Guardian, Yahoo! Japan said it did not sell dolphin meat \u201cor any related products\u201d on its site \u2013 only whale meat. The offal tested by AFD is listed on the Yahoo! Japan site as coming from the hanagondo-kujira, which can be translated into English as Risso\u2019s dolphin or Risso\u2019s pilot whale. The AFD investigator used the latter translation, which also appears on other <a href=\"https://www.doc.govt.nz/nature/native-animals/marine-mammals/dolphins/pilot-whales/#:~:text=species%20at%20sea.-,Pilot%20whales%20are%20in%20fact%20one%20of%20the%20largest%20members,'pilot'%20in%20the%20group.\">cetacean websites</a>.</p> <p>Tait said the cetacean is biologically a member of the dolphin family.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"383f60a7524b4f2f5ce032fba5c1c8fe38580537\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/383f60a7524b4f2f5ce032fba5c1c8fe38580537/0_0_1701_1161/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Sample of offal from a Risso\u2019s dolphin\" width=\"1000\" height=\"683\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Action for Dolphins claims that tests on this sample of offal from a Risso\u2019s dolphin revealed mercury levels almost 100 times higher than recommended safe levels</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Action for Dolphins</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Yahoo! Japan is the only major online retailer in the country that continues to sell cetacean products. Rakuten, Japan\u2019s biggest online retailer, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/apr/04/rakuten-ends-whale-meat-sales\">stopped selling whale and dolphin meat</a> in 2014 after the international court of justice ordered Japan to immediately <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/mar/31/japanese-whaling-halt-antarctic-international-court\">halt its annual whale hunts</a> in the Southern Ocean.</p> <p>The complaint, submitted on behalf of AFD by the Tokyo-based law office of Takashi Takano, targets a speciality whale meat store that sells meat from cetaceans caught in Taiji, on Japan\u2019s Pacific coast, via Yahoo! Japan.</p> <p>Russell Fielding, an assistant professor at Coastal Carolina University who has conducted extensive research on cetaceans and mercury concentration, said the contamination levels found in the meat tested by AFD would be expected to cause health problems if consumed regularly.</p> <p>\u201cWith mercury concentrations of 39 parts per million (ppm) and methylmercury concentrations of 1.58 ppm, the meat tested certainly exceeds the recommendations and would be expected to cause health problems if consumed regularly,\u201d said Russell, who is not a member of AFD.</p> <p>In its guidelines, Japan\u2019s health ministry advises that fish and seafood with levels above 0.4 ppm for total mercury and 0.3 ppm for methylmercury are unsafe for human consumption.</p> <p>The complaint is the latest part of AFD\u2019s campaign to end dolphin hunting in Taiji, where the annual slaughter of hundreds of dolphins was the subject of 2009 Oscar-winning documentary <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/the-cove\">The Cove</a>. Other dolphins are kept alive and sold to aquariums and marine parks.</p> <p>In a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/11/not-ashamed-dolphin-hunters-of-taiji-break-silence-over-film-the-cove\">rare interview</a> several years ago, local dolphin hunters told the Guardian that they were simply protecting a traditional industry and accused opponents of attempting to destroy the area\u2019s culinary traditions.</p> <p>Tests conducted by AFD in 2020 and 2021 revealed mercury levels in dolphin meat between 12 and 25 times the regulatory limit. The organisation launched a criminal complaint against the sale of toxic whale and dolphin meat in 2021, but prosecutors decided not to take action.</p> <p>Studies of people who regularly consume cetacean products show that mercury and other contaminants can have an adverse effect on foetal development, neural development and memory, as well as increasing the risk of developing Parkinson\u2019s disease, hypertension and arteriosclerosis in adults.</p> <p>A 2010 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/09/dolphin-meat-mercury-levels-japan\">study</a> by the National Institute for Minamata Disease \u2013 which Tait described as \u201cflawed\u201d \u2013 found that levels of mercury detected in Taiji residents were above the national average, probably due to their consumption of whale and dolphin meat. Further tests found they had suffered no ill effects, however.</p> <p>The tests involved hair samples from 1,137 of the town\u2019s approximately 3,500 residents.</p>", "wordcount": "818", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T01:17:53Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T06:24:09Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nmk4n", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/e90631378585499df2dd27d51962bcdaa055703f/0_0_3568_2141/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Marine conservation campaigners have lodged a complaint with police demanding that \u201ctoxic\u201d dolphin meat be removed from sale in Japan, after a test showed a sample contained levels of mercury up to 100 times higher than the government\u2019s recommended safe level. A conservation group has lodged a complaint demanding dolphin meat is removed from sale.", "displayCredit": true, "credit": "Photograph: AP", "source": "AP", "alt": "Fishermen drive bottle-nose dolphins into a net during their annual hunt off Taiji in Japan.", "mediaId": "e90631378585499df2dd27d51962bcdaa055703f", "mediaApiUri": "https://api.media.gutools.co.uk/images/e90631378585499df2dd27d51962bcdaa055703f", "suppliersReference": "TOK801", "imageType": "Photograph"}}]}, "body": [{"id": "643770ed8f0891526bb4160c", "bodyHtml": "<p>Marine conservation campaigners have lodged a complaint with police demanding that \u201ctoxic\u201d dolphin meat be removed from sale in Japan, after a test showed a sample contained levels of mercury up to 100 times higher than the government\u2019s recommended safe level.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.afd.org.au/\">Action for Dolphins</a> (AFD), a nonprofit based in Australia, filed the complaint with police in central Japan this month, amid expert warnings that regular consumption of dolphin meat could threaten the health of consumers.</p> <p>AFD said recent testing at a laboratory in Japan revealed that one sample bought in the country \u2013 a portion of Risso\u2019s dolphin offal \u2013 exceeded the government-set regulatory limit of mercury by up to 97.5 times. A second package of Risso\u2019s dolphin offal showed mercury levels 80 times higher than the safe limit.</p> <p>An AFD investigator based in Japan ordered Risso\u2019s dolphin offal from the Yahoo! Japan website on 13 October 2022. Two packages arrived on 15 October and were sent to a laboratory in Japan, where they were tested separately.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/mar/23/whale-meat-on-the-menu-as-japanese-suppliers-try-to-tempt-tourists\">Whale meat on the menu as Japanese suppliers enlist influencers</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Hannah Tait, AFD\u2019s chief executive, said she hoped the test results and police complaint would result in dolphin meat being removed from sale in supermarkets, restaurants and the online retailer Yahoo! Japan.</p> <p>\u201cThere are multiple test results dating back a decade showing potentially toxic levels of mercury in whale and dolphin meat sold via Yahoo! Japan\u2019s website,\u201d Tait told the Guardian. \u201cThere is a lack of information and labelling \u2026 anyone can buy the meat, including pregnant women, which is particularly troubling.</p> <p>\u201cWe hope that by launching this complaint the matter will be taken up with urgency and these products will be removed from Yahoo! Japan\u2019s website, as well as from supermarket shelves and restaurant menus.</p> <p>\u201cThis is a case of the Japanese government looking the other way, even though \u2013 as we say in our complaint \u2013 the continued sale of [toxic] dolphin meat is a violation of Japanese food sanitation laws.\u201d</p> <p>In an email to the Guardian, Yahoo! Japan said it did not sell dolphin meat \u201cor any related products\u201d on its site \u2013 only whale meat. The offal tested by AFD is listed on the Yahoo! Japan site as coming from the hanagondo-kujira, which can be translated into English as Risso\u2019s dolphin or Risso\u2019s pilot whale. The AFD investigator used the latter translation, which also appears on other <a href=\"https://www.doc.govt.nz/nature/native-animals/marine-mammals/dolphins/pilot-whales/#:~:text=species%20at%20sea.-,Pilot%20whales%20are%20in%20fact%20one%20of%20the%20largest%20members,'pilot'%20in%20the%20group.\">cetacean websites</a>.</p> <p>Tait said the cetacean is biologically a member of the dolphin family.</p>  <figure class=\"element element-image\" data-media-id=\"383f60a7524b4f2f5ce032fba5c1c8fe38580537\"> <img src=\"https://media.guim.co.uk/383f60a7524b4f2f5ce032fba5c1c8fe38580537/0_0_1701_1161/1000.jpg\" alt=\"Sample of offal from a Risso\u2019s dolphin\" width=\"1000\" height=\"683\" class=\"gu-image\" /> <figcaption> <span class=\"element-image__caption\">Action for Dolphins claims that tests on this sample of offal from a Risso\u2019s dolphin revealed mercury levels almost 100 times higher than recommended safe levels</span> <span class=\"element-image__credit\">Photograph: Action for Dolphins</span> </figcaption> </figure>  <p>Yahoo! Japan is the only major online retailer in the country that continues to sell cetacean products. Rakuten, Japan\u2019s biggest online retailer, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/apr/04/rakuten-ends-whale-meat-sales\">stopped selling whale and dolphin meat</a> in 2014 after the international court of justice ordered Japan to immediately <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/mar/31/japanese-whaling-halt-antarctic-international-court\">halt its annual whale hunts</a> in the Southern Ocean.</p> <p>The complaint, submitted on behalf of AFD by the Tokyo-based law office of Takashi Takano, targets a speciality whale meat store that sells meat from cetaceans caught in Taiji, on Japan\u2019s Pacific coast, via Yahoo! Japan.</p> <p>Russell Fielding, an assistant professor at Coastal Carolina University who has conducted extensive research on cetaceans and mercury concentration, said the contamination levels found in the meat tested by AFD would be expected to cause health problems if consumed regularly.</p> <p>\u201cWith mercury concentrations of 39 parts per million (ppm) and methylmercury concentrations of 1.58 ppm, the meat tested certainly exceeds the recommendations and would be expected to cause health problems if consumed regularly,\u201d said Russell, who is not a member of AFD.</p> <p>In its guidelines, Japan\u2019s health ministry advises that fish and seafood with levels above 0.4 ppm for total mercury and 0.3 ppm for methylmercury are unsafe for human consumption.</p> <p>The complaint is the latest part of AFD\u2019s campaign to end dolphin hunting in Taiji, where the annual slaughter of hundreds of dolphins was the subject of 2009 Oscar-winning documentary <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/film/the-cove\">The Cove</a>. Other dolphins are kept alive and sold to aquariums and marine parks.</p> <p>In a <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/11/not-ashamed-dolphin-hunters-of-taiji-break-silence-over-film-the-cove\">rare interview</a> several years ago, local dolphin hunters told the Guardian that they were simply protecting a traditional industry and accused opponents of attempting to destroy the area\u2019s culinary traditions.</p> <p>Tests conducted by AFD in 2020 and 2021 revealed mercury levels in dolphin meat between 12 and 25 times the regulatory limit. The organisation launched a criminal complaint against the sale of toxic whale and dolphin meat in 2021, but prosecutors decided not to take action.</p> <p>Studies of people who regularly consume cetacean products show that mercury and other contaminants can have an adverse effect on foetal development, neural development and memory, as well as increasing the risk of developing Parkinson\u2019s disease, hypertension and arteriosclerosis in adults.</p> <p>A 2010 <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/09/dolphin-meat-mercury-levels-japan\">study</a> by the National Institute for Minamata Disease \u2013 which Tait described as \u201cflawed\u201d \u2013 found that levels of mercury detected in Taiji residents were above the national average, probably due to their consumption of whale and dolphin meat. Further tests found they had suffered no ill effects, however.</p> <p>The tests involved hair samples from 1,137 of the town\u2019s approximately 3,500 residents.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Marine conservation campaigners have lodged a complaint with police demanding that \u201ctoxic\u201d dolphin meat be removed from sale in Japan, after a test showed a sample contained levels of mercury up to 100 times higher than the government\u2019s recommended safe level. Action for Dolphins (AFD), a nonprofit based in Australia, filed the complaint with police in central Japan this month, amid expert warnings that regular consumption of dolphin meat could threaten the health of consumers. AFD said recent testing at a laboratory in Japan revealed that one sample bought in the country \u2013 a portion of Risso\u2019s dolphin offal \u2013 exceeded the government-set regulatory limit of mercury by up to 97.5 times. A second package of Risso\u2019s dolphin offal showed mercury levels 80 times higher than the safe limit. An AFD investigator based in Japan ordered Risso\u2019s dolphin offal from the Yahoo! Japan website on 13 October 2022. Two packages arrived on 15 October and were sent to a laboratory in Japan, where they were tested separately.\nHannah Tait, AFD\u2019s chief executive, said she hoped the test results and police complaint would result in dolphin meat being removed from sale in supermarkets, restaurants and the online retailer Yahoo! Japan. \u201cThere are multiple test results dating back a decade showing potentially toxic levels of mercury in whale and dolphin meat sold via Yahoo! Japan\u2019s website,\u201d Tait told the Guardian. \u201cThere is a lack of information and labelling \u2026 anyone can buy the meat, including pregnant women, which is particularly troubling. \u201cWe hope that by launching this complaint the matter will be taken up with urgency and these products will be removed from Yahoo! Japan\u2019s website, as well as from supermarket shelves and restaurant menus. \u201cThis is a case of the Japanese government looking the other way, even though \u2013 as we say in our complaint \u2013 the continued sale of [toxic] dolphin meat is a violation of Japanese food sanitation laws.\u201d In an email to the Guardian, Yahoo! Japan said it did not sell dolphin meat \u201cor any related products\u201d on its site \u2013 only whale meat. The offal tested by AFD is listed on the Yahoo! Japan site as coming from the hanagondo-kujira, which can be translated into English as Risso\u2019s dolphin or Risso\u2019s pilot whale. The AFD investigator used the latter translation, which also appears on other cetacean websites. Tait said the cetacean is biologically a member of the dolphin family.\nYahoo! Japan is the only major online retailer in the country that continues to sell cetacean products. Rakuten, Japan\u2019s biggest online retailer, stopped selling whale and dolphin meat in 2014 after the international court of justice ordered Japan to immediately halt its annual whale hunts in the Southern Ocean. The complaint, submitted on behalf of AFD by the Tokyo-based law office of Takashi Takano, targets a speciality whale meat store that sells meat from cetaceans caught in Taiji, on Japan\u2019s Pacific coast, via Yahoo! Japan. Russell Fielding, an assistant professor at Coastal Carolina University who has conducted extensive research on cetaceans and mercury concentration, said the contamination levels found in the meat tested by AFD would be expected to cause health problems if consumed regularly. \u201cWith mercury concentrations of 39 parts per million (ppm) and methylmercury concentrations of 1.58 ppm, the meat tested certainly exceeds the recommendations and would be expected to cause health problems if consumed regularly,\u201d said Russell, who is not a member of AFD. In its guidelines, Japan\u2019s health ministry advises that fish and seafood with levels above 0.4 ppm for total mercury and 0.3 ppm for methylmercury are unsafe for human consumption. The complaint is the latest part of AFD\u2019s campaign to end dolphin hunting in Taiji, where the annual slaughter of hundreds of dolphins was the subject of 2009 Oscar-winning documentary The Cove. Other dolphins are kept alive and sold to aquariums and marine parks. In a rare interview several years ago, local dolphin hunters told the Guardian that they were simply protecting a traditional industry and accused opponents of attempting to destroy the area\u2019s culinary traditions. Tests conducted by AFD in 2020 and 2021 revealed mercury levels in dolphin meat between 12 and 25 times the regulatory limit. The organisation launched a criminal complaint against the sale of toxic whale and dolphin meat in 2021, but prosecutors decided not to take action. Studies of people who regularly consume cetacean products show that mercury and other contaminants can have an adverse effect on foetal development, neural development and memory, as well as increasing the risk of developing Parkinson\u2019s disease, hypertension and arteriosclerosis in adults. A 2010 study by the National Institute for Minamata Disease \u2013 which Tait described as \u201cflawed\u201d \u2013 found that levels of mercury detected in Taiji residents were above the national average, probably due to their consumption of whale and dolphin meat. Further tests found they had suffered no ill effects, however. the head of an international harm minimisation group.</p> <p>The executive director of London-based Harm Reduction International, Naomi Burke-Shyne, is in Melbourne for the organisation\u2019s annual conference and has called on the Andrews government to provide a promised second safe injecting facility in the city\u2019s central business district.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/mar/07/im-not-impaired-victorias-parliament-to-debate-drug-driving-in-age-of-medicinal-cannabis\">\u2018I\u2019m not impaired\u2019: Victoria\u2019s parliament to debate drug driving in age of medicinal cannabis</a> </p> </aside>  <p>\u201cDrug consumption rooms should be accessible, they should be where people need them,\u201d Burke-Shyne said. \u201cIt\u2019s that simple.\u201d</p> <p>The Victorian government recently introduced legislation to make the safe injecting room at its current location in North Richmond permanent, after more than 6,500 overdoses had been treated at the facility since it opened in 2018 and <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/jun/19/im-living-proof-how-melbournes-drug-injecting-room-has-changed-and-saved-lives\">63 deaths prevented</a>.</p> <p>Burke-Shyne, an Australian, said the key to the facility\u2019s success had also been the offering of other important health services as well as housing and legal support.</p> <p>\u201cPeople can get tested for hepatitis and get started on treatment within two hours, there are sexual reproductive health services for women, lawyers dropping around, housing officers,\u201d she said.</p> <ul> <li><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2022/oct/29/email-newsletters-guardian-australia-best-daily-news-emails-newsletter-free-sign-up-inbox-subscribe-headlines?CMP=copyembed\">Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup</a></strong></p></li> </ul> <p>\u201cYes, the space has drug consumption, but I think that really underplays how important the holistic approach to supporting vulnerable communities is.\u201d</p> <p>On Sunday the chair of the <a href=\"https://global.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=616fa46941a6c0b536ce9c4d7&amp;id=9b06b64c24&amp;e=63d3f32ee1\">Global Commission on Drug Policy</a> and former New Zealand prime minister, Helen Clark, went further, pushing for decriminalisation, saying drug prohibition has been \u201ca societal, economic and moral failure.\u201d</p> <p>\u201cWhere countries have decriminalised the use of drugs, the sky has not fallen in,\u201d Clark told the <a href=\"https://global.us11.list-manage.com/track/click?u=616fa46941a6c0b536ce9c4d7&amp;id=c284262127&amp;e=63d3f32ee1\">Harm Reduction International Conference</a>.</p> <p>\u201cDrug use continues to grow around the world, millions of people are imprisoned for drug possession and millions more are unnecessarily contracting HIV and hepatitis C because of lack of access to effective harm reduction measures.\u201d</p> <p>Burke-Shyne said there were 16 countries across the world that have introduced drug consumption rooms, or safe injecting facilities. They include France, which opened facilities in Paris and Strasbourg in 2016.</p> <p>Being presented at the conference on Tuesday are the results of the first-ever controlled trial conducted safe injecting room, which compared the behaviours of people who inject drugs in the Paris and Strasbourg centres with people who live in the cities of Bordeaux and Marseille, where no such centres exist.</p> <p>The 12-month longitudinal study found those who used the centres in Paris and Strasbourg were less likely to report overdoses, as well as injection equipment sharing, abscesses and emergency department visits. They were also less likely to inject in public and to have committed a crime in the past month.</p> <p>In 2020 an independent expert panel recommended a second facility be set up in Melbourne to take pressure off the North Richmond service, which had become the busiest in the country. The government responded by announcing it would open one in the CBD.</p> <p>But those within the alcohol and other drugs sector are concerned the government has lost its appetite to follow through with the commitment.</p> <p>They point to comments made by the premier, Daniel Andrews, in recent months about \u201cchanged drug patterns\u201d in the CBD. The release of a report by the former police commissioner Ken Lay, who was tasked with investigating the possible location for a facility, has also been delayed</p> <p>The former Yooralla building in Flinders Street \u2013 the government\u2019s preferred location for a second injecting room \u2013 has sat empty since it was bought for a reported $40.3m in 2021.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/law/2022/mar/08/people-dont-choose-to-become-addicts-the-push-to-end-victorias-war-on-drugs\">\u2018People don\u2019t choose to become addicts\u2019: the push to end Victoria\u2019s war on drugs</a> </p> </aside>  <p>Andrews last month said despite buying the building, the second site was not guaranteed and was dependent on the outcome of Lay\u2019s review.</p> <p>A group of 80 organisations, including the Australian Medical Association, the Salvation Army, several health unions and housing and legal services, responding by writing a joint letter to Andrews urging him to push ahead with the plan.</p> <p>Burke-Shyne said Victoria was an early and strong adopter of harm reduction policies, such as its needle and syringe programs and access to The executive director of London-based Harm Reduction International, Naomi Burke-Shyne, is in Melbourne for the organisation\u2019s annual conference and has called on the Andrews government to provide a promised second safe injecting facility in the city\u2019s central business district. \u201cDrug consumption rooms should be accessible, they should be where people need them,\u201d Burke-Shyne said. \u201cIt\u2019s that simple.\u201d The Victorian government recently introduced legislation to make the safe injecting room at its current location in North Richmond permanent, after more than 6,500 overdoses had been treated at the facility since it opened in 2018 and 63 deaths prevented. urging him to push ahead with the plan.</p> <p>Burke-Shyne said Victoria was an early and strong adopter of harm reduction policies, such as its needle and syringe programs and access to pharmacotherapy treatments, but could fall behind other jurisdictions.</p> <p>Fatal heroin-related overdoses dropped across Victoria in 2021, including in the City of Melbourne.</p> <p>It means the city has overtaken the City of Yarra \u2013 where the safe injecting room is located \u2013 for the first time on record.</p> <p>The City of Melbourne also has had the highest number of drug overdose deaths of any LGA in 2021, <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2021/jun/19/im-living-proof-how-melbournes-drug-injecting-room-has-changed-and-saved-lives\">while Yarra has been declining since the injecting room opened</a>.</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "Victoria risks falling behind the rest of the world if it fails to expand on the success of its safe injecting room in Richmond, according to the head of an international harm minimisation group. The executive director of London-based Harm Reduction International, Naomi Burke-Shyne, is in Melbourne for the organisation\u2019s annual conference and has called on the Andrews government to provide a promised second safe injecting facility in the city\u2019s central business district.\n\u201cDrug consumption rooms should be accessible, they should be where people need them,\u201d Burke-Shyne said. \u201cIt\u2019s that simple.\u201d The Victorian government recently introduced legislation to make the safe injecting room at its current location in North Richmond permanent, after more than 6,500 overdoses had been treated at the facility since it opened in 2018 and 63 deaths prevented. Burke-Shyne, an Australian, said the key to the facility\u2019s success had also been the offering of other important health services as well as housing and legal support. \u201cPeople can get tested for hepatitis and get started on treatment within two hours, there are sexual reproductive health services for women, lawyers dropping around, housing officers,\u201d she said. Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup \u201cYes, the space has drug consumption, but I think that really underplays how important the holistic approach to supporting vulnerable communities is.\u201d On Sunday the chair of the Global Commission on Drug Policy and former New Zealand prime minister, Helen Clark, went further, pushing for decriminalisation, saying drug prohibition has been \u201ca societal, economic and moral failure.\u201d \u201cWhere countries have decriminalised the use of drugs, the sky has not fallen in,\u201d Clark told the Harm Reduction International Conference. \u201cDrug use continues to grow around the world, millions of people are imprisoned for drug possession and millions more are unnecessarily contracting HIV and hepatitis C because of lack of access to effective harm reduction measures.\u201d Burke-Shyne said there were 16 countries across the world that have introduced drug consumption rooms, or safe injecting facilities. They include France, which opened facilities in Paris and Strasbourg in 2016. Being presented at the conference on Tuesday are the results of the first-ever controlled trial conducted safe injecting room, which compared the behaviours of people who inject drugs in the Paris and Strasbourg centres with people who live in the cities of Bordeaux and Marseille, where no such centres exist. The 12-month longitudinal study found those who used the centres in Paris and Strasbourg were less likely to report overdoses, as well as injection equipment sharing, abscesses and emergency department visits. They were also less likely to inject in public and to have committed a crime in the past month. In 2020 an independent expert panel recommended a second facility be set up in Melbourne to take pressure off the North Richmond service, which had become the busiest in the country. The government responded by announcing it would open one in the CBD. But those within the alcohol and other drugs sector are concerned the government has lost its appetite to follow through with the commitment. They point to comments made by the premier, Daniel Andrews, in recent months about \u201cchanged drug patterns\u201d in the CBD. The release of a report by the former police commissioner Ken Lay, who was tasked with investigating the possible location for a facility, has also been delayed The former Yooralla building in Flinders Street \u2013 the government\u2019s preferred location for a second injecting room \u2013 has sat empty since it was bought for a reported $40.3m in 2021.\nAndrews last month said despite buying the building, the second site was not guaranteed and was dependent on the outcome of Lay\u2019s review. A group of 80 organisations, including the Australian Medical Association, the Salvation Army, several health unions and housing and legal services, responding by writing a joint letter to Andrews urging him to push ahead with the plan. Burke-Shyne said Victoria was an early and strong adopter of harm reduction policies, such as its needle and syringe programs and access to pharmacotherapy treatments, but could fall behind other jurisdictions. Fatal heroin-related overdoses dropped across Victoria in 2021, including in the City of Melbourne. It means the city has overtaken the City of Yarra \u2013 where the safe injecting room is located \u2013 for the first time on record. national security.\u201d</p>", "bodyTextSummary": "The Liberal MP Karen Andrews has stepped down as shadow home affairs minister, prompting a wider reshuffle that promotes two Indigenous first-term Coalition senators who are opposed to enshrining the voice in the constitution. The Nationals senator Jacinta Price has been elevated to shadow minister for Indigenous Australians while the Liberal senator Kerrynne Liddle will serve in the outer ministry.\nAndrews announced on Tuesday that she will sit on the backbench before retiring at the next election, as the opposition leader, Peter Dutton, unveiled a reshuffle sparked by the departure of Julian Leeser to the backbench to campaign in favour of the Indigenous voice to parliament. Her move is not related to the voice referendum; she confirmed in a statement she would \u201ccontinue to support the party position\u201d on the voice but later clarified at a doorstop that she will not actively campaign for a no vote. The Nationals leader, David Littleproud, declared it a \u201cproud day for the Nationals\u201d, as Price will be the seventh National in the shadow cabinet \u2013 one more than the minimum guaranteed by the Coalition agreement. Sign up for Guardian Australia\u2019s free morning and afternoon email newsletters for your daily news roundup Littleproud said the Nationals had \u201cled the debate\u201d on the voice, by arguing against \u201cadding more bureaucracy\u201d. Dutton told reporters in Adelaide that Liddle would join the outer ministry as the shadow minister for child protection and prevention of family violence. James Paterson will also enter the Coalition cabinet, becoming the shadow minister for home affairs in addition to his existing portfolios of cyber security and countering foreign interference. Michaelia Cash, the shadow minister for employment and workplace relations, will gain the shadow attorney general portfolio. Dutton defended elevating another National to cabinet, explaining he wanted his \u201cbest people on the paddock\u201d and arguing it would be \u201csilly\u201d to overlook Price\u2019s \u201cobvious talent\u201d.\nPrice, a prominent opponent of the voice in the constitution, told reporters she was \u201chumbled and grateful that the leadership \u2026 has entrusted me to carry out this role on behalf of Indigenous Australians\u201d. She said some unnamed Indigenous leaders have said they \u201cdon\u2019t have any idea what the prime minister\u2019s proposal for the yes campaign is\u201d. \u201cThey don\u2019t know what the voice is, they don\u2019t feel like they will be represented by yet another model that they see as being run by those who have long held positions within the Aboriginal industry, if you like.\u201d\nPrice said she was concerned that some in Indigenous communities might be \u201cexploited for the purpose of this referendum\u201d and criticised as \u201cutterly ridiculous\u201d the fact that South Australia\u2019s voice allows citizens to self-identify as Aboriginal. \u201cThe fact that a citizen of South Australia can write a statutory declaration and claim to be Indigenous is deeply concerning.\u201d Liddle, another opponent of the constitutionally entrenched voice, also criticised the South Australian model, arguing: \u201cWe don\u2019t actually know how effectively this model will work.\u201d After the Coalition\u2019s 2022 election defeat Andrews considered contesting the Liberal leadership but opted against the move as the party united behind Dutton. On Tuesday Dutton rejected any suggestion that Andrews had been pushed out, giving a \u201c100% no\u201d when asked this in Adelaide. He said Andrews had been a \u201ca warrior for really important causes\u201d and she had been a \u201cfirst-rate contributor\u201d in the portfolio of home affairs.\nAndrews told reporters on the Gold Coast that she \u201cwon\u2019t be out there wearing a shirt that says \u2018vote no\u2019\u201d during the referendum debate. She said she had concerns with Labor\u2019s proposed wording and that she would explain these concerns, \u201cbut I want to do that in a very neutral way so that people are in a position that they can make their own mind up\u201d. In a statement, Andrews said: \u201cHaving made the decision to call time on my political career, I wanted to ensure the Coalition has maximum time to have a replacement in the crucial home affairs portfolio, and the best local candidate for McPherson in place. \u201cI am proud to have been the first female Queensland MP in a cabinet role, and I am even prouder of the strong work the Coalition The Republican governor dropped the suggestion at a hastily convened Monday lunchtime press conference, at which he laid out steps the state legislature would take to try to regain control over Florida\u2019s largest private employer.\nThe move is the latest in an ongoing feud that began in March 2022 when Disney\u2019s then chief executive Bob Chapek spoke out against a bill limiting discussion of sexuality and gender identity in Florida elementary school classrooms, dubbed the \u201cdon\u2019t say gay\u201d law. DeSantis attempted to seize power over Disney in February by firing its controlling board and installing a handpicked board of Republican allies, including one who helped craft the education bill. But the hard-right governor, a likely candidate for his party\u2019s 2024 presidential nomination, found himself humiliated in March when it emerged that the outgoing board, in a final act of defiance, made an agreement to hand over control to the company itself. Smarting from that move, DeSantis on Monday denounced the agreement as a legally unsound \u201csham\u201d, and announced a new measure that would return control of the special district that is home to Disney World to a state oversight board run by the governor\u2019s appointees. Among other things, the new measures include passing authority for the inspection of theme park rides and transportation to the state, increasing Disney\u2019s tax burden, and giving the newly constituted board the power to decide how to develop land adjacent to Disney\u2019s theme parks. DeSantis suggested that the new board could take other actions with Disney\u2019s 27,000 acres (10,926 hectares) in central Florida, such as building a state park, a competing theme park or a prison. \u201cI think the possibilities are endless,\u201d DeSantis said. told the transgender athlete Lexi Rodgers she is ineligible to play elite level basketball this season.</p> <p>Rodgers had been hoping to play for the Kilsyth Cobras in the the NBL1 South women\u2019s semi-professional basketball league that sits below the professional NBL and WNBL leagues, and is made up of North, South, East, West and Central conferences.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/mar/30/lexi-rodgers-australian-transgender-basketball-hopeful-breaks-silence\">Lexi Rodgers: Australian transgender basketball hopeful breaks silence</a> </p> </aside>  <p>To assess Rodgers\u2019 case BA convened an expert panel led by Dr Peter Harcourt (BA chief medical officer, Commonwealth Games medical advisor), Suzy Batkovic OLY (BA board member, three-time Olympian) and Assoc Prof Diana Robinson.<br><br>BA said in a statement they assess eligibility of prospective elite-level transgender athletes \u201con a \u2018case-by-case\u2019 basis, accounting for and balancing a range of factors\u201d, without specifying those factors.</p> <p>\u201cWe\u2019re still on a path of education and understanding,\u201d the governing body acknowledged. \u201cThe balance of inclusivity, fairness and the competitive nature of sport will always be a complex area to navigate, and we thank those involved who have maintained integrity and respect throughout the process.\u201d<br><br>Basketball Australia\u2019s director, Suzy Batkovic, said: \u201cI\u2019d like to acknowledge and sincerely thank Lexi for her cooperation, understanding and patience throughout this process \u2013 it\u2019s a complex space that continues to evolve.<br><br>\u201cWhile Lexi is understandably disappointed with the outcome, I know she\u2019ll continue to support her NBL1 South team throughout the season and be an active member of the basketball community.<br><br>In informing Rodgers and the Kilsyth Cobras of the decision, Batkovic added: \u201cI also want to make it clear, because it\u2019s important, that while this particular application was not approved based on criteria for elite competition, Basketball Australia encourages and promotes inclusivity at community level.\u201d</p> <p>Rodgers was a talented junior player but has previously acknowledged that transitioning might preclude her from playing the sport at the highest level, including her ultimate dream of representing the Opals.</p> <p>In response to BA\u2019s decision, Rodgers expressed her disappointment with the ruling and the message it projects.</p> <p>\u201cI sought a different outcome from Basketball Australia,\u201d Rodgers wrote in an Instagram post. \u201cI participated fully and in good faith with the process and eligibility criteria. Consistent with the views expressed by so many, I firmly believe I have a place as an athlete in women\u2019s basketball.</p> <p>\u201cBasketball is one of the great loves of my life. Like so many people who play every week across the country, the basketball court is where I feel safe, where I feel free, and where I feel I belong.</p> <p>\u201cThe backing of the players, coaches, my club and grassroots members has been overwhelming. I am so grateful for their desire to have me as part of their community. Such support fills me with pride, but also sends an honest message of equality to those who are also seeking belonging within sport.</p> <p>Rodgers said she would continue to advocate for transgender athletes and gender-diverse inclusion in sports.</p> <p>\u201cI hope Basketball Australia understands that this is not the end of my journey as an athlete and that it must not miss future opportunities to demonstrate its values,\u201d she wrote. \u201cI am sad about the potential message this decision sends to trans and gender-diverse people everywhere. I hope that one day basketball\u2019s governing body can replicate the inclusion and acceptance I have found on the court with my teammates.</p> <p>\u201cI hope to one day be playing elite women\u2019s basketball in the future and will continue to work on making the sport I love a place for all.\u201d<br><br></p>", "wordcount": "571", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T00:41:27Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-18T11:01:21Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnjme", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/45c3a1c57886b95f740f6d27f38d0e3a978a3017/60_0_1800_1080/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Basketball Australia has told the transgender athlete Lexi Rodgers she is ineligible to play elite level basketball this season. Rodgers had been hoping to play for the Kilsyth Cobras in the the NBL1 South women\u2019s semi-professional basketball league that sits below the professional NBL and WNBL leagues, and is made up of North, South, East, West and Central conferences. To assess Rodgers\u2019 case BA convened an expert panel led by Dr Peter Harcourt (BA chief medical officer, Commonwealth Games medical advisor), Suzy Batkovic OLY (BA board member, three-time Olympian) and Assoc Prof Diana Robinson. BA said in a statement they assess eligibility of prospective elite-level transgender athletes \u201con a \u2018case-by-case\u2019 basis, accounting for and balancing a range of factors\u201d, without specifying those factors. \u201cWe\u2019re still on a path of education and understanding,\u201d the governing body acknowledged. \u201cThe balance of inclusivity, fairness and the competitive nature of sport will always be a complex area to navigate, and we thank those involved who have maintained integrity and respect throughout the process.\u201d Basketball Australia\u2019s director, Suzy Batkovic, said: \u201cI\u2019d like to acknowledge and sincerely thank Lexi for her cooperation, understanding and patience throughout this process \u2013 it\u2019s a complex space that continues to evolve. \u201cWhile Lexi is understandably disappointed with the outcome, I know she\u2019ll continue to support her NBL1 South team throughout the season and be an active member of the basketball community. In informing Rodgers and the Kilsyth Cobras of the decision, Batkovic added: \u201cI also want to make it clear, because it\u2019s important, that while this particular application was not approved based on criteria for elite competition, Basketball Australia encourages and promotes inclusivity at community level.\u201d Rodgers was a talented junior player but has previously acknowledged that transitioning might preclude her from playing the sport at the highest level, including her ultimate dream of representing the Opals. In response to BA\u2019s decision, Rodgers expressed her disappointment with the ruling and the message it projects. \u201cI sought a different outcome from Basketball Australia,\u201d Rodgers wrote in an Instagram post. \u201cI participated fully and in good faith with the process and eligibility criteria. Consistent with the views expressed by so many, I firmly believe I have a place as an athlete in women\u2019s basketball. \u201cBasketball is one of the great loves of my life. Like so many people who play every week across the country, the basketball court is where I feel safe, where I feel free, and where I feel I belong. \u201cThe backing of the players, coaches, my club and grassroots members has been overwhelming. Rodgers had been hoping to play for the Kilsyth Cobras in the the NBL1 South women\u2019s semi-professional basketball league that sits below the professional NBL and WNBL leagues, and is made up of North, South, East, West and Central conferences.\nTo assess Rodgers\u2019 case BA convened an expert panel led by Dr Peter Harcourt (BA chief medical officer, Commonwealth Games medical advisor), Suzy Batkovic OLY (BA board member, three-time Olympian) and Assoc Prof Diana Robinson. BA said in a statement they assess eligibility of prospective elite-level transgender athletes \u201con a \u2018case-by-case\u2019 basis, accounting for and balancing a range of factors\u201d, without specifying those factors. \u201cWe\u2019re still on a path of education and understanding,\u201d the governing body acknowledged. \u201cThe balance of inclusivity, fairness and the competitive nature of sport will always be a complex area to navigate, and we thank those involved who have maintained integrity and respect throughout the process.\u201d Basketball Australia\u2019s director, Suzy Batkovic, said: \u201cI\u2019d like to acknowledge and sincerely thank Lexi for her cooperation, understanding and patience throughout this process \u2013 it\u2019s a complex space that continues to evolve. \u201cWhile Lexi is understandably disappointed with the outcome, I know she\u2019ll continue to support her NBL1 South team throughout the season and be an active member of the basketball community. Like so many people who play every week across the country, the basketball court is where I feel safe, where I feel free, and where I feel I belong. \u201cThe backing of the players, coaches, my club and grassroots members has been overwhelming. I am so grateful for their desire to have me as part of their community. Such support fills me with pride, but also sends an honest message of equality to those who are also seeking belonging within sport. </figure>", "body": "<p>Former footballer Gary Ablett Sr is suing the AFL and two clubs, claiming he suffered damage from concussions as a result of their negligence.</p> <p>Ablett has launched proceedings in the Victorian supreme court against the AFL, Geelong Football Club and Hawthorn Football Club. The 61-year-old claims he suffered concussions while training and playing throughout his AFL career, which ran between 1982 and 1997.</p> <p>The Geelong icon is the highest-profile former player to reveal his health issues in relation to on-field concussion, now a major issue in world sport.</p> <aside class=\"element element-rich-link element--thumbnail\"> <p> <span>Related: </span><a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2023/mar/28/afl-acknowledges-link-between-head-trauma-and-cte-in-submission-to-senate-concussion-inquiry\">AFL acknowledges link between head trauma and CTE, in submission to Senate concussion inquiry</a> </p> </aside>  <p>A class action led by former Melbourne star Shaun Smith, Adelaide Crows premiership player Darren Jarman and the family of the late Shane Tuck was launched last month and more than 60 former players have signed up for the legal action, seeking compensation for pain and suffering, economic loss and medical expenses relating to permanent damage from concussions and other head knocks.</p> <p>Lawyers acting for Ablett said he underwent a scan last year which revealed brain damage. They claim the league and Ablett\u2019s former clubs \u201cknew or ought to have known of the potential long-term consequences of concussion suffered by the plaintiff\u201d.</p> <p>The court writ lodged says the AFL and two clubs owed Ablett a duty of care and should have avoided exposing him to unnecessary risk of harm, given he was more vulnerable to head strikes when playing as a key forward in 248 VFL/AFL games.</p> <p>Ablett alleges the organisations breached that duty and were negligent, and he has subsequently suffered loss, injury and damage as a result of the concussions. Ablett is claiming damages, interests and costs in the supreme court proceedings.</p> <p>\u201cI started getting symptoms that alarmed me to the point where I contacted Peter Jess, whom I\u2019m aware has been a concussion advocate for a number of past players,\u201d Ablett told News Corp.</p> <p>\u201cI told him of my concerns and Peter helped organise an MEG scan that American Military use. It showed I have significant structural and functional brain damage.</p> <p>\u201cObviously I was a very physical player and while I only got totally knocked out eight-10 times, I experienced being semi-concussed, such as ears ringing and out of it for a few minutes many dozens of times. But because you weren\u2019t knocked completely out you wouldn\u2019t even bother mentioning it.\u201d</p> <p>Ablett\u2019s lawyer Michel Margalit said Ablett was dealing with significant health problems. \u201cHe\u2019s not doing well. He\u2019s had significant illness over the previous years and he\u2019s finding that he\u2019s struggling more and more as time goes on,\u201d she told ABC News Breakfast.</p> <p>\u201cHe has really significant medical and care needs, and there are just no funds available through the AFL Players Association or any other hardship fund to assist him with those care needs.\u201d</p> <p>Margalit would not say how much Ablett was seeking but said it was a significant claim. \u201cIt is a very substantial case and could be really at the upper range of the allowance permitted by the compensation schemes in Victoria,\u201d she said. \u201cThis could be multiple millions of dollars.\u201d</p> <p>Last week, the AFL released a statement saying it had made more than 30 changes to concussion protocols, tribunal guidelines and on-field rules to protect players\u2019 heads. It also released a strategic plan for sport-related concussion in Australian football.</p> <p>It follows the NRL making the most significant changes to its concussion policy in nearly a decade, introducing a mandatory 11-day stand down for rugby league players after brain injuries.</p> <p>The AFL has been contacted for comment.</p>", "wordcount": "581", "firstPublicationDate": "2023-04-18T00:32:52Z", "isInappropriateForSponsorship": "false", "isPremoderated": "false", "lastModified": "2023-04-19T09:51:12Z", "productionOffice": "AUS", "publication": "theguardian.com", "shortUrl": "https://www.theguardian.com/p/nnjt4", "shouldHideAdverts": "false", "showInRelatedContent": "true", "thumbnail": "https://media.guim.co.uk/5a2d10d11d8f0227118b086a274eca67e978986d/0_0_3891_2335/500.jpg", "legallySensitive": "false", "lang": "en", "isLive": "true", "bodyText": "Former footballer Gary Ablett Sr is suing the AFL and two clubs, claiming he suffered damage from concussions as a result of their negligence. Ablett has launched proceedings in the Victorian supreme court against the AFL, Geelong Football Club and Hawthorn Football Club. The 61-year-old claims he suffered concussions while training and playing throughout his AFL career, which ran between 1982 and 1997. The Geelong icon is the highest-profile former player to reveal his health issues in relation to on-field concussion, now a major issue in world sport. A class action led by former Melbourne star Shaun Smith, Adelaide Crows premiership player Darren Jarman and the family of the late Shane Tuck was launched last month and more than 60 former players have signed up for the legal action, seeking compensation for pain and suffering, economic loss and medical expenses relating to permanent damage from concussions and other head knocks. Lawyers acting for Ablett said he underwent a scan last year which revealed brain damage. They claim the league and Ablett\u2019s former clubs \u201cknew or ought to have known of the potential long-term consequences of concussion suffered by the plaintiff\u201d. The court writ lodged says the AFL and two clubs owed Ablett a duty of care and should have avoided exposing him to unnecessary risk of harm, given he was more vulnerable to head strikes when playing as a key forward in 248 VFL/AFL games. Ablett alleges the organisations breached that duty and were negligent, and he has subsequently suffered loss, injury and damage as a result of the concussions. Ablett is claiming damages, interests and costs in the supreme court proceedings. \u201cI started getting symptoms that alarmed me to the point where I contacted Peter Jess, whom I\u2019m aware has been a concussion advocate for a number of past players,\u201d Ablett told News Corp. \u201cI told him of my concerns and Peter helped organise an MEG scan that American Military use. It showed I have significant structural and functional brain damage. \u201cObviously I was a very physical player and while I only got totally knocked out eight-10 times, I experienced being semi-concussed, such as ears ringing and out of it for a few minutes many dozens of times. But because you weren\u2019t knocked completely out you wouldn\u2019t even bother mentioning it.\u201d Ablett\u2019s lawyer Michel Margalit said Ablett was dealing with significant health problems. \u201cHe\u2019s not doing well. He\u2019s had significant illness over the previous years and he\u2019s finding that he\u2019s struggling more and more as time goes on,\u201d she told ABC News Breakfast. \u201cHe has really significant medical and care needs, and there are just no funds available through the AFL Players Association or any other hardship fund to assist him with those care needs.\u201d Margalit would not say how much Ablett was seeking but said it was a significant claim. \u201cIt is a very substantial case and could be really at the upper range of the allowance permitted by the compensation schemes in Victoria,\u201d she said. \u201cThis could be multiple millions of dollars.\u201d Last week, the AFL released a statement saying it had made more than 30 changes to concussion protocols, tribunal guidelines and on-field rules to protect players\u2019 heads. It also released a strategic plan for sport-related concussion in Australian football. It follows the NRL making the most significant changes to its concussion policy in nearly a decade, introducing a mandatory 11-day stand down for rugby league players after brain injuries. Ablett has launched proceedings in the Victorian supreme court against the AFL, Geelong Football Club and Hawthorn Football Club. The 61-year-old claims he suffered concussions while training and playing throughout his AFL career, which ran between 1982 and 1997. The Geelong icon is the highest-profile former player to reveal his health issues in relation to on-field concussion, now a major issue in world sport.\nA class action led by former Melbourne star Shaun Smith, Adelaide Crows premiership player Darren Jarman and the family of the late Shane Tuck was launched last month and more than 60 former players have signed up for the legal action, seeking compensation for pain and suffering, economic loss and medical expenses relating to permanent damage from concussions and other head knocks. Lawyers acting for Ablett said he underwent a scan last year which revealed brain damage. They claim the league and Ablett\u2019s former clubs \u201cknew or ought to have known of the potential long-term consequences of concussion suffered by the plaintiff\u201d. The court writ lodged says the AFL and two clubs owed Ablett a duty of care and should have avoided exposing him to unnecessary risk of harm, given he was more vulnerable to head strikes when playing as a key forward in 248 VFL/AFL games. Ablett alleges the organisations breached that duty and were negligent, and he has subsequently suffered loss, injury and damage as a result of the concussions. Ablett is claiming damages, interests and costs in the supreme court proceedings. \u201cI started getting symptoms that alarmed me to the point where I contacted Peter Jess, whom I\u2019m aware has been a concussion advocate for a number of past players,\u201d Ablett told News Corp. \u201cI told him of my concerns and Peter helped organise an MEG scan that American Military use. It showed I have significant structural and functional brain damage. \u201cObviously I was a very physical player and while I only got totally knocked out eight-10 times, I experienced being semi-concussed, such as ears ringing and out of it for a few minutes many dozens of times. But because you weren\u2019t knocked completely out you wouldn\u2019t even bother mentioning it.\u201d Ablett\u2019s lawyer Michel Margalit said Ablett was dealing with significant health problems. \u201cHe\u2019s not doing well. "https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/apr/18/total-solar-eclipse-2023-how-to-safely-view-in-australia-protect-your-eyes-when-where-what-time-thursday-morning", "apiUrl":
